question_text: Which embryological structure gives rise to the pinna?
explanation: The 1st and 2nd branchial arches give rise to the pinna (auricle) through six mesenchymal proliferation. These proliferations are called auricular hillocks and they fuse to form the auricle. The tissue from the second arch forms nearly all of the pinna. The tissue from the first arch forms the tragus and external auditory meatus. Image showing the development of pinna:
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient is incidentally noted to have the following finding. It is also present on the other ear. Which of the following is the cause for such abnormality?
options: Persistent opening of first branchial cleft
explanation: The given image showing the presence of sinus seen between the tragus and crus of the helix is suggestive of the preauricular sinus. It is due to improper fusion of the auricular tubercle formed from the first and second arches. The preauricular sinus is apparent at birth and is usually bilateral. There may be occasional sebaceous discharge from the punctum. It does not regress spontaneously.
subject: ENT

question_text: When are reconstructive surgeries for congenital malformations of pinna usually performed?
explanation: Reconstructive surgeries for congenital malformations of the pinna (auricle) are usually performed around 5 or 6 years of age. Autologous cartilages from ribs are harvested for these purposes and the ideal timing is between 6-10 years. At around 3 years of age, 85% of the auricular growth is complete and the cartilaginous growth is almost complete by 5 years. Surgery performed on the auricle after 5 years doesn't hinder further growth.
subject: ENT

question_text: Invagination of which of the following structures will form the external auditory meatus?
explanation: Invagination of the first pharyngeal arch gives rise to the external auditory meatus. Previously, it was believed that the external auditory meatus develops from the first pharyngeal cleft. But recent studies suggest that the first pharyngeal arch gives rise to the external auditory meatus.
subject: ENT

question_text: Examination of a child with otorrhea revealed two discharging sinuses. One was present on the floor of the left external auditory canal and the other on the left neck just below the angle of the mandible. Which of the following structures is abnormal here?
explanation: Given clinical scenario is suggestive of a collaural fistula, and the first branchial cleft is abnormal here. The fistula has two openings: One situated in the neck just below and behind the angle of mandible and The other one in the external canal or the middle ear. The track of the fistula traverses through the parotid in close relation to the facial nerve.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following structure develops from all three germ layers?
explanation: Tympanic membrane develops from all three germinal layers: Outer epithelial layer is formed by the ectoderm Inner mucosal layer by the endoderm Middle fibrous layer by the mesoderm
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the structures given below forms the eustachian tube?
explanation: The eustachian tube develops from the first pharyngeal pouch. Initially, the first pharyngeal pouch forms the tubotympanic recess. The distal part of this recess widens to form the middle ear cavity. The proximal part forms the eustachian tube.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following pharyngeal arches gives rise to malleus and incus?
explanation: The first pharyngeal arch gives rise to malleus and incus. Stapes superstructure is formed from the second arch whereas the stapes footplate develops from the otic capsule.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following arches gives rise to the stapes?
explanation: The stapes develop from the second arch, except for its footplate and annular ligament, which develop from the otic capsule.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following attains adult size before birth?
explanation: Ear ossicles attain adult size before birth. The development of the middle ear: The ossicles are full-sized cartilage models by 15 weeks of gestation. Endochondral ossification is complete by 25 weeks. The middle ear is adult-sized at birth.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following does not reach adult size at birth?
explanation: The mastoid does not reach adult size at birth. It develops fully by 2 years of age. In infants and children up to 2 years of age, the mastoid process is not developed completely. So, the facial nerve lies just beneath the skin near its exit. Hence, during surgical procedures, the incision is given slanting posteriorly, avoiding the lower part of the mastoid. This spares the facial nerve.
subject: ENT

question_text: An ENT surgeon has difficulty locating the mastoid antrum due to the presence of Korner's septum. Which of the following sutures is persistent in this case?
explanation: The persistence of the petrosquamous suture is called Korner’s septum and it is responsible for the difficulty in locating the mastoid antrum and the deeper cells. Korner’s septum separates superficial squamosal cells from the deep petrosal cells. Incomplete removal of disease at mastoidectomy can occur if Korner’s septum is not identified. Mastoid antrum cannot be reached unless the Korner’s septum has been removed. Below is an image showing Korner's septum -
subject: ENT

question_text: From which of the following structure does the saccule develop?
explanation: The saccule develops from pars inferior. The development of the inner ear begins in the 3rd week of fetal life and is completed by the 16th week. The surface ectoderm on each side of the rhombencephalon thickens to form otic/auditory placodes, which then invaginate to form the otic vesicle (otocysts). The cells of the otic vesicle differentiate to form ganglion cells, which later develop into the vestibulocochlear ganglia. Later each otic vesicle divides into a dorsal component called pars superior and a ventral component called pars inferior. Pars superior gives rise to the utricle, semicircular canals, and endolymphatic ducts. Pars inferior gives rise to saccule and cochlear duct. The saccule is connected to the cochlea through a narrow duct called ductus reuniens.
subject: ENT

question_text: From how many ossification centre(s) does the inner ear develop?
explanation: The inner ear develops from 14 ossification centres.
subject: ENT

question_text:
When does the fetus start hearing?
10 weeks
explanation: The fetus starts hearing in the womb of the mother by 20 weeks of gestation due to sufficient development of the cochlea. Anatomy of External Ear
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the pinna made up of?
explanation: The pinna and the external auditory canal are made up of yellow elastic cartilage. It is also called the auricular cartilage.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 25-year-old woman undergoes a rhinoplasty procedure to correct a deformity of her nose. Auricular cartilage is harvested from her right pinna. Which of the following sites cannot be used to harvest the cartilage?
explanation: I cisura terminalis cannot be used to harvest cartilage as it is devoid of cartilage. It is the part of the pinna between the tragus and the crus of helix. Being devoid of cartilage, the incision for endaural approach for ear surgery can be made here. The lobule is also devoid of cartilage. Hence, it is the safest site for piercing. The parts of the pinna are:
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the skin over the pinna?
explanation: The skin over the pinna is loosely adherent on the medial or cranial side. Hence, it is pinchable. The skin is firmly adherent to the perichondrium on the lateral side and is non-pinchable.
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the length of external auditory canal?
explanation: The length of the external auditory canal is about 24 mm. It extends from the bottom of the concha to the tympanic membrane. It has two parts: Outer cartilaginous part - 8mm Inner bony part- 16mm
subject: ENT

question_text: You are an intern asked to do an otoscopic examination of a young adult. In which direction will you pull the pinna to visualize the tympanic membrane?
explanation: The pinna has to be pulled upwards, backwards and laterally to visualise the tympanic membrane. This is done to bring the bony and cartilaginous parts of the external auditory canal in alignment. The inner bony part is directed downwards, forwards, and medially. The outer cartilaginous part is directed upwards, backwards, and medially.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following statements is true about the external auditory canal?
options: Outer 1/3rd is cartilaginous and inner 2/3rd is bony
Outer 2/3rd is cartilaginous and inner 1/3rd is bony
Outer 1/3rd is bony and inner 2/3rd is cartilaginous
Outer 2/3rd is bony and inner 1/3rd is cartilaginous
explanation: The outer 1/3rd is cartilaginous (8mm) and the inner 2/3rd is bony (16mm) in the external auditory canal.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient with otitis externa develops parotitis. You suspect that the infection has spread through the fissures of Santorini. Which of the following best describes this fissure?
options: Connection between middle ear and pharynx
Connection between Inner ear and middle ear
explanation: Fissures of Santorini are the two deficiencies in the cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal. They provide a pathway for the spread of parotid or superficial mastoid infections to the canal or vice versa. The bony canal also has a deficiency called the foramen of Huschke which acts as a pathway for the spread of infections and tumours to the deep lobe of the parotid.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the external auditory canal?
options: Outer 2/3rd is cartilaginous and inner 1/3rd is bony part
Furuncles are seen in the cartilaginous part
Fissures of Santorini are present in bony part and permits parotid and superficial mastoid infections to spread to canal
Isthmus is present at junction of cartilaginous and fibrous part
explanation: Furuncles (staphylococcal infection of the hair follicles) are seen only in the outer one-third of the canal since hair is confined to the outer canal. Skin is also very tightly adherent to the cartilage and hence furuncles are extremely painful.
subject: ENT

question_text: What are ceruminous glands?
explanation: Ceruminous glands are modified apocrine sweat glands. They open into hair follicles & participate in wax production. Apocrine glands release their products by decapitation. It is a process by which membrane-bound cytoplasm from the apical surface of the cells buds off into the lumen of the duct and is secreted. Some apocrine glands have specific names. Those on the eyelids are referred to as Moll’s glands, and those on the external auditory meatus are termed ceruminous glands.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following statements is true regarding isthmus?
options: It is just lateral to the petrotympanic suture.
It is at the bony cartilaginous junction of EAC.
It is the narrowest part of ear canal.
explanation: The isthmus is the narrowest part of the external auditory canal (EAC). EAC measures about 24 mm long, cartilaginous part forms the outer one-third (8 mm) and bony part forms two-third (16 mm) of the canal. Isthmus is situated 6 mm lateral to the tympanic membrane in the bony part of the EAC. Foreign bodies that go beyond the isthmus are difficult to remove and are called impacted.
subject: ENT

question_text: You observe a normal-looking tympanic membrane on otoscopy. What is its colour?
explanation: The normal tympanic membrane is pearly grey in color. It is thin and semitranslucent.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the tympanic membrane?
options: It is derived from all 3 germ layers
It seperates external from middle ear
explanation: Peripheral parts are more mobile than the central part where the handle of the malleus is attached The tympanic membrane develops from all three germinal layers. It has 3 layers – Outer epithelial layer from ectoderm Middle fibrous layer from mesoderm Inner mucosal layer endoderm.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is false about the tympanic membrane?
explanation: The tympanic membrane has a thickness of 0.1mm. The dimensions of the tympanic membrane are Length: 9-10mm Width: 8-9mm Area: 90 mm2 Subtends an angle of 55° with horizontal The medial (inner) surface is convex and the lateral surface is concave. The most depressed part of its concavity is called the umbo, to which the tip of the malleus is attached. Image: Right tympanic membrane
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the other name for Shrapnell’s membrane?
explanation: Pars flaccida is also known as Shrapnell’s membrane. Pars flaccida is situated above the lateral process of malleus between the notch of Rivinus and the anterior and posterior mallear folds.
subject: ENT

question_text: During an otoscopic examination of a patient, where will the cone of light be seen on the tympanic membrane?
explanation: A bright cone of light can be seen radiating from the tip of malleus (umbo) to the periphery in the anteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following nerves supply a major part of pinna?
explanation: Greater auricular nerve (C2,C3) supplies most of the medial surface and posterior portion of lateral surface of the external ear. Nerve Derivation Region supplied Greater/Great auricular nerve Cervical plexus C2,C 3 Medial surface and posterior part of the lateral surface Lesser occipital nerve Cervical plexus C2 Superior portion of medial su rface Nerve Derivation Region supplied Nerve Derivation Region supplied Nerve Derivation Region supplied Auricular branch Vagus (X) Concha and antihelixSome su pply medial surface (eminetia concha) Auriculotemporal nerve Mandibular (V3) Tragus, crus of helix and adja cent helix Facial (VII) Small region in the root of co ncha and retroauricular groo ve
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient develops tingling and numbness along the upper part of the medial surface of the pinna. Which nerve is most likely to be affected?
explanation: The upper part of the medial surface of the pinna is supplied by the lesser occipital nerve. Nerve Derivation Region supplied Greater/Great auricular nerve Cervical plexus C2,C 3 Medial surface and posterior part of the lateral surface Lesser occipital nerve Cervical plexus C2 Superior portion of medial su rface Auricular branch Vagus (X) Concha and antihelixSome su pply medial surface (eminetia concha) Auriculotemporal nerve Mandibular (V3) Tragus, crus of helix and adja cent helix Facial (VII) Small region in the root of co ncha and retroauricular groo ve
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient coughs when removing excess cerumen from the ear. This is due to the stimulation of which of the following nerves?
explanation: Reflex cough is due to stimulation of the auricular branch of vagus. It can occur when cleaning or during an examination of the ear. Nerve Derivation Region supplied Greater/Great auricular nerve Cervical plexus C2,C 3 Medial surface and posterior part of the lateral surface Lesser occipital nerve Cervical plexus C2 Superior portion of medial su rface Auricular branch Vagus (X) Concha and antihelixSome su pply medial surface (eminetia concha) Auriculotemporal nerve Mandibular (V3) Tragus, crus of helix and adja cent helix Facial (VII) Small region in the root of co ncha and retroauricular groo ve
subject: ENT

question_text: What is Arnold's nerve?
explanation: Auricular branch of vagus (CN X) is also called Arnold’s nerve or Alderman's nerve. Tympanic branch of CN IX is also called Jacobson’s nerve. Sensory root of the facial nerve is also called the nerve of Wrisberg and carries secretomotor fibres to the lacrimal gland and salivary glands, and brings fibres of taste and general sensation.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following cranial nerves do not supply the tympanic membrane?
explanation: The spinal accessory nerve (CN XI) does not supply the tympanic membrane. It is supplied by: Lateral surface - Anterior half by auriculotemporal nerve (CN V3) Posterior half by auricular branch of vagus nerve (CN X). Medial surface - Tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (Jacobson's nerve) CN IX.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 25-year-old patient presents with bleeding from his ear following a road traffic accident. Which of the following could be its reason?
explanation: A temporal bone fracture can cause bleeding from the ear as it is related to the roof of the middle ear and the external auditory canal. The relations of the external auditory canal are: Superior - Middle cranial fossa Inferior - Parotid gland Anterior - Temporomandibular joint Posterior - Mastoid air cells and facial nerve.
subject: ENT

question_text:
Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to?
Auriculotemporal nerve
explanation: Cough on scratching the external acoustic canal is due to the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (Arnold's nerve). Arnold's nerve supplies the concha and corresponding eminence on the medial surface. It also supplies the posterior wall and floor of the external auditory canal. Scratching or mechanical stimulation of the ear leads to activation of Arnold's nerve, which evokes reflex cough (ear-cough reflex/otorespiratory reflex). The image below shows the nerve supply of the pinna: Causesofreferred otalgia Nerveresponsible Site Temporomandibular joint an d dental conditions, parotid i nfections/tumor, and anterior 2/3rd of tongue Auriculotemporal nerve Tragal area, crus of the helix, and anterior wall and roof of the external auditory canal. Causesofreferred otalgia Nerveresponsible Site Causesofreferred otalgia Nerveresponsible Site Causesofreferred otalgia Nerveresponsible Site Acute tonsillitis, peritonsillar abscess, carcinoma base of t he tongue or tonsils (orophar ynx) The glossopharyngeal nerve ( Jacobson's) Medial surface of the tympan ic membrane, and middle ear Carcinoma of the larynx (cou gh), hypopharynx, epiglottis, vallecula, esophagus, and thy roid Auricular branch of the vagus nerve (Arnold's/Alderman's nerve) Concha, posterior wall, and fl oor of the external auditory c anal Cervical spondylitis Great auricular nerve (C2,3) Lateral and medial surfaces o f the pinna Acoustic neuroma Facial nerve (nervus interme dius/nerve of Wrisberg) Concha, retro auricular groov e, and posterosuperior part o f the external auditory meatu s. Numbness in the posterosu perior meatal wall known as Hitzelberger's sign, is seen in acoustic neuroma. Anatomy of Middle Ear
subject: ENT

question_text: Otoendoscopy of a patient revealed cholesteatoma limited to the protympanum. Which of the following sites is being referred to here?
options: The developmental predecessor of the middle ear
The anterior part of middle ear
The part of the middle ear foremost in conduction of sound
The part of middle ear around the eustachian tube
explanation: The part of the middle ear around the eustachian tube is referred to as the protympanum. The middle ear is divided into 3 main parts: Epitympanum/attic- above the level of pars tensa, medial to pars flaccida, and scutum. Mesotympanum- opposite the pars tensa Hypotympanum- below the level of TM
subject: ENT

question_text: Which is the narrowest part of the middle ear?
explanation: Mesotympanum is the narrowest part of the middle ear. Transverse diameters of middle ear at various levels are: Epitympanum- 6 mm Mesotympanum- 2 mm Hypotympanum- 4 mm.
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the distance between promontory and tympanic membrane?
explanation: The distance between the promontory and tympanic membrane, i.e., the transverse diameter at the level of mesotympanum, is 2 mm.
subject: ENT

question_text: In a patient with necrotizing otitis media, CT scans reveal erosions of the structures present in the epitympanum. Which of the following is least likely to be involved?
explanation: Footplate of stapes is least likely to be involved in the given scenario because it is not a part of epitympanum. Epitympanum contains: Head of the malleus Incudomalleolar joint Short process and body of the incus
subject: ENT

question_text: While performing tympanoplasty, the ENT surgeon notices that the floor of the middle ear is deficient. Which of the following structures is susceptible to injury?
explanation: The internal jugular vein is susceptible to injury in this given clinical scenario. The floor of the middle ear is related to the internal jugular vein. Occasionally, the floor is deficient and the jugular bulb is then covered only by fibrous tissue and a mucous membrane making it susceptible to injury during middle ear surgery. The middle ear can be likened to a room with a roof, floor, and 4 walls (anterior, posterior, medial & lateral), as shown in the image:
subject: ENT

question_text: Which part of middle ear is formed by tegmen tympani?
explanation: The tegmen tympani forms the roof of the middle ear. It separates the tympanic cavity from the middle cranial fossa. It also extends posteriorly to form the roof of the aditus and antrum as tegmen mastoidea. The following images shows the tegmen tympani and relations of middle ear:
subject: ENT

question_text: CT scans of a patient with nasopharyngeal carcinoma reveal that the tumor has undergone a local spread, destroying the anterior wall of the middle ear. Which of the following structures is least likely to be involved?
explanation: The prominence of the facial canal is least likely to be injured in this given clinical scenario because it is a part of the medial wall of the middle ear and not the anterior wall. The anterior wall of the middle ear is related to the following structures: Eustachian tube The canal for tensor tympani Internal carotid artery
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following structures is not a part of the lateral wall of the middle ear?
explanation: The subiculum is not a part of the lateral wall of the middle ear. It is present in the medial wall, below the sinus tympani. The lateral wall of the middle ear separates it from the external ear. It contains: Pars tensa lying opposite to the mesotympanum Pars flaccida and scutum lying opposite to the epitympanum. Scutum or lateral attic wall is a wedge-shaped bone that separates the epitympanum from the external auditory canal. It can be eroded in attic cholesteatomas. Image showing the boundaries of middle ear:
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following structures is not related to the pyramid?
explanation: The round window is not related to the pyramid because it is a medial wall structure whereas the pyramid is a projection present in the posterior wall. Image showing pyramidal eminence: The pyramid has the following features: It contains stapedius muscle and the tendon leaves the pyramid to attach the neck of the stapes It divides the posterior space into a medial sinus tympani and a lateral facial recess. It serves as the landmark for the second genu of the facial nerve and houses the vertical segment of the facial nerve & the nerve to stapedius. The aditus (opening to the mastoid) lies just above it.
subject: ENT

question_text: You are approaching the middle ear via the mastoid through the facial recess. Regarding anatomical relations of facial recess, which of the following is true?
options: Bound medially by horizontal part of facial nerve
explanation: Facial recess or the posterior sinus is a depression in the posterior wall lateral to the pyramid. It is bounded medially by the vertical part of the facial nerve, laterally by the chorda tympani and above, by the fossa incudis. Facial recess is important surgically, as direct access can be made through this into the middle ear without disturbing the posterior canal wall. This is called intact canal wall technique. Image showing the facial recess:
subject: ENT

question_text: A child with cholesteatoma undergoes surgical removal via an intact canal wall procedure. Through which of the following structures is the middle ear approached?
explanation: In intact canal wall surgeries, the middle ear is approached through the suprapyramidal recess. Surgically, facial recess/posterior sinus/supra pyramidal recess is important, as direct access can be made through this into the middle ear without disturbing the posterior canal wall (intact canal wall technique). Image showing the facial recess:
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following structures forms the promontory?
explanation: The basal turn of the cochlea forms the promontory. The promontory is a bulge in the middle ear's medial wall, which is formed by the labyrinth. It gives 2 extensions: Subiculum below to the round window. Ponticulus to the posterior wall.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which is the smallest bone in the body?
explanation: The smallest bone in the body is the stapes. It is also called a stirrup as it looks like the stirrup/footrest for jockeys while riding a horse. The malleus is called the hammer. The incus is called the anvil (large metal striking surface for shaping metals).
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the type of joint between the middle ear ossicles?
explanation: The type of joint between the middle ear ossicles is the synovial joint. The malleo-incudal joint is a saddle type. The incudostapedial joint is a ball and socket type.
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the structure marked in the given image?
explanation: The marked structure is incus. This is an image taken during mastoidectomy. The incus articulates with the malleus and has a short process and a long process. The long process articulates with the head of the stapes. CT: chorda tympani; I: incus; JB: jugular bulb; LSC: lateral semicirular canal; M: malleus; PSC: posterior semicircular canal; S: stapes; SM: stapedius muscle; SSC: superior semicircular canal; VIIms: mastoid segment of VII cranial nerve; VIIts: tympanic segment of VII cranial nerve.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is attached to fossa incudis?
explanation: Fossa incudis gives attachment to the short process of incus. Fossa incudis is a depression on the posterior wall of the middle ear. It lies lateral to aditus ad antrum.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which among the following structures covers the oval window?
explanation: The oval window is covered by the footplate of stapes.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following structures vibrates when the stapes footplate is moved?
explanation: The movement of the stapes footplate causes vibration in the scala vestibuli. This is because the scala vestibuli, which opens at the oval window, is closed by the footplate of stapes. The scala tympani opens at the round window. Image depicting the transmission of sound:
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following covers the round window?
explanation: The round window or the fenestra cochlea is covered by the secondary tympanic membrane.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is related to processus cochleariformis?
explanation: Processus cochleariformis is related to the tendon of tensor tympani Just anterior to the oval window, the medial wall presents a hook-like projection called the processus cochleariformis. The tendon of tensor tympani takes a turn here to get the attachment to the neck of the malleus. It is also the landmark for the 1st genu of the facial nerve and the geniculate ganglion.
subject: ENT

question_text: Impedance audiometry performed in a patient showed absent stapedial reflex. Which of the following nerves is most likely to be injured?
explanation: The absence of stapedial reflex is suggestive of facial nerve injury among the given options. The facial nerve forms the efferent arm of the stapedial or acoustic reflex. Anatomy of stapedius muscle: Stapedius is a second arch muscle and it arises from the pyramid and attaches to the neck of the stapes. Its action is to lateralize the stapes & dampen loud sounds. It is supplied by a branch of the facial nerve.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following nerves supply the tensor tympani?
options: Branch from the medial pterygoid nerve
explanation: Tensor tympani is supplied by a branch from the medial pterygoid nerve which is a direct branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (and not the posterior division of the mandibular nerve). Anatomical features of tensor tympani muscle: The tensor tympani develops from the first arch. Arises from the semicanal for tensor tympani in the anterior wall of the middle ear. Hooks around the processus cochleariformis in the medial wall Attaches the neck of the malleus in the lateral wall. Action is to medialize the malleus & conduct sound. The posterior division of the mandibular nerve is mainly sensory and divides into three branches: The auriculotemporal nerve. The lingual nerve. The inferior alveolar (dental) nerve. The motor component of the posterior division of the mandibular nerve supplies the mylohyoid and anterior belly of the digastric.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following cranial nerves provide sensory supply to middle ear cavity?
explanation: The sensory supply to the middle ear cavity is provided by the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve. It forms the tympanic plexus with the caroticotympanic nerves from the internal carotid plexus of the sympathetic fibers.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following nerves does not contribute to the tympanic plexus?
explanation: The tympanic branch of the facial nerve does not contribute to the tympanic plexus. The tympanic plexus is formed by 3 nerves : The glossopharyngeal nerve forms the tympanic branch The sympathetic fibers from internal carotid plexus forms the superior and inferior caroticotympanic nerve. The tympanic plexus innervates the tympanic membrane's medial surface, the tympanic cavity, mastoid air cells, and the bony eustachian tube. It also carries secretory fibres for the parotid gland, and in Frey's syndrome, the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve can be sectioned.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is true regarding the facial nerve course in the middle ear?
options: Horizontal in the medial wall, vertical in the posterior wall
Vertical in medial wall, horizontal in posterior wall
Horizontal in the medial wall, vertical in the anterior wall
Vertical in medial wall, horizontal in anterior wall
explanation: The facial nerve runs horizontally in the medial wall and vertically in the posterior wall of the middle ear. The medial wall is related to the 3rd part, which runs from 1st genu (processus cochleariformis) to 2nd genu (pyramid). It is called the tympanic or horizontal part. The posterior wall is related to the 4th part, which runs from the genu (pyramid) to the stylomastoid foramen where it exits the temporal bone. It is called the mastoid or the vertical part. Image showing course of facial nerve in ear:
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is true regarding the course of chorda tympani in the middle ear?
options: Enters middle ear lateral to tympanic membrane
Runs in between the malleus and incus
Enters middle ear via the canal of Huguier
explanation: In the middle ear, the chorda tympani runs in between the malleus and incus. Image showing the course of chorda tympani:
subject: ENT

question_text:
Which of the following is false about the lesser petrosal nerve?
It is formed over the promontory of the middle ear
options: It is a branch of the tympanic plexus
Its fibers synapse in the pterygopalatine ganglion
explanation: The fibers of the lesser petrosal nerve synapse in the otic ganglion and not pterygopalatine ganglion. The lesser petrosal nerve is the parasympathetic or secretomotor nerve for the parotid glands. It arises over the promontory of the middle ear from the tympanic plexus (glossopharyngeal nerve). Image showing lesser petrosal nerve synapsing with otic ganglion: Anatomy of Mastoid
subject: ENT

question_text: Where does one find flat non-ciliated epithelium in the middle ear cleft?
explanation: The flat non-ciliated epithelium is found in the mastoid air cells and the epitympanum. The mucosal lining of the middle ear is continuous with that of the nasopharynx but shows variations: Bony eustachian tube- ciliated columnar Cartilaginous eustachian tube- ciliated pseudostratified columnar Protympanum- ciliated columnar Most of the middle ear space- cuboidal Epitympanum & mastoid air cells- flat non-ciliated.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which is the largest mastoid air cell?
explanation: The mastoid antrum is the largest mastoid air cell. It is the most constant mastoid air cell because it is present even in a sclerotic mastoid. The attic or the epitympanum is the part of the middle ear adjacent to its roof. Aditus ad antrum is the pathway or the connection between mastoid antrum and attic.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient with acute coalescent mastoiditis undergoes cortical mastoidectomy. Which of the following is used as a surgical landmark to locate the mastoid antrum?
explanation: Macewen’s (suprameatal) triangle is used as a surgical landmark to locate the mastoid antrum. In an adult, the antrum lies 12–15 mm from the surface. This triangle is also the site of tenderness in acute mastoiditis.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following structures does not form the boundary of the suprameatal triangle?
options: Posterosuperior segment of bony external auditory canal
Tangent drawn to external auditory canal
explanation: Promontory does not form the boundary of the suprameatal triangle. Boundaries of MacEwen’s (suprameatal) triangle: Superior- temporal line Anterior- posterosuperior segment of the bony external auditory canal Posterior- the line drawn as a tangent to the external canal. It is an important landmark to locate the mastoid antrum in mastoid surgery. Image showing the suprameatal triangle:
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is not a pneumatic bone?
explanation: The mandible is not a pneumatic bone. Some bones of the skull, notably the mastoid process of the temporal bone and the paranasal sinuses of the frontal, maxilla, sphenoid and ethmoid bones, many of the internal cavities are filled with air, i.e. they are variably pneumatized. The maxillae are the largest of the pneumatized bones of the midface. They contain the maxillary air sinuses and bear the upper teeth. The mastoid consists of a bone cortex with a 'honeycomb' of air cells underneath.
subject: ENT

question_text: You are evaluating a patient with past history of chronic suppurative otitis media. The CT is suggestive of sclerosis and loss of aeration of mastoid air cells. What is this type of mastoid pneumatization called?
explanation: The type of mastoid pneumatization in the given clinical scenario is acellular or sclerotic mastoid. Here, sclerosis and loss of aeration of mastoid air cells are seen. Sclerotic mastoids contain only mastoid antrum which is small with anteposed sigmoid sinus. It can occur due to eustachian or middle ear disease in childhood preventing mastoid development. Other types of mastoids pneumatization: Well-pneumatized or cellular- contains multiple air spaces Diploetic- contains air cells and marrow spaces.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is not a part of the temporal bone?
explanation: The parietal is not a part of the temporal bone. The temporal bone consists of the following parts: Squamous part- anterosuperiorly It articulates with the parietal bone. The persistence of petrosquamous suture is called Korner's septum. Mastoid part- posteroinferiorly. Its outer surface forms a conical projection called the mastoid process. Sternocleidomastoid, splenius capitis and longissimus capitis attach here. Petrous part- medially The arcuate eminence is related to the superior semicircular canal below The posterior surface contains the internal auditory meatus (IAM). The vestibular aqueduct is present behind the IAM. The inferior surface contains the carotid canal and the jugular fossa (jugular notch). Tympanic part- centrally It contains the external auditory meatus (EAM), and the bony EAM is 16 mm long. The suprameatal triangle is present above the EAM Styloid process- anteroinferior it gives attachment to: 3 muscles - stylohyoid, styloglossus, stylopharyngeus 2 ligaments - stylohyoid ligament, stylomandibular ligament Zygomatic process The temporal bone gives the zygomatic process which articulates with the temporal process of the zygomatic bone to form the zygomatic arch.
subject: ENT

question_text: While performing cortical mastoidectomy, the head and neck surgeon drills the bone up to the Citelli's angle. This angle is seen between which of the following structures?
explanation: Citelli’s angle or sinodural angle is the angle between the sigmoid sinus plate and tegmen or dural plate. The boundaries of cortical mastoidectomy are: Tegmen plate superiorly Sigmoid sinus plate posteriorly Posterior bony external auditory canal wall anteriorly This is also called the triangle of attack. Image showing sinodural angle:
subject: ENT

question_text: Endolymphatic sac surgery is performed on a patient who has Ménière disease with intractable vertigo. Which of the following is the surgical landmark to identify the sac?
explanation: Donaldson’s line is the surgical landmark to locate the endolymphatic sac. It is an imaginary line drawn from the horizontal semicircular canal, which bisects the posterior semicircular canal. The endolymphatic sac lies just below it. Image showing Donaldson’s line: ELS: Endolymphatic sac; HSCC: Horizontal semicircular canal, PSCC: Posterior semicircular canal; PF dura: Posterior fossa dura.
subject: ENT

question_text:
A head and neck surgeon enters the cranial cavity via the Trautmann’s triangle. Which fossa can be approached through this triangle?
Anterior cranial fossa
explanation: Trautmann’s triangle is a landmark to approach the posterior cranial fossa. It is a triangular area on the medial wall of the mastoid antrum. It is bounded superiorly by the dura or superior petrosal sinus, posteriorly by the sigmoid sinus, and anteriorly by the bony labyrinth. Since here the bone is thin, it can lead to the spreading of infections from the mastoid to the cerebellum. Image showing the Trautmann’s triangle: Anatomy of Inner Ear
subject: ENT

question_text: You are assisting an ENT surgeon who places a cochlear implant into the scala tympani. Which part of the bone is the implant placed in?
explanation: The implant is placed in the cochlea which is a part of the inner ear. The inner ear lies in the petrous part of the temporal bone. The inner ear is well protected between the medial wall of the middle ear and the internal auditory canal.
subject: ENT

question_text: Where is the electrode placed in cochlear implant procedures?
explanation: The electrode of a cochlear implant is placed in the scala tympani. It allows for the electrodes to be in close proximity to the ganglion cells and their dendrites which are located in the modiolus and bony spiral lamina of the cochlea. A cochlear implant is an electronic device for severe to profound SNHL and who cannot benefit from a hearing aid. It converts sound to an electrical signal (transduction) and delivers this to the auditory nerve. Prerequisites include an intact cochlear nerve and higher auditory pathway. In the auditory brainstem implant, the site of the implant is the lateral recess of the fourth ventricle. It is used when the cochlear nerve is not intact.
subject: ENT

question_text: You are examining the CT scan images of the temporal bone of a patient. Which of the following structures can not be visualized on the CT scan?
explanation: The organ of Corti present in the scala media is a part of the membranous labyrinth. It cannot be visualized on a CT scan. Bony labyrinth consists of: Vestibule Cochlea Semicircular canals These structures can be seen on a CT scan of the temporal bone. Membranous labyrinth consists of: Saccule and utricle Cochlear duct/ scala media Semicircular ducts Endolymphatic duct and sac
subject: ENT

question_text: The bony cochlea is a coiled tube making turns around a bony pyramid called
explanation: The bony cochlea is a coiled tube making 2.5 to 2.75 turns round a central pyramid of bone called modiolus.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which two structures does the helicotrema connect?
explanation: The scala vestibuli and scala tympani communicate with each other at the apex of the cochlea through an opening called the helicotrema. Scala tympani and subarachnoid space are connected by the aqueduct of cochlea.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is not a part of the bony cochlea?
explanation: Scala media is part of the membranous cochlea. The bony cochlea is a coiled tube with 2.5 to 2.75 turns around a central pyramid of bone called modiolus. From the modiolus laterally into the tube winding like the thread of a screw is the osseous spiral lamina. Spiral lamina along with membranes attached to it divide the tube into 3 parts: Scala vestibuli above Scala media in between Scala tympani below. The scala vestibule & tympani are part of the bony labyrinth and are filled with perilymph. They communicate with each other at the apex called helicotrema. Scala media is part of the membranous cochlea and contains the sensory organ of Corti with hair cells.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the vestibule?
options: It is a part of the membranous labyrinth
It is part of the auditory pathway
explanation: Vestibule contains the spherical recess for the saccule. It is part of the bony labyrinth and not part of the auditory pathway. The inside of the medial wall presents with recesses & openings: A spherical recess, which lodges the saccule An elliptical recess, which lodges the utricle An opening for aqueduct of vestibule An opening for the semicircular canals
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient has undergone a high-resolution CT of the temporal bone which confirmed a diagnosis of semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome. Which of the following will not be affected?
explanation: The medial semicircular canal does not exist. The semicircular canals are part of the bony labyrinth. They house the semicircular ducts which are the end organs for angular momentum. They are 3 in number: Superior also called anterior in the X-axis Posterior in Y-axis Lateral also called horizontal in Z-axis. Semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome is an inner ear abnormality where the bony covering of the semicircular canals is very thin or absent. It usually affects the superior semicircular canal but can rarely involve the posterior or lateral semicircular canals. The superior semicircular canal is present inferior to the arcuate eminence of the temporal bone.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following structures is the crus commune a part of?
explanation: Crus commune is a part of the semicircular canals. Each semicircular canal has 2 ends, ampullated & non-ampullated which open into the vestibule. The non-ampullated ends of posterior and superior canals unite to form a common channel called crus commune.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 45-year old construction worker presents to you with hearing loss. His audiogram reveals a diagnosis of noise-induced hearing loss. Which organ is most likely to be affected?
explanation: The organ of Corti is the sensory organ of hearing and is situated on the basilar membrane. Chronic exposure to loud noises may mechanically damage the organ of Corti and result in noise induced hearing loss.
subject: ENT

question_text: The organ of Corti is situated over which membrane?
explanation: The organ of Corti is situated over the basilar membrane in scala media. The membranes of the cochlear duct: The basilar membrane sepearates scala media from tympani and supports the organ of Corti. Reissner’s membrane seperates scala media from scala vestibuli. Stria vascularis is the lateral part of scala media which secretes endolymph. Shrapnell’s membrane is another name for pars flaccida of the tympanic membrane.
subject: ENT

question_text: What does the stria vascularis secrete?
explanation: The stria vascularis contains vascular epithelium and is concerned with secretion of endolymph.
subject: ENT

question_text: Where is the endolymph is seen?
explanation: Endolymph is present in the scala media.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following fluids have high potassium and low sodium content?
explanation: Endolymph is akin to intracellular fluid and hence high in potassium. Perilymph and cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) are both extracellular fluids (ECF) that are high in sodium.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 20-year-old man diagnosed with meningitis later develops sensorineural hearing loss. Which structure is responsible for the spread of his infection to the cochlea?
explanation: Infections can spread from the CNS to the inner ear or vice versa through the aqueduct of cochlea. Scala tympani is connected with the subarachnoid space through this structure.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following statements is true about membranous cochlea?
options: Higher frequencies heard at the base
Lower frequencies are heard at the base
Higher frequencies are heard at the apex
All frequencies are heard at the apex
explanation: Higher frequencies of sound are heard at the basal coil while lower frequencies are heard at the apical coil of membranous cochlea. This is because the length of basilar membrane increases as we proceed from the basal coil to the apical coil.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following sentence is false?
options: Cristae are present in semicircular canal
Maculae are present in utricle and saccule
Organ of corti rests over basilar membrane
Reissner's membrane overlies the organ of Corti
explanation: The tectorial membrane overlies the organ of Corti. Reissner's membrane separates scala vestibuli and scala media. The basilar membrane supports the organ of Corti. The sensory epithelium of the utricle and saccule is called macula and is concerned with linear acceleration and deceleration. The ampullated end of each semicircular canal contains a thickened ridge of neuroepithelium called crista ampullaris.
subject: ENT

question_text: Angular movements are sensed by
explanation: Semicircular canals respond to angular acceleration and deceleration. The receptors are the cristae, located in the ampullated ends of the three semicircular ducts. Their utricle and saccule which contain macula, are stimulated by linear acceleration and deceleration or gravitational pull during the head tilts.
subject: ENT

question_text: The endolymphatic duct is a continuation of which of the following?
explanation: The endolymphatic duct is formed by the union of two ducts, one each from the saccule and the utricle. Ductus reunions connect the cochlear duct to the saccule. The aqueduct of cochlea (cochlear aqueduct) connects scala tympani to the subarachnoid space.
subject: ENT

question_text: Endolymphatic duct connects
options: Scala vestibuli with aqueduct of cochlea
explanation: The endolymphatic duct is formed by the union of two ducts, one each from the saccule and the utricle. It passes through the vestibular aqueduct. Its terminal part is dilated to form an endolymphatic sac, which lies between the two layers of dura on the posterior surface of the petrous bone. The scala vestibuli and scala tympani are filled with perilymph and communicate with each other at the apex of cochlea through an opening called helicotrema. Aqueduct of cochlea connects scala tympani with subarachnoid space.
subject: ENT

question_text: Where is the endolymphatic sac is present?
options: Subdural space in petrous part of temporal bone
explanation: The terminal part of the endolymphatic duct is dilated to form an endolymphatic sac, which lies between the two layers of dura on the posterior surface of the petrous bone. Endolymphatic sac is surgically important. It is exposed for drainage or shunt operation in Meniere’s disease.
subject: ENT

question_text:
Blood supply to the labyrinth is from which of the following arteries?
Anterior inferior cerebellar artery
explanation: Blood supply to the inner ear is by a branch of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery. The inner ear is supplied by labyrinthine artery, a branch of the anterior inferior cerebellar artery, which is a branch of the basilar artery. Disorders of External Ear
subject: ENT

question_text: In a 7-year-old child with hearing loss and intellectual disability, you notice the following external ear anomaly. What could the anomaly in this case be?
explanation: The external ear anomaly seen here is pre-auricular tag/appendage. Pre-auricular tags/appendages are congenital external ear anomalies. They are seen as skin-covered pieces of cartilage anywhere between the tragus and the angle of the mouth. The clinical features of facial asymmetry, intellectual disability, limbal dermoid, and pre-auricular tags and mixed or conductive hearing loss point to a diagnosis of Goldenhar syndrome (oculoauriculovertebral spectrum). Clinical features include: Hypoplasia of the malar, maxillary, and mandibular regions Macrostomia and microtia Preauricular and facial skin tags Hemivertebrae (usually cervical) Intellectual disability Cardiac, renal, and central nervous system (CNS) anomalies Ocular features- Limbal dermoids, upper lid notching or coloboma, microphthalmos, disc coloboma
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient presents to the OPD with the following finding and history of pus discharge from the same area. What is the likely etiology of this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of preauricular sinus seen between the tragus and crus of the helix. It is the most common congenital anomaly of the 1st branchial arch, due to the incomplete fusion of the hillocks of His that develop to form the pinna. It can get repeatedly infected and form an abscess, which would then require excision.
subject: ENT

question_text: An 8-month-old child was brought to your OPD with the following finding. What is your diagnosis?
explanation: The given image showing malformed small pinna appearing like tubercles are suggestive of microtia. It is frequently accompanied by hearing loss.
subject: ENT

question_text: A child with protruding ears is brought to the OPD by his worried parents. They opt for surgical correction of the defect due to cosmetic reasons. After what age would you proceed with the surgery?
explanation: Protruding ears or bat ears can be corrected anytime after 6 years of age if cosmetic appearance demands. This is due to the fact that the pinna is completely developed and achieves adult configuration by the age of 6 years. Protruding ears are caused by a large concha with poorly developed antihelix and scapha.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 5-year-old girl was brought to you with complaints of serous discharge from a cutaneous opening on the right side of her neck. A fistulogram confirms your diagnosis of collaural fistula. Which of the following is a feature of this condition?
options: Opens in front of the tragus
Traverses close to the facial nerve
explanation: Collaural fistula traverses close to the facial nerve within the substance of the parotid. It is a congenital anomaly of 1st branchial cleft. The fistula is between the external auditory canal and neck, where the upper opening is on the floor of the external auditory canal and the lower opening is on the neck between mandible and sternocleidomastoid.
subject: ENT

question_text: A professional wrestler presents to your OPD with the deformity shown below. What is the most likely cause of the same?
explanation: The image shows a cauliflower ear deformity, which is likely due to auricular hematoma. Auricular hematoma is a collection of blood between the auricular cartilage and its perichondrium. If left untreated, the extravasated blood may clot and then organize, resulting in a typical deformity called cauliflower ear. It is also called pugilistic or boxer’s ear. It is often seen in boxers, wrestlers, and rugby players due to blunt trauma. Treatment comprises of aspiration of the hematoma under strict aseptic precautions and a pressure dressing, to prevent reaccumulation. Aspiration may need to be repeated. If aspiration fails, incision and drainage should be done. All cases should receive prophylactic antibiotics.
subject: ENT

question_text: A young man is rushed to the ER following a road traffic accident with severe injuries and a completely avulsed pinna. How would you preserve the avulsed pinna until the patient is stable enough for reconstructive surgery?
options: By storing it in a refrigerator in isotonic saline
By suturing it to buccal mucosa after careful cleaning
By peeling its skin and inserting cartilage into postauricular area
By implanting it into the abdominal cavity
explanation: The avulsed pinna is preserved by peeling its skin and inserting the cartilage into the postauricular area which can be preserved for delayed reconstruction. However, immediate reimplantation using microvascular techniques would be ideal. If the pinna is still attached to the head by a small pedicle of skin, primary reattachment should be considered.
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the most likely diagnosis in a patient who presents with a painful ear swelling as shown below?
explanation: The given clinical scenario of painful, erythematous ear swelling is suggestive of perichondritis. The most common cause is trauma either iatrogenic (surgical incision) or non-iatrogenic (laceration, hematoma). It can be due to the extension of infection from diffuse otitis externa or furuncle of the meatus. The most common organism responsible is Pseudomonas aeruginosa. The image given below shows a patient with a cauliflower ear deformity. It is also known as perichondrial hematoma or wrestler's ear. It is usually caused by repeated episodes of trauma. Chondrodermatitis chronica helicis is a small, nodular, tender, chronic inflammatory lesion occurring on the helix of the ear. It is shown in the image below. Otitis externa, also called swimmer's ear, is the inflammation of the ear canal. It has the following appearance:
subject: ENT

question_text: A middle-aged man presents with a lesion as shown below. He is unable to sleep on the affected side. There is no history of trauma. What is the most probable diagnosis?
explanation: A small tender nodule in the helix in a middle-aged patient is suggestive of chondrodermatitis nodularis chronica helicis. The patient will have difficulty sleeping on the affected side. Treatment includes excision of the lesion.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient is planned for excision of the following lesion. Which of the following measures will not prevent its recurrence post-excision?
explanation: The given image shows a keloid of the pinna and neoadjuvant chemotherapy does not reduce its recurrence post excision. Keloid commonly occurs following trauma. The common sites are lobule and helix. There is a high chance of recurrence after excision, which can be prevented by: Intralesional steroids Pre and post-operative radiotherapy
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is true about furunculosis of ear?
options: Patients with repeated attacks should be investigated for diabetes mellitus
Most common cause is streptococcal infection of hair follicle
Can occur anywhere in the external auditory cana
Tragal sign is negative in majority of cases
explanation: Patients with repeated attacks of furunculosis should be investigated for diabetes mellitus. A furuncle is a staphylococcal infection of the hair follicle. As the hairs are confined only to the cartilaginous part of the meatus, furuncle is seen only outer one-third of EAC. Symptoms are severe compared to signs as the skin over the EAC is tightly adherent. The tragal sign is positive and there is an obliteration of the retro auricular groove. Treated by incision and drainage or 10% ichthammol glycerine wicks and antibiotics.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is synonymous with swimmer’s ear?
explanation: Swimmer’s ear is synonymous with diffuse otitis externa. The normal pH of the external auditory canal is acidic. Any condition that makes the pH alkaline predisposes to otitis externa. This includes situations such as: Hot & humid climate (excessive sweating) and Prolonged swimming
subject: ENT

question_text: A 40-year-old male presents with right-sided ear discharge, itching and pain for the past 4 days. He gives a history of insect entry into the external auditory canal which he removed himself. On examination, there is purulent discharge in a narrow canal and the tympanic membrane is normal. Which of the following is the most effective single treatment for this condition?
explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of diffuse otitis externa following a trauma. Aural toilet remains the most effective single treatment for this condition. All exudate and debris should be carefully removed, with special emphasis on the anteroinferior meatal recess, which forms a blind pocket and acts as a reservoir of infective secretion. The aural toilet can be done by dry mopping, suction clearance, or irrigating the canal with warm, sterile normal saline. Further treatment modalities: After the aural toilet is done, wicks medicated with antibiotic-steroid preparation can be used. These wicks have to be changed daily for 2 to 3 days, which thereafter can be substituted by ear drops. Broad-spectrum systemic antibiotics are used when there is cellulitis and acute tender ymphadenitis. Analgesics are usually a part of management, as otitis externa is associated with severe pain. Gauze wick soaked in 10% ichthammol glycerine is used to reduce swelling. Astringents such as aluminum acetate (8%) or silver nitrate (3%) are used to dry up an oozing meatus.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is the most common cause of otomycosis?
explanation: Otomycosis is a fungal infection of the ear canal that often occurs due to Aspergillus niger (most common), Aspergillus fumigatus, or Candida albicans.
subject: ENT

question_text: A young man presented with irritation and itching in the ear, associated with watery discharge and a musty odor. Otoscopic imaging is shown below. What is the causative organism?
explanation: The given clinical scenario along with the otoscopic image showing black-headed filamentous growth is suggestive of otomycosis by Aspergillus niger. Irritation and itching are the most predominant symptoms of Aspergillus niger infection. Pain is predominant in Aspergillus flavus infection. The fungal mass in otomycosis is likened to a wet blotting paper/wet newspaper appearance. The appearances of otomycosis on otoscopy and the causative organisms are: Black-headed filamentous growth - Aspergillus niger infection Green or brown - Aspergillus fumigatus infection White and creamy deposit - Candida infection Rhizopus oryzae is one of the causative agents of mucormycosis. The common clinical form of this opportunistic infection is rhino-orbital-cerebral mucormycosis (ROCM). It is rarely implicated in otomycosis.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the OPD with right-sided facial weakness. On examination, she has vesicles in the external auditory canal and over the tympanic membrane. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario of facial paralysis along with vesicular eruptions in the external auditory canal and tympanic membrane is suggestive of Ramsay Hunt syndrome (herpes zoster oticus). Ramsay Hunt Syndrome is caused by the reactivation of Herpes zoster in the geniculate ganglion. In most patients, there is an involvement of the trunk of the facial nerve, which results in severe facial palsy. Often, the 8th cranial nerve is also involved, which causes hearing loss and vertigo. There may also be anesthesia of the face due to the involvement of the 5th cranial nerve. Bell's palsy is an idiopathic, peripheral facial paralysis or paresis of acute onset due to a lower motor neuron lesion of the facial nerve. Moebius syndrome is a congenital unilateral/bilateral lower motor neuron facial nerve paralysis with abducens palsy causing limited ocular abduction. Melkersson syndrome is an idiopathic disorder consisting of a triad of: Facial paralysis Swelling of lips Fissured tongue.
subject: ENT

question_text:
A 60-year-old diabetic presents to the ER with fever, excruciating left ear pain, and otorrhoea which is unresponsive to antibiotics. On examination, she has a deviation of the angle of mouth to the right side, and granulation tissue is seen in the left external auditory canal.
What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The clinical scenario of an elderly diabetic with severe otalgia, otorrhoea, granulation tissue in the external auditory canal, and lower motor neuron facial nerve palsy indicates malignant otitis externa. It is termed malignant, even though it is an infection, due to the high mortality rate and poor response to treatment.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following statements is false about malignant otitis externa?
options: It is due to pseudomonas infection
Technetium 99 bone scan is used for follow up
Facial nerve is the most common affected nerve
explanation: Technetium 99 bone scan remains positive for a year or so and cannot be used to follow up response to treatment. It is particularly useful when the clinical suspicion for malignant otitis externa is high but the CT scan is negative. Features of malignant otitis externa: Pseudomonas infection in the elderly diabetics and those on immunosuppressive drugs. Excruciating pain, profuse discharge & granulations on the floor of the external auditory canal. Necrosis of bone aids in the spread of infection. Infection may spread to the skull base and jugular foramen causing multiple cranial nerve palsies. Facial paralysis is the most common nerve palsy seen. Mitotic figures will be normal since it is an infective and not a malignant condition. Gallium-67 is more useful in the follow-up of the patient.
subject: ENT

question_text: A young man presents to the OPD with complaints of intense irritation in the ear following the use of ear drops. Examination reveals vesicle formation, oozing, and crusting in the canal. Which of the following is responsible?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of eczematous otitis externa and the drug implicated is neomycin. Eczematous otitis externa is due to hypersensitivity to infective organisms or topical ear drops such as chloromycetin or neomycin, etc. The presence of intense irritation, vesicle formation, oozing, and crusting in the canal is observed. Management involves stopping the implicated ear drops, changing to a different combination and application of steroid cream. Note - Otitis externa hemorrhagica is a condition characterized by the formation of haemorrhagic bullae on the tympanic membrane and deep meatus. This causes severe pain in the ear and blood-stained discharge when the bullae rupture. It is probably viral in origin.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following statements is false about wax?
options: Contains secretions of glands in the external auditory cana
Formed by dried up middle ear discharge
Is extruded out on its own during jaw movements
explanation: Wax or cerumen is not made up of middle ear discharge. Composition of wax: Secretions of ceruminous glands (modified apocrine sweat glands) Secretions of the sebaceous gland (fatty secretion) Desquamated epithelial cells Hair Wax is normally expelled by the movement of the jaw during eating, talking. Functions include antibacterial action and trapping of foreign bodies and dirt. Impacted wax causes a sensation of blockage of the ear, reduced hearing, vertigo, tinnitus. Treatment: Softening with ceruminolytics like 2% paradichlorobenzene, 5% sodium bicarbonate in equa parts of glycerine and water. Syringing or instrumentation or suction clearance.
subject: ENT

question_text: Ceruminous glands are modifications of which of the following?
explanation: Ceruminous glands are modified apocrine sweat glands. Ceruminous and sebaceous glands open into the space of the hair follicle in the external auditory canal.
subject: ENT

question_text: While performing syringing for a patient with impacted wax, along which wall of the meatus would you direct the jet of water?
explanation: During syringing, the pinna is pulled upwards and backward and the water jet is directed along the posterosuperior wall of the meatus. This is preferred because of two anatomical reasons: On maneuvering the pinna to bring the EAC into a straight configuration, the posterior wall is straighter and easily accessible than the anterior wall. The posteroinferior wall of EAC is supplied by the vagus. Direct stimulation of this can lead to sudden cardiac arrest. Complications of syringing: Vertigo– caloric stimulation of lateral semicircular canal if water is too hot or too cold Rupture of the tympanic membrane Reactivation of quiescent otitis media, if there is pre-existing perforation Contraindications for syringing: Presence of ear infection, tympanic membrane perforation Presence of grommet or history of ear surgery
subject: ENT

question_text: After the extraction of the mass in a patient with keratosis obturans, it is sent for histopathological examination. Which of the following is seen here?
explanation: Keratosis obturans is the collection of a pearly white mass of desquamated epithelial cells in the deep meatus. The keratin plug is arranged in a lamellar fashion, not at a random pattern.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is not seen in a patient with keratosis obturans?
options: Narrowing of meatus causing facial nerve palsy
explanation: Keratosis obturans, by pressure effect, causes absorption of bone which causes widening (not narrowing) of the meatus leading to facial nerve palsy. Normally, epithelium from the surface of the tympanic membrane migrates onto the posterior meatal wall. Failure of this migration, or obstruction to migration caused by wax, may lead to keratosis obturans which is the accumulation of a large plug of desquamated keratin in the external auditory meatus. Features of keratosis obturans: Severe otalgia Conductive hearing loss Thickened tympanic membrane Keratin plug/pearly white mass occluding the cana Widened ear canal- may lead to facial nerve paralysis Hyperemia of canal skin, sometimes with ulcerations and granulomas Staphylococcus aureus is the most frequent isolate. Keratosis oburans may be associated with systemic conditions like bronchiectasis and chronic sinusitis.
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the surgery done to widen the cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal called?
explanation: The surgery done to widen the cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal is meatoplasty. Meatoplasty is a surgical procedure that involves the removal of a crescent-shaped portion of conchal cartilage to widen the external auditory meatus. It is performed in combination with all canal wall-down procedures like modified radical and radical mastoidectomies, for easy access to the mastoid cavity for periodic inspection and cleaning. It is also done as an isolated procedure in elderly people with sagging auricles. A sagging auricle causes obstruction to the meatus leading to the retention of wax and difficulty in hearing. Other options: Option B: Tympanoplasty is the surgical reconstruction to correct damage in the middle ear and restore the integrity of the tympanic membrane for improved hearing. It is ossicular reconstruction only or ossicular reconstruction with myringoplasty. Option C: Myringoplasty refers to the reconstruction of the tympanic membrane only. Option D: Otoplasty is the correction of external ear/deformities of the pinna.
subject: ENT

question_text: In which of the following is meatoplasty not performed?
explanation: Meatoplasty is not a part of canal wall-up (CWU) procedures as the meatus appears normal. However, meatoplasty is performed in combination with all canal wall down procedures like modified radical and radical mastoidectomies, for the treatment of middle ear disease such as cholesteatoma. The widened meatus helps to easily visualize and access the mastoid cavity for periodic inspection and cleaning. It is also done in atresia/stenosis to recanalize the ear and in tortuous canals post-tympanoplasty to improve hearing.
subject: ENT

question_text: While performing otoscopy, which of the following would not indicate a normal tympanic membrane?
options: Mobile with a change in middle ear pressures
explanation: The normal tympanic membrane is concave to the EAC with the maximum concavity at the umbo. Features of normal TM: Pearly grey in color Shiny Degree of transparency varies Mobile with change in middle ear pressures
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is false regarding retracted tympanic membrane?
options: Sickling of anterior and posterior malleal folds
explanation: A retracted TM is dull and lustreless, not shiny and pearly white. Features of retracted TM: The cone of light is absent or interrupted. The handle of the malleus appears foreshortened. The lateral process of the malleus becomes more prominent. Anterior and posterior malleal folds become sickle-shaped. The image below shows a retracted TM with the above mentioned findings:
subject: ENT

question_text:
While performing routine otoscopy, a patient is found to have tympanic membrane retraction with the pars tensa draping over the incudostapedial joint. What is the grade of retraction?
Grade I Sade
explanation: Draping of pars tensa over the incudostapedial joint is classified as Sade's grade II retraction. Sade classification of retraction of Pars tensa: Tos classification of retraction of Pars flaccida: Grad e Description Grad e 1 Mild retractionnot touchingt he long process of theincus Grad Description e Grad Description e Grad e 2 Retracted drumtouchingthe ong process of theincus Grad e 3 Touching promontory butmo bileon seigalization -atelectas isof the middle ear Grad e 4 Plastered to promontory andi mmobile -adhesivemiddle ear Grad e Description Grad e 1 Mild attic retractionnot touc hingthe neck of themalleus. Grad e 2 Touchingthe neck of themalle us Grad e 3 Limitedouter attic wall erosio n Grad e 4 Severeouter attic wall erosion Disorders of Middle Ear
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the most common route of infection in acute suppurative otitis media?
explanation: The eustachian tube is the most common route of infection in acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM). The infection travels via the lumen of the tube or along subepithelial peritubal lymphatics. It can also spread from the external ear through a traumatic perforation or via the blood but it is rare.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following conditions does not predispose to eustachian tube obstruction?
explanation: Choanal atresia does not predispose to eustachian tube obstruction. Eustachian tube obstruction is caused by: Extrinsic causes: Adenoid hypertrophy Nasopharyngeal tumors Nasal pack Intrinsic causes: Allergic rhinitis Rhinosinusitis Upper respiratory tract infection Defective functioning of the tube: Cleft palate Down syndrome Submucous cleft palate Eustachian tube obstruction can lead to complications such as: Acute suppurative otitis media Otitis media with effusion Chronic suppurative otitis media Atelectasis and ossicular necrosis
subject: ENT

question_text: A worried mother brings her febrile infant to the ER. He is crying incessantly and clutching his ear. He had the following finding on otoscopy. What is the most likely organism implicated in this condition?
explanation: The clinical scenario along with the image showing congested tympanic membrane with purulent effusion and absent cone of light is suggestive of acute suppurative otitis media. The most likely organism implicated is Streptococcus pneumoniae. Organisms causing ASOM in infants and young children: Streptococcus pneumoniae (most common) Haemophilus influenzae Moraxella catarrhalis Streptococcus pyogenes Staphylococcus aureus Pseudomonas aeruginosa
subject: ENT

question_text: Otologic examination of a febrile child with otalgia is shown below. What is the stage of acute suppurative otitis media seen here?
explanation: The clinical picture and image show the stage of pre-suppuration of acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM). During this stage, due to prolonged tubal occlusion, pyogenic organisms invade the tympanic cavity. An inflammatory exudate appears in the middle ear and there is congestion of pars tensa. A leash of blood vessels appears along with the handle of malleus and at the periphery of the tympanic membrane imparting it a cart-wheel appearance. Later, the whole of the tympanic membrane including pars flaccida becomes uniformly red. Symptoms of this stage include marked earache, a high degree of fever, hearing loss, and tinnitus (seen only in adults). Tuning fork tests show the conductive type of hearing loss.
subject: ENT

question_text: Pain is most severe in which stage of acute suppurative otitis media?
explanation: Pain is most severe in stage of suppuration in acute suppurative otitis media.
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the most common site of perforation of the tympanic membrane in acute suppurative otitis media?
explanation: The most common site of perforation of the tympanic membrane in ASOM is the posterior half of pars tensa where usually, a small perforation is seen. Note: As per Dhingra Diseases of Ear Nose and Throat 7th edition, the perforation most commonly occurs in the anteroinferior quadrant. However, as Scott-Brown's Otorhinolaryngology: Head and Neck Surgery; 7th Edition mentions the most common site as the posterior half of pars tensa, we have picked it as the best option in this question.
subject: ENT

question_text: How will you manage a patient who is diagnosed to have acute suppurative otitis media in the pre-suppuration stage?
explanation: Management of ASOM in the pre-suppuration stage involves the usage of antibiotics and decongestants. Myringotomy is indicated only when there is an impending rupture of tympanic membrane.
subject: ENT

question_text:
A 23-year-old woman presented to the OPD with complaints of excruciating pain in the right ear, deafness and decreased sleep. On examination, she had right-sided LMN facial nerve
paralysis and bulging tympanic membrane on otoscopy. Which of the following best describes the procedure to be done?
options: Removal of disease and reconstruction of hearing
explanation: The above clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM) complicated by right-sided LMN facial nerve palsy. Otoscopic finding of bulging tympanic membrane is an indication to perform myringotomy i.e., surgical opening in the tympanic membrane. Treatment of facial nerve paralysis secondary to otitis media Conservative management is preferred, using antibiotics and corticosteroids. Myringotomy and a ventilation tube should be added when spontaneous perforation of the tympanic membrane has not occurred. Facial nerve decompression is not usually necessary. Tympanoplasty is the removal of disease from the middle ear and reconstruction of hearing with or without myringoplasty.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the OPD with fever and earache. On examination, the tympanic membrane appears congested and bulging with a loss of landmarks. What is the next line of management?
explanation: The scenario points towards a diagnosis of acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM). Antibiotics form the mainstay of treatment in acute suppurative otitis media, and if the tympanic membrane is bulging, myringotomy should be done. Myringotomy is the procedure involving incising the tympanic membrane to evacuate pus. It is indicated when: The tympanic membrane is bulging and there is acute pain. There is an incomplete resolution despite antibiotics and the drum remains full with persistent conductive deafness. There is persistent effusion beyond 12 weeks.
subject: ENT

question_text: You are an ENT resident assisting on a myringotomy in a patient with serous otitis media. In which quadrant would you make the incision?
explanation: In serous otitis media, a radial incision is made in the anteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane. A curvilinear incision is used in acute suppurative otitis media in the posteroinferior quadrant (smiling incision). Note: Although an anteroinferior incision is the first step, we resort to an anterosuperior incision in the case of thick secretions that are difficult to aspirate. The 'beer-can' principle supports the said mechanism.
subject: ENT

question_text: In which of the following conditions would you expect to observe the light-house effect?
explanation: The light-house effect is seen in acute mastoiditis, which is a complication of otitis media. This effect is described as a pulsatile mucopurulent or purulent discharge, coming through a central pin-hole perforation of pars tensa. This suggests a reservoir of infection in the mastoid and middle ear. Note: Otoscopic signs in intratympanic glomus tumors include: Red reflex through an intact tympanic membrane Pulsation sign or Brown sign - when ear canal pressure is raised with Siegel’s speculum, the tumor pulsates vigorously and then blanches
subject: ENT

question_text: A 6-year-old child with measles is brought to the OPD with complaints of profuse otorrhea. Otoscopy is suggestive of acute necrotizing otitis media. What is the most likely causative organism?
explanation: -hemolytic streptococcus is the most common organism causing acute necrotizing otitis media. Acute necrotizing otitis media is a variety of acute suppurative otitis media. This is often seen in children suffering from measles, scarlet fever, or influenza. It leads to the destruction of the entire tympanic membrane, middle ear mucosa, and air cells. There is profuse otorrhoea. In such cases, healing is followed by fibrosis or ingrowth of squamous epithelium from the meatus leading to a secondary acquired cholesteatoma. Treatment is early antibiotic therapy for at least 7- 10 days. Cortical mastoidectomy may be indicated if medical treatment fails to control or the condition gets complicated by acute mastoiditis.
subject: ENT

question_text: What is glue ear also called as?
explanation: Glue ear is also called secretory otitis media. It refers to otitis media with effusion.
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the most common cause of hearing loss in children?
explanation: Otitis media with effusion, or glue ear, is the most common cause of hearing loss in children. Clinical features of glue ear include: Bilateral, painless, and fluctuating hearing loss. Conductive hearing loss not more than 40 dB is bserved. Defective and delayed development of speech. Occasional mild earaches are present.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding serous otitis media?
options: Function of the eustachian tube is abnormal in most cases
Adenoid hypertrophy is the most common cause in children causing bilateral serous otitis media
