Tumors of nasopharynx is the most common cause in adults causing unilateral serous otitis media
The effusion is thick, viscid and unsterile in most cases
explanation: The effusion is thick, viscid and sterile in most cases of serous otitis media. Etiology of serous otitis media: Malfunctioning of eustachian tube: Adenoid hyperplasia in children - causes bilateral serous otitis media Benign and malignant tumors of the nasopharynx - should always be excluded in unilateral serous otitis media in an adult Cleft lip, cleft palate and chronic tonsillitis - interference with ET opening Otitic barotrauma Allergy - increased middle ear secretions Unresolved ASOM - due to inadequate treatment dosage or duration Viral infections - increased secretory activity due to stimulation of middle ear mucosa
subject: ENT

question_text: You see a child with delayed development of speech as part of a health visit in a local school. The otoscopic appearance of the ear is shown below. Hearing loss of 20 dB is detected in audiometric tests. What is your diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and image suggest a diagnosis of serous otitis media. The golden yellow discoloration of the tympanic membrane is caused by the clear watery straw-colored effusion filling the middle ear. Since the fluid is clear, one can see the structures of the middle ear quite clearly on otoscopy. Patients having serous otitis media will have hearing loss that rarely exceeds 40 dB. This deafness can pass unnoticed, and maybe accidentally discovered during audiometric screening tests. Because of hearing loss, the development of speech is delayed or defective. Otoscopic findings in serous otitis media: Fluid level and air bubbles are seen when fluid is thin and the tympanic membrane transparent. In chronic cases, the fluid becomes very sticky. Hence, the name glue ear. The tympanic membrane is often dull and opaque with a loss of light reflex. The mobility of the tympanic membrane is restricted.
subject: ENT

question_text: What type of tympanogram would you expect to see in a patient with serous otitis media?
explanation: B-type tympanogram is expected in a case of serous otitis media. Here, compliance decreases i.e., mobility of tympanic membrane is restricted due to the effusion, usually secondary to negative middle ear pressure (eustachian tube obstruction). This results in a B-type tympanogram. Hearing tests suggestive of conductive hearing loss as seen in serous otitis media: Rinne negative (BC>AC). Weber - lateralized towards the worse ear Audiogram - AC abnormal, BC normal, air-bone gap present Impedance audiometry - flat curve (reduced compliance, shift to the negative side) Note: Tympanograph is Flat when there is Fluid in the middle ear.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following procedures is not used to treat a patient with glue ear?
explanation: Serous otitis media can be managed by cortical mastoidectomy. It is sometimes required for removing loculated thick fluid or other associated pathologies such as cholesterol granuloma. Management of glue ear: Medical: Antihistaminics Decongestants Antibiotics Valsalva maneuver. Surgical: Myringotomy and aspiration Grommet insertion Tympanotomy Cortical mastoidectomy A grommet is placed in the middle ear to aerate and drain the middle ear. It acts as a substitute for the blocked eustachian tube. It is placed through radial myringotomy in the anteroinferior quadrant. The device is shown in the image below:
subject: ENT

question_text: A child with hearing difficulty is diagnosed to have glue ear. Which of the following is not a possible sequela of this condition?
explanation: Otosclerosis is not a possible sequela of glue ear. Otosclerosis is a hereditary disease of the bone of the inner ear, which mostly affects the stapes footplate area. It is not related to other ear pathologies. The sequelae of long-standing glue ear include: Atrophy of tympanic membrane (TM) and myringosclerosis (fibrosis of TM) Atelectasis of middle ear - when the tympanic membrane gets retracted over the promontory Ossicular necrosis Tympanosclerosis - collagen deposits within the middle ear Retraction pockets in TM and cholesteatoma Cholesterol granulomas - due to stasis of secretions in the mastoid and middle ear
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is not a feature of tubercular otitis media?
explanation: Earache is not a feature of tubercular otitis media. It is a painless condition. Tuberculosis of the ear is usually secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis. It occasionally spreads hematogenously, from a tubercular focus in the lungs, tonsils, and cervical or mesenteric lymph nodes It presents as a painless condition with foul-smelling discharge from the ear, that does not respond to standard antibiotic treatment. Patients have severe hearing loss that is out of proportion to symptoms. Although predominantly conductive, sensorineural hearing loss may also occur if the labyrinth is involved. A thickened tympanic membrane with multiple perforations in pars tensa of the tympanic membrane and pale granulations in the middle ear cleft is seen. The image below shows the tympanic membrane in tuberculous otitis media: Histopathology shows submucosal tubercles with Langhans giant cells and caseous necrosis. Smears and culture of ear discharge may be positive for acid-fast bacilli (AFB). Evidence of primary pulmonary tuberculosis may also be seen on chest radiography. Facial nerve palsy is a common complication. Mastoiditis, postauricular fistula, and osteomyelitis are also seen. Treatment includes aural toilet, treatment of secondary bacterial infections, and a full course of antitubercular therapy followed by reconstructive surgery.
subject: ENT

question_text:
A 42-year-old farmer presented to your clinic after developing painless otorrhoea and hearing loss in his right ear. Examination revealed multiple perforations in the pars tensa in addition to a purulent, foul-smelling discharge with right facial nerve palsy. Audiometry indicated a 35 dB conductive hearing loss. Which of the following does not constitute an essential part of the treatment?
Corticosteroids
explanation: The clinical stem consisting of painless otorrhoea, conductive hearing loss with multiple perforations in the pars tensa, and right facial nerve palsy point to a diagnosis of tuberculous otitis media, for which corticosteroids do not form an essential part of the treatment. Tuberculosis of the ear usually occurs secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis. It is occasionally blood-borne, spreading from a tubercular focus in the lungs, tonsils, cervical or mesenteric lymph nodes. Tuberculous otitis media is mostly seen in children and young adults. It presents as a painless condition with foul-smelling discharge from the ear, that does not respond to standard antibiotic treatment. A thickened tympanic membrane with multiple perforations in pars tensa of the tympanic membrane and pale granulations in the middle ear cleft is seen. Facial nerve palsy is the most common complication. Mastoiditis, postauricular fistula, osteomyelitis are also seen. Histopathology shows submucosal tubercles with Langhans giant cells and caseation necrosis. Smears and culture of ear discharge may be positive for AFB. Chest X-ray features of tuberculosis along with other evidence of tuberculosis in the body help in confirmation of the diagnosis. DNA probe and PCR from the ear discharge can provide an early diagnosis. Treatment includes: Antitubercular therapy Aural toilet Treatment of secondary infection Mastoid surgery for complications. Reconstructive middle ear surgery is delayed till antitubercular therapy has been completed. Cholesteatoma and Types of CSOM
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following epithelia does not line the middle ear?
explanation: The middle ear is not lined by keratinizing squamous epithelium, and hence its presence anywhere within the middle ear cleft is considered cholesteatoma. Various kinds of epithelia lining the middle ear are: Ciliated columnar- around the eustachian tube opening (Protympanum) Pavement like- attic/epitympanum Cuboidal- rest
subject: ENT

question_text: Otoscopic image of a patient with a history of repeated middle ear infections is shown below. Which one of the following statements is true regarding this condition?
options: It is also known as epidermosis
explanation: The image shows the presence of a large mass of white keratin debris in the left upper quadrant of the left tympanic membrane. This along with clinical scenario is suggestive of cholesteatoma which is also known as epidermosis or keratoma Cholesteatoma is the presence of stratified squamous epithelium in middle ear where it is not usually present, i.e., skin in wrong place. A central white mass, consisting of keratin debris is produced by the matrix. For this reason, it has also been named epidermosis or keratoma. The term cholesteatoma is a misnomer because it neither contains cholesterol crystals nor it is a tumor to merit the suffix “oma.”
subject: ENT

question_text: You see a patient with a history of painless foul-smelling ear discharge and loss of hearing for the past year. He had undergone tympanoplasty on the same ear 3 years back. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of secondary acquired cholesteatoma. The history of middle ear infection and hearing loss after surgery of the tympanic membrane makes the diagnosis more likely. Classification of cholesteatoma: Congenital cholesteatoma is that which has its nidus of trapped squamous epithelium present at birth. Primary acquired cholesteatoma presents with no history of previous otitis media or a pre-existing perforation. It is associated with a defect in pars flaccida. Secondary acquired cholesteatoma presents with a history of previous otitis media or a pre-existing perforation. It is associated with a defect in pars tensa.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following theories does not explain the origin of cholesteatoma?
options: Ruedi’s theory of basal cell hyperplasia
von Bekesy theory of mucosal metaplasia
explanation: von Békésy proposed the traveling wave theory, whereas Sade’s metaplasia theory explains the origin of cholesteatoma. Cholesteatoma can be of 2 main types: Congenital cholesteatoma - explained by the presence of congenital cell rests within the middle ear and other parts of the temporal bone. Acquired cholesteatoma - explained by a pathology either within the mastoid air cell system and eustachian tube drainage, or the tympanic membrane epithelium.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is the most accepted theory for secondary cholesteatoma?
explanation: The most accepted theory for secondary cholesteatoma is Habermann's theory. It proposes that the skin of the external auditory meatus grows or migrates into the middle ear through the posterosuperior marginal perforation or attic perforation forming cholesteatoma.
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the most common site for primary cholesteatoma?
explanation: Prussak’s space is the most common site of primary cholesteatoma. It is the space in the epitympanum lying in between pars flaccida and the neck of the malleus.
subject: ENT

question_text:
An 8-year-old boy was referred to an otolaryngologist for subjective left-sided hearing loss. A hearing test revealed mild conductive hearing loss at low and middle frequencies.
Otoendoscopy showed a mass with the appearance as shown below. Which of the following criteria is used to diagnose this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario with the otoendoscopy showing a white pearly mass behind the intact eardrum in the anterosuperior quadrant is suggestive of congenital cholesteatoma. Levenson criteria should be satisfied in order to diagnose this condition. Levenson criteria: A white mass behind the normal tympanic membrane Normal pars tensa and pars flaccida No prior history of otorrhoea No prior history of otological procedure Episodes of otitis media with effusion should not be considered as exclusion criteria. Another popular guideline used is Derlaki and Clemis which includes all the above except for the 4th criteria.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the expansion of cholesteatoma and destruction of bone?
options: Release of enzymes like collagenase and acid phosphatase at the site of destruction
Destruction of bone mediated by pressure necrosis
Osteoclasts and mononuclear infiltrates play a role in bone destruction
Erosion of ossicles is more common in children compared to adults
explanation: Cholesteatoma does not cause bone destruction by pressure necrosis. Bone destruction by cholesteatoma has been attributed to enzymes liberated by osteoclasts and mononuclear inflammatory cells such as: Collagenase Acid phosphatase and Proteolytic enzymes. Pediatric cholesteatoma (PC) has more inflammation and greater chances of ossicular erosion compared to adults. However, PC has lesser chances of petrous labyrinth invasion and lateral semicircular canal fistula formation.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient presented to your OPD for a second look surgery following a canal wall-up procedure for cholesteatoma removal. Where is the residual disease most likely to be seen?
explanation: Residual cholesteatoma is most likely to be seen in the sinus tympani. The involvement of sinus tympani, along with posterior mesotympanum, is a recognized risk factor for residual cholesteatoma. This is because it is particularly difficult to remove the disease from these areas. Canal wall-up procedures have a higher risk of leaving residual disease behind than the canal wall-down procedures. Sinus tympani or infra pyramidal recess is the medial of the two posterior spaces in the middle ear. It is bounded by: Pyramid and vertical segment of facial nerve laterally The stapes & oval window medially Ponticulus superiorly Subiculum inferiorly Image showing sinus tympani:
subject: ENT

question_text: Patients with tubotympanic type of chronic suppurative otitis media are considered safe compared to atticoantral disease. What is the reason?
options: Does not progress into malignancy usually
Does not involve the mastoid air cells
explanation: Tubotympanic type (TTD) of CSOM is considered the safe type in relativity to atticoantral disease (AAD) as TTD has less chance of complications than AAD. Note: TTD can also lead to complications but the incidence is much less than that in AAD.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following best describes the given otoscopy finding in a child with poor scholastic performance?
explanation: The given otoscopic image shows a subtotal perforation. It involves all four quadrants of the tympanic membrane but is covered by remnant pars tensa/annulus all around. Chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) is the single most important cause of hearing impairment in rural populations. Children with CSOM have poor academic performance.
subject: ENT

question_text: A young adult presents with intermittent non-foul smelling mucoid discharge from the left ear for the past few years. Otologic examination revealed a central perforation of the tympanic membrane. Which of the following statements is false regarding his condition?
options: No evidence of bone destruction in CT scans
Mixed aerobic and anaerobic infections are seen
Aural polyp if present, should never be avulsed
explanation: The clinical scenario of intermittent mucoid discharge and central perforation of the tympanic membrane points to a diagnosis of tubotympanic type of CSOM, which is not associated with cholesteatoma. Atticoantral type is associated with cholesteatoma and it leads to dangerous complications due to its bone-eroding properties. Etiology of tubotympanic (benign or safe) type of CSOM: As a sequela of acute otitis media Ascending infection via the eustachian tube Allergic conditions Bone destruction is not present in this type. Culture reveals mixed aerobic and anaerobic infection. Aural polyp if present should be removed and not avulsed before starting local treatment. This is due to the fact that the polyp may be arising from the stapes, facial nerve, or horizontal canal and its avulsion can lead to facial paralysis or labyrinthitis.
subject: ENT

question_text: A known case of tubotympanic disease was taken up for surgery and on examining the middle ear, few chalky white deposits were found between the ossicles. What is the diagnosis?
options: Candidal infection of the middle ear
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of tympanosclerosis. It is a sequela of long-standing middle ear disease where there are hyaline deposits within the middle ear, which calcify leading to impaired mobility of ossicles. The common sites are the tympanic membrane, promontory, ossicles, joints, tendons, and oval and round windows. When hyalinization and calcification involve only the tympanic membrane, it is known as myringosclerosis.
subject: ENT

question_text: A first-year ENT postgraduate sees a child with permanent perforation of the tympanic membrane. Which of the following is a feature of such perforation?
options: It is seen in acute suppurative otitis media
It is caused by necrotizing otitis externa
It has squamous epithelium at its edges
Medical management can be tried initially
explanation: A permanent perforation is lined by squamous epithelium at its edges, hindering spontaneous healing. Features of a permanent perforation: Seen in chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) Is similar to an epithelial lined fistulous tract Cannot be medically managed, thus mandating surgery
subject: ENT

question_text:
A young adult presents with a 3-year history of intermittent ear discharge. He complains of poor hearing, which improves during discharge periods, but is worse when the ear is dry.
Which of the following explains this phenomenon?
explanation: The given scenario describes the round window-shielding effect that is seen in tubotympanic type of CSOM. The round window-shielding effect is where the ear discharge shields the round window from sound waves. During the inactive phase (no discharge), the sound strikes both the oval window and round window together and the noise cancels itself out. So, the hearing is worse when the ear is dry. Cholesteatoma hearer is a patient with a discontinuous ossicular chain but the sound is conducted through the cholesteatoma to the footplate. On removing the cholesteatoma by surgery, the patient has worse hearing.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient with chronic suppurative otitis media is posted for surgery. Preoperatively, the surgeon wants to assess the status of the ossicles so that he can be prepared for ossicular construction if required. Which of the following tests is useful here?
explanation: The patch test is useful in assessing the status of the ossicles preoperatively so that the surgeon can be prepared for ossicular reconstruction if required. It is done in tubotympanic type of CSOM. A thin paper-like cigarette foil is soaked in vaseline and cut into the size of perforation and is used to close the perforation. Pure tone audiometry is done before and after the closure of perforation. Results are as follows: Improved hearing – intact ossicular chain Decreased hearing – ossicular fixity or discontinuity No improvement – technical fault or improper hearing. Another test done in the tubotympanic type of CSOM is Bonsin's test. When the eardrum is painted with 1 in 20% solution of silver nitrate, the perforation stands out as a black spot against a white background. Option A: Nine-step test is used to predict the ears at risk of middle ear barotrauma. Options B and D: The side-step test and Unterberger test are vestibular tests and are positive in perilymphatic fistula.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is true regarding the tubotympanic type of chronic suppurative otitis media?
options: Central perforation in antero-inferior quadrant is commonly seen
Blood stained ear discharge is seen
The discharge is scanty, purulent and foul smelling
explanation: Central perforation in the antero-inferior quadrant of tympanic membrane is commonly seen in tubotympanic type, while marginal perforation in the postero-superior quadrant is commonly seen in atticoantral type of CSOM. Bloody, scant, foul-smelling ear discharge, ear pain, hearing loss, and tinnitus are often seen in the atticoantral type of CSOM.
subject: ENT

question_text:
Which of the following is true about the atticoantral type of chronic suppurative otitis media?
Most commonly involves the protympanum
options: Involvement of Shrapnell's membrane is seen
explanation: Atticoantral type also called unsafe or dangerous type involves perforation of Shrapnell's membrane or pars flaccida (attic perforation). The disease is often associated with a bone-eroding process such as cholesteatoma, granulations, or osteitis. The risk of complications is high in this variety. CSOM - Treatment and Complications
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is the most common surgery done for tubotympanic type of chronic suppurative otitis media?
explanation: Tympanoplasty is the most common surgery done in the tubotympanic type of CSOM. It involves ossiculoplasty (the eradication of the disease from the middle ear and repair of ossicles) with or without myringoplasty (repair of perforation of the tympanic membrane, which is done to check repeated infections from external ear).
subject: ENT

question_text: As a first-year ENT resident, you are preparing a patient for tympanoplasty. Which of the following would not be in your pre-operative checklist?
explanation: CT scan of the temporal bone is not required in tympanoplasty procedures. It is required only in cases of mastoidectomy. For tympanoplasty, routine blood investigations, pure tone audiometry, and an X-ray of the mastoid are sufficient.
subject: ENT

question_text: Wullstein’s classification is used for which of the following procedures?
explanation: Zollner and Wullstein’s classification is used to classify tympanoplasty.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 30-year-old man presents with complaints of painless, odourless and profuse discharge from the right ear. An otoscopic image of the affected ear is given below. Which of the following would not be a part of the management?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and image showing a medium central perforation of the pars tensa is suggestive of tubo-tympanic type (TTD) of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM). Canal wall down mastoidectomy is not a part of the management plan. This is only performed in attico-antral type and in cases of tubo-tympanic type where a reservoir of infection in the middle ear is suspected. Management of tubo-tympanic type of CSOM: Medical management: Aural toilet Topical antibiotics with steroid drops Systemic antibiotics Treatment of causative factors. Surgical management: It is done once the ear is dry for 6 weeks without antibiotics. Tympanoplasty (ossiculoplasty with or without myringoplasty).
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is the most common graft material used for tympanoplasty?
explanation: Temporalis fascia is the most common graft material used for tympanoplasty Other graft materials used are: The areolar fascia overlying the temporal fascia Perichondrium from the tragus Conchal cartilage Vein Periosteum Dura mater was used earlier but then discontinued due to the risk of prion diseases like Cruetzfeldt Jacob disease.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient having chronic otitis media with perforation of pars tensa is scheduled for myringoplasty to restore hearing. Which of the following is true regarding the techniques used here?
options: In underlay technique, graft is placed medial to annulus
In underlay technique, graft is placed lateral to malleus
In overlay technique, graft is placed medial to annulus
In overlay technique, graft is placed lateral to malleus
explanation: In the underlay technique, the graft is placed medial to the annulus. Whereas, in the overlay technique, the graft is placed lateral to the annulus. The graft is medial to malleus in both techniques. Myringoplasty techniques are based on the relation of the graft with lamina propria of tympanic membrane remnants and fibrous annulus.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient with mucosal disease of the middle ear is set to undergo myringoplasty. Which of the following incisions is used here?
explanation: Wilde’s (or post-aural) incision is used in myringoplasty. Wilde's incision is used in the following: Cortical mastoidectomy Modified radical and radical mastoidectomy Tympanoplasty - when perforation extends anterior to handle of malleus Exposure of CN VII in the vertical segment Surgery of endolymphatic sac. Option A: Killian’s incision is used in submucous resection surgery for deviated nasal septum. In cases of a deviated septum, a slightly curvilinear incision is made, 2–3 mm behind the caudal end of septal cartilage at the mucocutaneous junction, always on the left side. Option B: Freer’s hemitransfixion incision is used in septoplasty done for deviated nasal septum. In case of caudal dislocation, a transfixion or hemitransfixion incision is made. It is a septocolumellar incision between the caudal end of septal cartilage and columella on the concave side. Option D: Gluck–Sorenson’s incision used for laryngectomy with radical neck dissection.
subject: ENT

question_text: Austin’s classification for anatomical defects in the ossicular chain is based on which of the following structures?
explanation: Austin's classification of anatomical defects in the ossicular chain is based on the presence or absence of handle of malleus and stapes suprastructure. Incus is the most common bone to be eroded and assuming it to be absent in most cases, the remaining 2 ossicles, i.e., malleus and stapes are considered for the classification.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient presents to your OPD with hearing difficulty and scanty, foul-smelling discharge from the left ear. Otologic examination reveals the following finding. What is the treatment of choice in this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario describes a case of atticoantral type of CSOM and modified radical mastoidectomy is the treatment of choice here. Option A: Myringotomy is done in cases of acute suppurative otitis media (ASOM) and serous otitis media. Options C and D: Medical management followed by myringoplasty or tympanoplasty once the ear is dry for 6 weeks without antibiotics is the treatment of choice for tubotympanic type of CSOM.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 7-year-old child presents with scanty, foul-smelling ear discharge. Otologic examination shows the following finding. Which of the following is an appropriate management plan?
explanation: The given clinical scenario along with the image showing marginal perforation is suggestive of atticoantral type of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM), and the appropriate management plan is surgical intervention with tympanomastoid exploration.
subject: ENT

question_text: What would be the primary aim of surgery in a patient presenting with the following otoscopic finding?
explanation: The given image shows a white mass located in the anterosuperior quadrant behind the intact eardrum suggestive of cholesteatoma. The primary aim is to clear the disease and render the ear safe. The second priority is to preserve or reconstruct the hearing, but never at the cost of the primary aim.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 12-year-old child with chronic suppurative otitis media and cholesteatoma is planned for a mastoidectomy. He is part of the school swimming club and wants to pursue the sport. Which of the following would you mention while counselling the parents regarding canal wall up (CWU) and canal wall down (CWD) mastoidectomies?
options: Incidence of residual disease is very low not requiring second look surgery in CWU procedure
Easy to wear a hearing aid if need in CWD procedure
Post surgery healing is rapid and periodic cleaning is unnecessary in CWU procedure
The patient is allowed to swim after CWD procedure
explanation: Post-surgery healing is rapid and periodic cleaning is unnecessary in case of canal wall up procedure (CWU). This procedure has a low predisposition to infection but carries the risk of leaving behind residual disease requiring the need for second-look surgery. Canal wall up procedure (CW U) Canal wall down procedure ( CWD) Meatus appears normal Meatus opening is wide com munication with mastoid Does not require routine clea ning Cleaning once or twice a year required. High rate of recurrent or resi dual cholesteatoma Low rate of recurrence Requires second-look surgery after 6 months Not required The patient is allowed to swi m. No limitation. Swimming can lead to infecti on of the mastoid cavity Easy to wear a hearing aid if needed Problems in fitting a hearing aid due to large meatus and mastoid cavity
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is not seen in a case of otitis media?
explanation: Battle sign refers to retro auricular or mastoid ecchymosis that typically results from a fracture of the middle cranial fossa following head trauma. It is prominent when there is a fracture of the temporal bone. Battle sign is not seen in the case of otitis media. Option A: Bezold abscess is a complication of acute otomastoiditis where the infection/pus breaks through the thin medial side of the tip of the mastoid and presents as a swelling in the upper part of the neck. Option B: Griesinger sign refers to edema of the postauricular soft tissues overlying the mastoid process as a result of thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein seen in sigmoid sinus thrombosis. It is a complication of acute otomastoiditis. Option D: Delta sign is a contrast-enhanced CT finding seen in sagittal sinus thrombosis, which can occur as a complication of acute mastoiditis or chronic suppurative otitis media. It is a triangular area with rim enhancement and the central low-density area is seen in the posterior cranial fossa on axial cuts. MR venography is useful to assess the progression or resolution of a thrombus. The image below depicts a filling defect (thrombus) outlined by contrast medium in the sagittal sinus.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient complains of severe pain in his right ear associated with high-grade fever and profuse ear discharge. Clinical examination reveals mastoid tenderness and perforation of the tympanic membrane. If this infection were to burst out through the medial aspect of the tip of the mastoid, which of the following conditions would ensue?
explanation: The clinical scenario of severe pain in his right ear associated with high-grade fever, profuse ear discharge, mastoid tenderness, and perforation of the tympanic membrane is suggestive of acute mastoiditis, which has most likely occurred as a complication of acute infection of the middle ear. If this infection is to burst out through the medial side of the tip of the mastoid, it results in the formation of Bezold abscess. Acute mastoiditis is used to refer to an acute infection that spreads from the mucosa, lining the mastoid air cells, to involve the bony walls of the mastoid air cell system. The image below shows a picture of acute mastoiditis: Blood leukocytes and ESR is raised. CT scan of the temporal bone shows clouding of air cells due to the collection of exudate in them. In later stages, a cavity may be seen in the mastoid. Treatment is done by administration of intravenous antibiotics and if indicated, surgical procedures such as myringotomy and cortical mastoidectomy. Abscesses in Relation to mastoid infection are: Bezold abscess lies deep to the sternocleidomastoid and presents as a swelling in the tip of the mastoid or the angle of the jaw and is seen in the upper part of the posterior triangle or the parapharyngeal space The images below show a picture of Bezold abscess: Other abscesses in relation to mastoid infection: Post auricular abscess - it is the most common abscess that forms over the mastoid. In infants and children, this presents over the MacEwen’s triangle. Zygomatic abscess - infection of the zygomatic air cells. It is situated at the posterior root of the zygoma Luc abscess (meatal abscess) - the pus breaks through the bony wall between the mastoid antrum and external auditory meatus Citelli’s abscess - the abscess is formed posterior to the mastoid, occupying a position more towards the occipital bone
subject: ENT

question_text: A 30-year-old woman presented with a history of ear discharge in the left ear for the past 4 weeks, deep-seated ear pain for the past 1 week, and diplopia for the past 2 days. What is the most probable diagnosis in this scenario?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Gradenigo’s syndrome, which occurs secondary to petrous apicitis. This is a complication of otitis media. The triad of Gradenigo's syndrome consists of: Ipsilateral abducens nerve palsy (6th nerve palsy) - external rectus palsy Deep ear/facial pain (5th nerve involvement) Persistent ear discharge (otitis media) The incidence of this syndrome has reduced with the advent of antibiotics. Option A- Following acute coalescent mastoiditis the pus breaks through the bony wall between the mastoid antrum and the external meatus and forms Luc's abscess. The swelling can burst into the meatus causing otorrhea. Options B and C- Nasopharyngeal carcinoma and trigeminal schwannoma can present with cranial nerve palsy, but they do not follow the above clinical course.
subject: ENT

question_text: In which of the following conditions would you expect to see Griesinger’s sign?
explanation: Griesinger’s sign is seen in sigmoid sinus thrombosis. It is described as mastoid tenderness and edema, which is secondary to thrombophlebitis of the mastoid emissary vein. However, Gradenigo's syndrome/triad is a complication of otitis media and is seen when the infection extends to the petrous apex (petrositis). The triad consists of: Ipsilateral abducens nerve palsy (6th nerve palsy) - external rectus palsy Deep ear/facial pain (5th nerve involvement) Persistent ear discharge (otitis media)
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient with a history of foul-smelling ear discharge, for which he did not complete treatment now presents with complaints of fever with chills and swelling over the mastoid. On examination, there is tenderness along the jugular vein. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lateral sinus thrombophlebitis. It is an inflammation of the inner wall of the lateral venous sinus with the formation of an intrasinus thrombus. Clinical features of lateral sinus thrombophlebitis: Hectic picket fence fever with chills and rigors. This is due to septicemia. The clinical picture resembles malaria but lacks regularity. Headache - In the early stage, it may be due to peri-sinus abscess and is mild. Later, it may be severe when intracranial pressure rises due to venous obstruction. Griesinger’s sign - this is due to thrombosis of the mastoid emissary vein. Edema appears over the posterior part of the mastoid. Papilloedema - its presence depends on obstruction to venous return. It is often seen with the right sinus (which is larger than the left). Tenderness along the jugular vein - This is seen when thrombophlebitis extends along the jugular vein. There may be associated enlargement and inflammation of the jugular chain of ymph nodes and torticollis. Investigations: Blood culture CSF analysis - normal except for increased CSF pressure that helps in ruling out meningitis. X-ray mastoid shows: Clouding of air cells seen in acute mastoiditis. Destruction of bone seen in cholesteatoma. CECT shows a typical delta sign. Treatment: Intravenous antibacterial therapy Mastoidectomy and exposure of sinus Ligation of internal jugular vein Anticoagulant therapy
subject: ENT

question_text:
A patient with hearing loss has the following otoscopic finding. What is the treatment modality of choice?

Medical management
explanation: The image shows a cherry-red small mass of granulation tissue arising from the pars flaccida of the left tympanic membrane strongly suggesting that there is an underlying cholesteatoma in the attic area. Surgery is the treatment of choice in case of cholesteatoma. The continuing discharge from the granulation tissue has caused the surface epithelia of the tympanic membrane to become edematous and thickened. This gives the surface of the tympanic membrane a thickened whitish appearance. The primary aim in surgical treatment is to remove the disease and render the ear safe, and second in priority is to preserve or reconstruct hearing but never at the cost of the primary aim. Mastoidectomy is done. Otosclerosis
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following structures does otosclerosis affect?
explanation: Otosclerosis affects the otic capsule. The otic capsule is the dense bony labyrinth of the inner ear that surrounds the cochlea, the vestibule, and the semicircular canals. In otosclerosis, one or more foci of irregularly laid spongy bone replace part of the normally dense bone. The inner ear is divided into: The membranous labyrinth is also called the otic labyrinth. It is filled with endolymph. The bony labyrinth, which is also called the otic capsule. Periotic labyrinth, which is the space between the bony and membranous labyrinth and is filled with perilymph.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which layer of the otic capsule is affected in otosclerosis?
explanation: Otosclerosis affects the enchondral layer of the otic capsule. Within the enchondral layer, there are sometimes islands of unossified cartilage rests that later give rise to otosclerosis. The otic capsule is made of 3 layers: Endosteal: Innermost Enchondral: Middle layer derived from cartilage that ossifies Periosteal: Outermost layer
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the most common site of origin of otosclerosis?
explanation: The most common site of origin of otosclerosis is the fissula ante fenestram lying in front of the oval window. It is seen in the stapedial type of otosclerosis. Types of otosclerosis : Stapedia Cochlear Histological. Stapedial otosclerosis is the most common type of otosclerosis.
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the type of otosclerotic focus when the disease process involves the entire footplate except for the annular ligament?
explanation: The otosclerotic focus is biscuit type when the disease process involves the entire footplate except for the annular ligament. The otosclerotic foci in the stapedial type of otosclerosis can be of various types: Anterior focus - involving only the fissula ante fenestrum Posterior focus- involving only the fissula post fenestrum Circumferential - affects the margin of the footplate only (annular ligament alone) Biscuit type - affects the entire footplate except for the annular ligament Obliterative- affects the entire footplate & its annular ligament.
subject: ENT

question_text:
You are an OBGYN resident and your patient is one of your staff nurses. She is a primigravida who has just been diagnosed with otosclerosis and wants to know its inheritance pattern.
Which of the following is the inheritance pattern for otosclerosis?
explanation: Otosclerosis has an autosomal dominant type of inheritance. About 50% of the cases of otosclerosis have a positive family history while the rest are sporadic. Genetic studies reveal that it is an autosomal dominant trait with incomplete penetrance and variable expressivity.
subject: ENT

question_text:
For research on pharmacological treatment in otosclerosis, a researcher wanted to set the age limit of the study to the most common age group when the hearing loss usually manifests.
Which of the following will be a suitable set?
explanation: The most common age group when the hearing loss in otosclerosis usually manifests is 20-30 years of age. It is rare before 10 and after 40 years.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding otosclerosis?
options: Females are affected twice as often as males.
Stapedotomy should be avoided in children.
HRCT shows double ring sign in stapedial otosclerosis.
It may be associated with measles.
explanation: HRCT shows the double-ring sign in cochlear otosclerosis, not in the stapedial type. Otosclerosis affects females twice as often as males. But in India, otosclerosis seems to predominate in males. Stapedotomy is contraindicated in children because recurrent eustachian tube dysfunction is common in them. This can displace the prosthesis or cause acute otitis media. Measles RNA has been found in otosclerotic foci implicating its possible role in pathogenesis.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following hearing defects is not seen in otosclerosis?
explanation: Presbyacusis is not seen in otosclerosis. The following hearing defects are seen in otosclerosis: Painless progressive bilateral conductive hearing loss most commonly. Sensorineural hearing loss may be seen in cochlear type of otosclerosis. Paracusis willisii: Patient hears better in noisy surroundings as other people raise their voice to be heard.
subject: ENT

question_text: In a stapedectomy specimen of a patient with otosclerosis, a pathologist noted that a few areas of the otic capsule appeared more basophilic than normal. What is this appearance called?
explanation: The blue mantle sign of Manasseh is a histopathological finding seen in otosclerosis. On histopathological examination of an otosclerotic foci, the osteoblasts and osteoclasts lie in an abundance of cement substance, which stains blue with hematoxylin and eosin stain. Option B - Blue dot sign is seen in the torsion of the testicular appendage. Blue cement sign and islets in ocean sign do not exist.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 30-year-old Caucasian woman came with a history of progressive hearing impairment which improves in a noisy environment. Tuning fork tests revealed a conductive hearing loss in both ears. The otoscopic finding is given in the image below. What is the most probable diagnosis among the given options?
explanation: The given image is of a normal tympanic membrane. There is bilateral conductive deafness, paracusis willisi and, a normal tympanic membrane which suggest a diagnosis of otosclerosis with matured focus. Paracusis willisi - Patient hears better in noisy surroundings as other people raise their voice to be heard. The tympanic membrane has a normal appearance in most cases. This is indicative of a matured or inactive focus of otosclerotic bone. Option B - A case of CSOM will have a perforated tympanic membrane. Option C - Otosclerosis with an active focus will show the Schwartze sign. Option D - In the case of otitis media with effusion the tympanic membrane is often dull and opaque with loss of light reflex.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 20-year-old female patient presents with features of bilateral conductive hearing loss, not associated with tinnitus. The following image shows the otoscopic findings of her tympanic membranes. What is this sign called?
explanation: The otoscopic picture of both the tympanic membranes shows the Schwartze sign. This finding along with the history of bilateral conductive deafness is seen in active otosclerosis. A reddish hue may be seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane (Schwartze sign). This is indicative of an active focus with increased vascularity. The tympanic membrane is quite normal and mobile. Option A: Rising sun sign is seen in glomus tumor. Option C: Setting sun sign is an eye sign seen in hydrocephalus. Option D: Cartwheel appearance is seen in acute suppurative otitis media.
subject: ENT

question_text: An ENT senior resident posted in a remote village comes across a patient in whom he suspects otosclerosis. Which of the following tests can be used if he wants to clinically confirm the diagnosis?
explanation: Gelle’s is a tuning fork test done to clinically confirm otosclerosis in the olden days. It is based on the fact that in a normal ear if pressure is increased in the external ear the stapes footplate will get medialized and will stop conducting sound. But, in an ear with otosclerosis of the footplate, there will be no movements and the patient will continue to hear the sound. Thus, Gelle’s test is considered positive in normal persons and in those with sensorineural hearing loss. It is negative when the ossicular chain is fixed or disconnected. Stenger’s test is done to rule out malingering. Schwabach is a tuning fork test that compares the bone conduction of the patient with that of the examiner. Rinne’s is a tuning fork test that compares bone conduction with air conduction.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following symptoms is not included in the triad of Van der Hoeve syndrome?
explanation: Icterus is not included in the triad of Van der Hoeve syndrome The triad of symptoms is called Van der Hoeve syndrome: Osteogenesis imperfecta Otosclerosis Blue sclera
subject: ENT

question_text: A 25-year-old woman with a family history of hearing loss in her mother developed a hearing problem during pregnancy. Hearing loss is bilateral and progressive. Which of the following is the single best investigation to establish a diagnosis?
explanation: The above clinical scenario is suggestive of otosclerosis and the single best investigation to diagnose otosclerosis is impedance audiometry. Option B- In pure tone audiometry (PTA), Carhart's notch with an air-bone gap indicates otosclerosis. Option C- MRI is usually not done. HRCT is the preferred imaging modality for otosclerosis. Option D- Schwabach’s test is a tuning fork test that shows conductive hearing loss.
subject: ENT

question_text: Carhart’s notch typically dips at which of the following frequencies?
options: 4000 Hz in both BC and AC
explanation: Carhart's notch typically dips at 2000 Hz in bone conduction. Pure tone audiometry in otosclerosis: Air conduction is poor & worse for lower frequencies. Bone conduction is normal. There is a large air-bone gap In some cases, there is a dip in the bone conduction curve. It is different at different frequencies but the maximum dip is at 2000 Hz and is called Carhart’s notch. Note: Boiler’s notch is a similar dip in BC and AC curve but at 4000 Hz seen in noise-induced hearing loss.
subject: ENT

question_text: An elderly woman with a history of otosclerosis has now come with worsening deafness. She attained menopause 1 year ago. What would be the most likely report if impedance audiometry was done for her?
options: Ad graph with increased stapedial reflex
As graph with loss of stapedial reflex
As graph with increased stapedial reflex
explanation: The above case is suggestive of a long-standing case of otosclerosis and impedance audiometry will show As graph and loss of stapedial reflex as a result of fixation of ossicles. Impedance audiometer measures 2 parameters in the middle ear: Tympanogram - Type As is seen in otosclerosis due to decreased compliance at or near ambient air pressure Stapedial reflex - Stapedial reflex is lost due to immobile ossicles.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient was diagnosed with otosclerosis and Schwartze’s sign was positive on otoscopy. How will you manage this patient?
explanation: Sodium fluoride is used in the medical management of otosclerosis. This is an active case of otosclerosis evidenced by Schwartze’s sign and in an active case of otosclerosis medical management is preferred. Surgery is contraindicated if Schwartze’s sign is positive. Schwartze sign - A reddish hue is seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane. This is indicative of an active focus with increased vascularity. In an active case of otosclerosis, medical management with Sodium fluoride (NaF) is preferred because NaF hastens the maturity of active focus in otosclerosis. It acts by inhibiting the osteoclasts and decreasing the proteolytic enzymes.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 25-year-old woman presents with bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss. On examination, the tympanic membrane is normal and the audiogram shows bilateral conductive deafness. Impedance audiometry shows As type of curve and acoustic reflexes are absent. Which of the following treatment options is not used in patients with the above diagnosis?
explanation: The above clinical scenario of bilateral progressive conductive deafness with As type of tympanogram and absent acoustic reflexes is suggestive of otosclerosis. Gentamicin is not used in the management of otosclerosis. Medical management includes the use of sodium fluoride and bisphosphonates in active cases. Surgical management includes stapedectomy and stapedotomy, though the latter is preferred due to decreased risk of fistula formation. Hearing aids may be used as an alternative to surgery.
subject: ENT

question_text: A primipara is being evaluated for hearing impairment which had worsened during her pregnancy. Rinne’s test is negative in both the ears and Weber’s lateralized to the right side. On otoscopy, tympanic membranes appear normal. Audiometry shows a dip in BC at 2000 Hz. What is the treatment of choice for the above condition?
explanation: The above clinical scenario is suggestive of otosclerosis and the treatment of choice for otosclerosis is stapedotomy. Stapedotomy is the excision of the superstructure of stapes and drilling a hole in the footplate & placing a piston in the hole. This is the treatment of choice. Stapedectomy is the excision of the entire stapes (superstructure + footplate) and placing a piston in its place. It is outdated. NaF is used in an active case of otosclerosis to hasten maturation. Note: Both stapedectomy and stapedotomy have been described for the treatment of otosclerosis. Even in the stapedectomy procedure, stapedotomy (drilling) has been practiced. Hence stapedotomy is preferred over stapedectomy and is considered the treatment of choice. In the above case since Rinne’s test is negative on both ears, it indicates bilateral conductive deafness. Weber’s test will lateralize to the ear with greater conductive loss.
subject: ENT

question_text: You are assisting in a stapedotomy procedure for a patient with otosclerosis. After appropriate dissection, where will you place the piston?
explanation: The piston is placed between the incus and oval window. Stapedotomy is done to bypass the immobile stapes using a piston which will take over the function of conducting sound. For this reason, the piston replaces the removed stapes superstructure.
subject: ENT

question_text: You are an ENT surgeon and the following are few patients with otosclerosis. For which of the following patients will you advise stapedotomy?
explanation: A stapedotomy will be indicated for patients 4 and 5 as bronchial asthma and diabetes without schwartze sign are not contraindications for the procedure. Contraindications for Stapedotomy: Only hearing ear Positive Schwartze sign Otitis externa Meniere’s disease: can damage the inner ear while drilling a hole in the footplate Young children Professional athletes, pilots, construction workers, and divers: Sudden changes in pressure can displace the piston and cause vertigo. Those who work in noisy surroundings: Surgery makes them more vulnerable to noise-induced hearing loss.
subject: ENT

question_text: An ENT surgeon has referred a patient with otosclerosis posted for stapedotomy to your anesthesia OPD. She has no known co-morbidities. Which of the following techniques will you recommend for the above patient?
explanation: Stapedotomy is preferred to be done under local anesthesia because - Immediate on-table improvement of hearing can be assessed Damage to the inner ear can be assessed by the patient’s symptoms of vertigo/ nystagmus Damage to the facial nerve can be checked.
subject: ENT

question_text: In a patient with otosclerosis who underwent stapedotomy, which of the following complications is least likely?
explanation: Cholesteatoma is not a complication of stapedotomy. Complications of stapedotomy: Sensorineural hearing loss Injury to the facial nerve Floating/ submerged footplate Endolymph gush due to damage to the inner ear Dislodgement of piston Post-op vertigo Dead ear.
subject: ENT

question_text:
In Lempert’s fenestration, an alternative window is created in which of the following structures?
Oval window
explanation: Lempert’s fenestration, an alternative window is created in the lateral semicircular canal to function for the obliterated oval window. Lempert’s fenestration operation for otosclerosis is outdated now. It has the disadvantage of a postoperative mastoid cavity and an inherent hearing loss of 25 dB which cannot be corrected. Meniere’s Disease
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is not Ménière’s disease?
explanation: Ménière’s disease is also called endolymphatic hydrops. It is a disorder of the inner ear where the endolymphatic system is distended with endolymph. This occurs due either due to excessive production or faulty absorption of endolymph. It has 2 variants: Cochlear hydrops - the main feature is hearing loss. Vertigo is absent. Vestibular hydrops - repeated episodes of vertigo without loss of hearing.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following statements are true about Ménière’s disease?
explanation: Ménière’s disease is commonly seen in the age group of 35-60 years and incidence peaks in the fifth decade. It is a disorder of the inner ear causing a sensorineural type of hearing loss. Usually, it is unilateral but the other ear may be affected after a few years. Symptoms of the disease occur in attacks (episodes) and there is not a constant presence of the symptoms.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of these symptoms is least likely to be present in a patient diagnosed with Ménière’s disease?
explanation: Otalgia is least likely to be present in a patient diagnosed with Ménière’s disease. The characteristic triad of Ménière’s disease includes: Episodic vertigo- attacks come in clusters, with periods of spontaneous remission lasting for weeks, months, or years Fluctuating hearing loss- hearing is affected during episodes of vertigo, improves after the attack, and maybe normal during remissions Tinnitus- low-pitched whistling or roaring type Warning symptoms preceding an attack of vertigo in Ménière’s: Sense of fullness in the ear Change in pitch or increasing intensity of tinnitus Decrease in hearing
subject: ENT

question_text: A 35-year-old patient presented with complaints of intolerance to loud sounds and mild giddiness associated with ringing in the ear. What is the probable cause of intolerance to loud sounds in this patient?
explanation: Intolerance to loud sounds in this patient is due to the recruitment phenomenon (sound is amplified to be heard better). It is a feature of all cochlear pathologies. The characteristic presentation of a middle-aged man with vertigo, tinnitus, and intolerance to loud sounds points to a diagnosis of Ménière’s disease. It is a cochlear pathology, hence shows the recruitment phenomenon. The rollover phenomenon is a feature of retro-cochlear pathologies like an acoustic neuroma. Diplacusis is the perception of a single auditory stimulus as sounds of a different pitch in two ears. Tullio phenomenon is a condition where loud sounds precipitate a vertiginous attack.
subject: ENT

question_text: A middle-aged man presented with a history of vertigo, tinnitus, and intolerance to loud sounds. He constantly gets vertiginous episodes when exposed to loud sounds or noise. This phenomenon is not seen in which of the following conditions?
options: ASOM with a perforated tympanic membrane
explanation: The phenomenon described above is the Tullio phenomenon and is not seen in ASOM with a perforated tympanic membrane. The Tullio phenomenon refers to sound-induced vertigo. People with this condition experience unsteadiness, vertigo, nausea and rapid involuntary eye movements (nystagmus) when exposed to loud sounds or noise. It is due to the distended saccule lying against the stapes footplate. Some cases of Ménière’s disease show the Tullio phenomenon. It is also seen whenever there is a third mobile window lesion such as otic syphilis, perilymph fistula and dehiscence of semicircular canals.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following would be the most likely audiometric finding in a patient who is diagnosed with early Ménière’s disease?
explanation: Early Ménière’s disease affects lower frequencies. As the disease progresses, all the frequencies become affected. There is no classical audiogram pattern that can be used to identify Ménière’s disease. However, there are certain features that have been commonly observed. These include: A varying degree of sensorineural hearing loss. This hearing loss is usually low frequency.
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the summating potential: action potential ratio seen in Ménière’s disease on electrocochleography?
explanation: Summating potential: action potential ratio (SP: AP) >0.4 or 0.5 are consistent with a diagnosis of Ménière’s disease. Normally, the ratio of SP to AP is 0.3 (suggestive of normal cochlear function).
subject: ENT

question_text: A middle-aged patient presented with a history of recurrent episodes of whirling vertigo, which usually are preceded by a variable sense of ear pressure and fullness, decreased hearing, and low-tone roaring tinnitus. Which of the following is a useful test to diagnose this patient's condition?
explanation: The given clinical history points to a diagnosis of Ménière’s disease. The glycerol test is useful for the diagnosis of Ménière’s disease. Glycerol is an osmotic diuretic which when given orally reduces hydrops and improves symptoms. Electrocochleography done along with a glycerol test. An improvement after administration of glycerol is diagnostic of Ménière’s disease. The caloric test used in Ménière’s disease is not diagnostic as it is abnormal in many other conditions like ototoxicity, vestibular schwannoma, vestibular neuritis, etc. Dix-Hallpike test is performed to diagnose BPPV. A positive test would result in a vertiginous episode and nystagmus observed by the clinician.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 37-year-old man presented with a history of progressive hearing loss over a year, followed by an episode of sudden onset vertigo. He noticed an improvement in hearing after the vertiginous episode. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The most likely diagnosis would be Lermoyez syndrome. It is a variant of Ménière’s wherein the symptoms appear in reverse order. The patient presents with a progressive hearing loss followed by an attack of vertigo which causes improvement in hearing. Lemierre’s syndrome is a condition characterized by infectious thrombophlebitis of the internal jugular vein and bacteremia caused by primarily anaerobic organisms, following a recent oropharyngeal infection. Leriche syndrome, commonly referred to as an aortoiliac occlusive disease, is due to thrombotic occlusion of the abdominal aorta just above the site of its bifurcation. Leigh syndrome (subacute necrotizing encephalomyelopathy) is a rare genetic neurometabolic disorder characterized by degeneration of the CNS.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient diagnosed with Meniere’s disease presented with a history of sudden fall without loss of consciousness and no associated neurological or cardiovascular symptoms. On examination, there were no neurological deficits. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical presentation is suggestive of Tumarkin’s otolithic crisis. Tumarkin’s otolithic crisis (drop attacks) is when a patient with Meniere’s develops sudden drop attacks without loss of consciousness. It is an uncommon manifestation. Its pathogenesis is not well understood. Tullio phenomenon: It is a condition seen with some cases of Meniere's disease, where loud sounds or noise produce vertigo. This phenomenon is due to the distended saccule lying against the stapes footplate. Lermoyez syndrome: Here symptoms of Meniere's disease are seen in reverse order. Initially, there is a progressive deterioration of hearing, followed by an attack of vertigo.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is not a differential diagnosis for a patient with suspected Ménière’s disease?
explanation: CSOM is a middle ear disease with symptoms of ear discharge and is not a differential for Ménière’s. Ménière’s is a cochlear pathology with symptoms of vertigo, hearing loss & tinnitus. Differentials of Ménière’s disease: Vestibular neuronitis BPPV Cervical spondylosis Acoustic tumours Vertebrobasilar insufficiency Labyrinthitis Perilymph fistula Migraine induced vertigo
subject: ENT

question_text: A 27-year-old woman diagnosed with Ménière’s disease presented with complaints of sudden onset dizziness and sensation of surroundings swirling. Which of the following drugs cannot be used as a vestibular sedative to treat this condition?
explanation: Among the given drugs, Loratadine is not a vestibular sedative. Loratadine is a second generation antihistamine which lacks CNS depressant effects. It is used for allergic rhinitis, chronic idiopathic urticaria, and exercise-induced bronchospasm prophylaxis. The first line of treatment of an acute episode of Ménière’s is symptomatic and hence vestibular sedatives are the mainstay in the treatment. These are Dimenhydrinate Prochlorperazine Promethazine Rarely- diazepam and atropine
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following drugs is a vasodilator of the inner ear?
explanation: Betahistine is a vasodilator of the inner ear. It is used in the treatment of Meniere's disease. It is reported to act by: Improving microvascular circulation in the stria vascularis of the cochlea Inhibiting vestibular nuclei activity
subject: ENT

question_text: An ENT surgeon is going to perform a chemical labyrinthectomy on a patient with Meniere's disease, that is refractory to treatment. Which of the following drugs will he be using for this procedure?
explanation: Gentamicin is the drug used in chemical labyrinthectomy. Gentamicin is mainly vestibulotoxic. It has been used in daily or biweekly injections into the middle ear (Intratympanic gentamicin therapy). The drug is absorbed through the round window and destroys the vestibular labyrinth.
subject: ENT

question_text: Microwick and microcatheter devices are used in which of the following diseases?
explanation: Microwick and microcatheter devices are used to treat Meniere’s disease, sudden sensorineural hearing loss (sudden SNHL), and autoimmune inner ear disease. These devices are used to deliver drugs from the external canal to the inner ear thereby avoiding repeated intratympanic injections. When soaked with the drug, wick delivers it to the round window to be absorbed into the inner ear. It has been used to deliver : Steroids in sudden sensorineural deafness and autoimmune inner ear disease. Gentamicin to destroy the vestibular labyrinth in Ménière’s disease.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient with Meniere’s disease has debilitating vertigo episodes which are causing him multiple daily falls. On examination, mild hearing loss is present. Which of the following is not a treatment option for this patient?
explanation: Labyrinthectomy is a destructive procedure that totally destroys cochlear and vestibular function. Thus, It is used only when the cochlear function is not serviceable. This patient has mild hearing loss with disabling vertigo, so conservative procedures are to be offered. In these procedures, hearing is preserved. Conservative procedures done for Ménière’s include: Decompression of endolymphatic sac Endolymphatic shunt operation Sacculotomy (Fick’s operation) Section of the vestibular nerve Ultrasonic destruction of vestibular labyrinth.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 61-year-old woman is on treatment for Ménière’s disease for two years. Unfortunately, there is no improvement in her symptoms despite taking medications and intratympanic gentamicin injections. Which of the following treatment modalities would you not recommend for her?
explanation: A vestibulectomy is not done in Ménière’s disease. It is a surgical procedure that can be used to treat vulvar pain, specifically in cases of provoked vestibulodynia. Ménière’s disease, unresponsive or refractory to medical management (including intratympanic gentamicin) is treated with surgery. They can either be: Conservative (hearing is preserved): Decompression of endolymphatic sac Fick’s Sacculotomy Endolymphatic shunt Vestibular neurectomy Ultrasonic destruction of the vestibule Destructive: Labyrinthectomy Meniett’s device- provides intermittent positive pressure to the inner ear which improves hearing and reduces vertigo in these patients
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the definitive treatment of intractable vertigo due to Meniere’s disease?
explanation: The definitive treatment of intractable vertigo due to Ménière’s disease is labyrinthectomy. Labyrinthectomy involves uniform destruction of hearing and vestibular function. Ideal candidates have no functional hearing and have failed more conservative treatments, such as gentamicin injection. Despite this morbidity, labyrinthectomy has the highest rate of vertigo control (>95%), more than vestibular neurectomy (78-90%), and is considered the single definitive treatment. The step-by-step management approach for Ménière's disease consists of dietary modifications and vestibular suppressants as the initial measures, followed by intratympanic gentamicin ablation, and finally, surgical intervention. Primarily, the management of Menier's disease involves a sodium restricted diet and diuretics like acetazolamide (Option A). They are more useful for short-term control. Gentamicin (Option D) is a selective vestibulotoxic aminoglycoside antibiotic that is preferentially taken up by type I hair cells. It is opted for only if dietary modifications and vestibular suppressants have failed to control the symptoms. If used judiciously, hearing is preserved. The options for surgical management include - Endolymphatic sac surgery, vestibular neurectomy, and labyrinthectomy. Endolymphatic sac surgery is currently declining in popularity due to lack of evidence of vertigo control. Vestibular neurectomy (Option C) refers to selective ablation of the vestibular nerve. Even though it is considered a hearing sparing surgery and carries comparable rates of vertigo control as labyrinthectomy, it is an intradural procedure and carries a greater risk of complications. Hearing loss will still progress as it would have in the natural course of illness.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following features is not associated with superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome?
explanation: Sensorineural hearing loss is not seen in superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome (SSCDS). They may experience mild to moderate hearing conductive loss. Conductive hearing loss is due to the abnormal transmission and dissipation of acoustic energy through the defect (third window), leading to reduced conduction to the cochlea for lower frequencies. This can manifest as a low-frequency air-bone gap at multiple frequencies. There is no defect in the cochlea or the auditory pathway. Superior semicircular canal dehiscence (SSCD) is a condition in which bone between the apex of the superior semicircular canal and the middle cranial fossa is absent. This causes endolymph in the labyrinthine system to move with sound or pressure, causing an activation of the vestibular system. Patients may have vestibular symptoms like vertigo triggered by loud sounds (Tullio phenomenon)or pressure such as coughing and can also experience hyperacusis for bone-conducted sounds. They may perceive the sounds of their own eye movements or footsteps in the affected ear. The patients may exhibit nystagmus when exposed to loud sounds or during the Valsalva maneuver or pressure in the ear canal (positive fistula test). The direction of the nystagmus aligns with the affected superior semicircular canal, and some patients may tilt their heads in the plane of the affected superior semicircular canal in response to loud sounds. Noncontrast HRCT of the temporal bone can demonstrate the defect. The click-evoked VEMP (vestibular evoked myogenic potential) response and vestibuloocular reflex are pronounced in SSCD patients, in which the evoked eye movements align with the affected superior canal. For mild symptoms, avoidance of triggers is recommended. In case of severe disabling symptoms, surgical resurfacing of the superior semicircular canal or plugging of the superior semicircular canal may be attempted.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient complains that he feels like the room is spinning when he gets up from lying down or turning his head. He has no history of loss of consciousness. Which of the following could be the probable diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario, with complaints of dizziness associated with postural change and no history of loss of consciousness is suggestive of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). BPPV is one of the common causes of recurrent vertigo, and the episodes are brief (<1min) and are always provoked by changes in head position. The attacks are caused by free-floating calcium carbonate crystals usually dislodged from the posterior canal. A positive Dix-Hallpike maneuver confirms the diagnosis of BPPV. In this maneuver, the patient begins sitting up with their head turned 45° toward the ear to be tested. Then the patient is made to lie down quickly with their head past the end of the bed. Then, the patient's neck is extended 20° below the horizontal. The clinician then watches the patient's eyes for torsional and up-beating nystagmus, which should persist for no more than one minute. This would indicate a positive test. Epley's maneuver is performed to reposition the crystals into the macula from the semicircular canals. This is only a temporary cure and there is a high rate of recurrence.
subject: ENT

question_text:
A 52-year-old woman presents to the ENT surgeon with a history of vertigo whenever she moves sideways on the bed while lying supine. She feels nauseous and as if the room is spinning. The symptoms subside after a few minutes but return when she moves her head. Which of the following tests is most appropriate to diagnose this condition?
Dix-Hallpike’s manoeuvre
Glycerol test
Caloric test
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV). The diagnostic maneuver used in BPPV is the Dix-Hallpike maneuver, the gold standard for diagnosing BPPV. The therapeutic maneuver is Epley's maneuver. BPPV is one of the common causes of recurrent vertigo, and the episodes are brief (<1min) and are always provoked by changes in head position. The attacks are caused by free-floating calcium carbonate crystals usually dislodged from the posterior canal. A patient presenting with vertigo should be evaluated for ruling out the central lesions (like a tumor in the fourth ventricle, multiple sclerosis, etc) before confirming the diagnosis of BPPV. Dix-Hallpike maneuver helps rule out central lesions and also diagnose BPPV. Dix-Hallpike maneuver: The maneuver starts with the patient in a sitting position. Their head is turned 45° towards the ear to be tested. The examiner quickly brings the patient to a supine position with their head 30° below the horizontal. The 45-degree head rotation is maintained during the procedure. Now the examiner observes the patient for nystagmus. Tumors of Ear
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is the most common site for ear carcinoma?
explanation: The most common site for ear carcinoma is the pinna, followed by the external auditory meatus, the middle ear, and mastoid.
subject: ENT

question_text: Where are sebaceous cysts most commonly located in the ear?
explanation: The most common site of a sebaceous cyst is postauricular sulcus or below and behind the ear lobule. Treatment is total surgical excision.
subject: ENT

question_text: What is shown in the given image?
explanation: The image shows a dark-colored summit over a swelling, usually seen in a sebaceous cyst. Sebaceous cysts are the retention cysts of the sebaceous gland that are usually present on the face, scalp, or scrotum. They contain yellowish-white cheesy material with fat and epithelium. Clinical features: The swelling is painless, soft, and freely mobile. Though non-transilluminating, they are Paget's test positive (fluctuant). Punctum is seen in 70% of the patients with sebaceous cysts. They are dark in color due to the accumulation of denuded epithelium. They also have an unpleasant sebum odor. The swelling can ulcerate and become painful (Cock’s peculiar tumor). Some cysts over the scalp may also harden over time (Sebaceous horn). Many may get infected and lead to abscess formation. Treatment: Excision including skin adjacent to punctum using elliptical incision-dissection method. Incision and avulsion of cyst wall. In the presence of an abscess, an initial treatment with an incision later followed by excision of the cyst Other options: Option A: Dermoid cysts present as firm painless subcutaneous nodules and are of 4 types: Sequestration dermoid - sequestration of epithelium during embryological development Tubulodermoid - accumulation of secretions from ectodermal tube/duct Implantation dermoid - implantation of the epidermis due to trauma Teratomatous dermoid - having all 3 germ layers (ecto, meso, and endoderm) Option C: Meningiomas are benign tumors arising from the meningothelial cells of the dura. They present with headaches, seizures, or focal neurological deficits. Option D: Postauricular cutaneous mastoid fistula is a rare complication of chronic otitis media that heals very slowly and needs surgical closure.
subject: ENT

question_text: A surfer presented with hearing loss and a feeling of fullness in his ear. On otoscopy, multiple bony swellings were present in the external auditory canal. Which of the following features is diagnostic of exostosis?
explanation: Exostoses are bilateral, multiple, smooth, sessile bony swellings in the deeper canal seen in divers/swimmers and surfers. It is also called as surfer’s ear. Osteoma Exostosis/Surfer's Ear Single Multiple Unilateral Bilateral Pedunculated, ha rd Sessile, smooth Outer canal Inner, deeper canal
subject: ENT

question_text: A middle-aged woman presents with foul-smelling ear discharge and hearing loss for 1 year. On examination, a hemorrhagic polypoidal mass was seen in the middle ear. Biopsy revealed squamous cell carcinoma of the middle ear. Where is it least likely to spread to?
explanation: Squamous cell carcinoma is least likely to spread to the dura, as it is resistant to invasion. It commonly affects middle-aged women. Other clinical features include- Chronic foul-smelling discharge that is usually blood-stained. Friable, hemorrhagic granulations Polyp Hearing loss It usually spreads to Ossicles Facial cana Internal ear Jugular bulb & carotid artery Petrous pyramid Parotid & temporomandibular joint Eustachian tube, Nasopharynx & Infratemporal fossa. Lymph node involvement is a late finding.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is the most common benign tumor of the middle ear?
explanation: Glomus tumor is the most common benign neoplasm of the middle ear and is so-named because of its origin from the glomus bodies.
subject: ENT

question_text: A post-menopausal woman with progressive hearing loss and tinnitus is diagnosed to have a glomus tumor. Which cells do her tumor originate from?
explanation: Glomus tumors originate from paraganglionic cells that are derived from neural crest cells. They are found in glomus bodies present in the dome of the jugular bulb or promontory. These cells are found in 2 sites giving rise to 2 similar yet distinct clinical tumors: Glomus jugulare: in the jugular bulb Glomus tympanicum: over the promontory along Jacobson’s nerve(IX nerve).
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following statements is false about paragangliomas of the head and neck?
explanation: Paragangliomas of the head and neck, also known as glomus tumors, affect women more than men. Glomus tumors are benign, non-encapsulated but vascular. They are extremely slow-growing, locally invasive, and often seen in middle age (40–50 years).
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the earliest symptom of glomus tumors?
explanation: Earliest symptoms of glomus tumor are tinnitus and hearing loss. Hearing loss is conductive and slowly progressive.
subject: ENT

question_text: You are a junior resident in the ENT department. A patient presents to you with pulsatile tinnitus. Which of the following will be your first differential diagnosis?
explanation: Glomus tumour will be your first differential diagnosis. Tinnitus in glomus tumors is: Pulsatile Of swishing character Synchronous with pulse and Can be temporarily stopped by carotid pressure.
subject: ENT

question_text: You are evaluating a patient with a glomus tumor and on otoscopy, see the following image. Which of the following signs is seen here?
explanation: Rising sun sign is seen here, as it is a case of glomus tumor. The rising sun appearance is seen when a tumor arises from the floor of the middle ear. Otoscopy shows a red reflex through an intact tympanic membrane. Option A - Cartwheel appearance is the leash of blood vessels appear along the handle of malleus and at the periphery of tympanic membrane. Option B - Lighthouse sign is a pulsatile discharge from a pin-hole perforation of pars tensa seen in mastoiditis. Option D - Schwartze sign is the reddish hue seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane in otosclerosis.
subject: ENT

question_text: While evaluating a patient with a suspected aural polyp, you apply Siegel's speculum and observe that the mass pulsates vigorously and then blanches. What is this sign called?
explanation: The sign is called Brown’s sign or pulsation sign which is suggestive of glomus tumor. When ear canal pressure is raised with Siegel’s speculum, the tumor pulsates vigorously and then blanches. The reverse happens with the release of pressure. Option A - Rising Sun sign is seen when glomus tumor arises from the floor of the middle ear. Option B - Schwarze sign is the reddish hue seen on the promontory through the tympanic membrane in otosclerosis. Option C - Lighthouse sign is a pulsatile discharge from a pin-hole perforation of pars tensa seen in mastoiditis.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient presents with a history of hearing loss and tinnitus. On examination, a polypoidal mass is seen in the middle ear, which bleeds heavily on touch. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of glomus tympanicum, a subtype of glomus tumors. Symptoms of glomus tumors: Hearing loss Tinnitus Bleeding from the ear Vertigo and facial palsy Dysphagia, hoarseness of voice (cranial nerve palsies). Examination findings: Intratympanic tumor: rising sun appearance with a positive Brown sign Red, vascular polyp that bleeds readily on manipulation or biopsy Once the tympanic membrane is breached: bleeding polyp in the external ear Audible bruit over the mastoid.
subject: ENT
