question_text: A 60-year-old woman presented with hearing loss, pulsatile ringing in the right ear, and deviation of the tongue to the right side. MRI revealed a mass in the right jugular fossa. On examination, a pulsatile reddish mass was seen behind the intact tympanic membrane. Which of the following structures is invaded by the mass?
explanation: The given case scenario of hearing loss, pulsatile tinnitus, 12th cranial nerve involvement, and red mass on otoscopy is suggestive of glomus jugulare. Hypotympanum is invaded by the tumor. It arises in the adventitia of the dome of the jugular bulb and invades the hypotympanum, jugular foramen, and jugular vein. In addition to ear signs and symptoms, cranial nerve involvement is commonly seen of the IXth to XIIth cranial nerves in glomus jugulare.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 45-year-old is referred to your ENT practice with pulsatile tinnitus, and Brown’s sign is positive. The patient gives you her CT films. Which of the following CT signs will help you differentiate between glomus jugulare and glomus tympanicum?
explanation: Phelp sign helps differentiate between glomus jugulare and glomus tympanicum on CT. It is the erosion of the spine of the carotico-jugular crest, seen in glomus jugulare tumors. It is intact in glomus tympanicum. Option A - Battle's sign is ecchymosis over the mastoid seen in fractures of the temporal bone. Option B - Lyre sign- splaying apart of internal and external carotid arteries on angiogram in cases of carotid body tumor of the neck. Option D - Griesinger's sign is edema over the mastoid and is seen in lateral sinus thrombosis. The image given shows Battle's sign.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 68-year old woman presents with complaints of right-sided facial weakness for 15 days and progressive hearing loss for 2 years. On examination, there is tachycardia and carotid bruit on the right side. Otoscopy shows a red mass behind the tympanic membrane and 24-hour urine collection shows the presence of metanephrines. Which of the following classification systems is used for this condition?
explanation: The given case scenario with right-sided facial palsy, hearing loss, red mass behind the tympanic membrane, tachycardia, carotid bruit and positive urinary metanephrines is suggestive of a functional glomus tumor. 10% of all glomus tumors are functional and secrete catecholamines. This is diagnosed by testing the patient's 24-hour urine collection for urinary VMA (vanillylmandelic acid) or metanephrines. Glomus tumors are classified based on Fisch classification Option A: Lederman's classification is used in maxillary carcinoma. Option C: Austin's classification is used to classify anatomical defects in the ossicular chain. Option D: Sade's classification is used to classify atelectasis or retraction of the pars tensa. Class Extent Class A Tumor limited to the middle ear (mesotympanum) Class B Tumor in the middle ear (me so- and hypotympanum) and the mastoid Class C Tumour originates in the do me of the jugular bulb, destr oying the overlying bone and has extensive local spread. Class D Intracranial extension. It can be intradural or extradural
subject: ENT

question_text: A middle-aged woman presents with deafness, tinnitus, and bleeding from the ear. On examination, a reddish mass is seen behind the tympanic membrane which blanches on applying pressure with the pneumatic speculum. Which of the following is not a part of its management?
explanation: A pre-operative biopsy is not done in the management of glomus tumor due to the following reasons. Tumour is highly vascular and since the vessels lack the contractile musculature it bleeds profusely. Risk of injury to High jugular bulb Aberrant internal carotid artery Clinical and radiological features are enough to arrive at a diagnosis. Treatment consists of: Surgical removal. Radiation. Embolization. Combination of the above Glomus tumor: Circled in red: Note: Although CT is the test of choice for the evaluation of bone involvement, gadolinium-enhanced MRI provides a superior definition of the relationship of the tumor to adjacent vascular and skull base structures. Hence Both MRI and CT are typically needed for a suspected jugulotympanic paraganglioma given that the information derived from each study is complementary.
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the most common tumor at the cerebellopontine angle?
explanation: Acoustic neuroma is the most common tumor at the cerebellopontine angle. It arises from the vestibular division of the VIIIth nerve within the internal auditory canal, widens and erodes the canal and appears at the cerebellopontine angle. Other tumors arising at the cerebellopontine angle are: Meningioma Cholesteatoma Arachnoid cysts Facial nerve schwannomas Glomus tumor.
subject: ENT

question_text: Where does acoustic neuroma most commonly arise from?
explanation: Acoustic neuroma or vestibular schwannoma almost always arises from the Schwann cells of the vestibular division of 8th nerve. It arises from the superior and the inferior division of the vestibular nerve in the medial internal auditory canal at the site of transition of central to peripheral myelin i.e., Obersteiner-Redlich zone. Rarely, it can arise from the cochlear division of the 8th nerve within the internal auditory canal.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following features is common to vestibular schwannomas and glomus tumors?
explanation: Glomus tumors and vestibular shwannomas are both slow-growing, benign tumors of the temporal bone with locally invasive properties. Vestibular shwannomas are encapsulated tumors. They are seen in middle aged individuals and have equal incidence in both sexes. Glomus tumors are vascular paragangliomas and are non-encapsulated tumors. They are seen more commonly in middle-aged women.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is the most common symptoms that acoustic neuroma presents with?
explanation: Progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL), often accompanied by tinnitus, is the presenting symptom in the majority of cases. Early symptoms of acoustic neuroma: Progressive unilateral SNHL Gross inability to understand speech out of proportion to the PTA average Tinnitus Unsteadiness and imbalance The involvement of other cranial nerves leads to other deficits.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is the earliest cranial nerve to be involved in acoustic neuroma?
explanation: The 8th cranial nerve is the earliest to be involved in acoustic neuroma. Cochleovestibular symptoms are the earliest symptoms when the tumor is still intracanalicular and are caused by pressure on cochlear or vestibular nerve fibers or on the internal auditory artery. Once the tumor erodes the canal, it presents in the cerebellopontine angle and can expand to involve other nearby cranial nerves such as the 5th and 7th cranial nerves. Note: Acoustic neuroma arises from the 8th cranial nerve. Hence, it is the first nerve involved. However, if the 8th cranial nerve is not given as an option, then the answer would be the 5th cranial nerve.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 50-year-old patient presents with progressive unilateral hearing loss, decreased lacrimation, and loss of taste. On examining the external auditory meatus, there is decreased sensation on the posterior side. You suspect acoustic neuroma in this case. What sign was elicited here?
explanation: Hitzelberger’s sign is the sign elicited in the given clinical scenario of acoustic neuroma. Hitzelberger’s sign is the hypoaesthesia of the posterior meatal wall because the tumor has affected the sensory fibers of the facial nerve. In this case, sensory fibers of the facial nerve are affected, as the patient has decreased lacrimation and loss of taste. Motor fibers are more resistant and are affected late. A delayed blink reflex may be an early manifestation.
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the gold standard investigation to confirm acoustic neuroma?
explanation: MRI with gadolinium contrast is the gold standard for the diagnosis of acoustic neuroma. It is superior to a CT scan. Intracanalicular tumors measuring even a few millimeters can be easily diagnosed by this method.
subject: ENT

question_text: A middle-aged-man presents with progressive sensorineural hearing loss, imbalance, and tinnitus. Which of the following features rules out Meniere’s disease and is diagnostic of acoustic neuroma?
explanation: Rollover phenomenon is diagnostic of acoustic neuroma. It is a feature of retro-cochlear/neural lesions wherein the speech discrimination steadily increases with intensity but suddenly drops significantly beyond a particular intensity of sound. Meniere’s disease is an important differential for acoustic neuroma as the patients suffer from similar symptoms. Meniere’s is a cochlear pathology and acoustic neuroma is retrocochlear. Option A - Stapedial reflex is present in cochlear lesions (Meniere’s) and absent in retrocochlear lesion (acoustic neuroma) Option B - Recruitment phenomenon is the abnormal growth in loudness in the affected ear, seen in cochlear pathologies. Option C - SISI (short increment sensitivity score) is a test of intensity discrimination which is very high in cochlear pathologies but low in retro-cochlear.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 50-year-old man presents with difficulty hearing. Pure tone audiometry shows rollover phenomenon. An MRI with Gadolinium contrast shows a mass over the cerebellopontine angle. What is the treatment of choice?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acoustic neuroma. Treatment of choice in this case is surgery. The approach depends upon site and size of tumor: Middle cranial fossa approach Translabyrinthine approach Retrosigmoid/Suboccipital approach Combined.
subject: ENT

question_text:
Which of the following is not used in the treatment of vestibular schwannomas?
X-Knife
explanation: Cold knife is not used in the treatment of vestibular schwannomas. It is used for the conization of the cervix in cervical carcinoma. Stereotactic radiosurgery is a reasonable alternative for people who refuse or cannot tolerate surgery. Here, beams are modified and focused only to concentrate on the tumor and have little effect on surrounding tissue. It can be done by using X-knife using a linear accelerator (LINAC) Gamma-knife using Cobalt 60 CyberKnife - image-guided linear accelerator using real-time image guidance to deliver radiation from multiple angles. External beam radiation is not recommended as it causes significant damage to the surrounding brain and neural structures. Anatomy of Facial Nerve
subject: ENT

question_text: What type of nerve is the facial nerve?
explanation: The facial nerve is a mixed cranial nerve which contains both sensory and motor part. It is the 7th cranial nerve.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is not a component of the facial nerve?
explanation: The general somatic efferent is not a component of the facial nerve. Components of the facial nerve: Special visceral efferent - motor to muscles of facial expression (derived from branchial arches, hence special visceral and not general somatic like the other muscles) General visceral efferent - secretomotor to lacrimal and submandibular glands Special visceral afferent - taste from anterior 2/3rd tongue General somatic afferent - general sensations from pinna, external auditory canal, and tympanic membrane.
subject: ENT

question_text: In a patient with an acoustic neuroma involving the sensory division of the facial nerve, the Hitzelberger sign was positive. What is the other name for this nerve?
explanation: The sensory division of the facial nerve is also called the nerve of Wrisberg. The facial nerve is a mixed nerve having the motor and a sensory root. Hitzelberger sign refers to hypoesthesia of the posterior meatal wall in acoustic neuroma due to the compression of the facial nerve. Option A: Jacobson’s nerve - the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (9th cranial nerve). It is associated with glomus tympanicum. Option B: Arnold’s nerve - the auricular branch of the vagus nerve (10th cranial nerve). Option D: Herring’s nerve - the carotid sinus branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (9th cranial nerve).
subject: ENT

question_text: You are performing the cranial nerve examination in a patient with a stroke. You noticed a loss of taste sensation in the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue. What is this sensation carried by?
explanation: The taste sensation from the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue is carried by the special visceral afferent of the facial nerve via chorda tympani nerve. The taste sensation from the hard and soft palate is also carried by the facial nerve via the greater superficial petrosal nerve to the nucleus tractus solitarius.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient with the following findings is presented to you. Where is the motor nucleus of the involved cranial nerve is located?
explanation: The given image shows left-sided lower motor neuron facial nerve palsy and the motor nucleus is located in the pons. It is located along with abducens and vestibulocochlear nerve nuclei.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following best describes the course of the facial nerve in the pons?
options: It hooks around the 8th nerve nucleus
It hooks around the 6th nerve nucleus
It exits the pons at ponto-pyramidal junction
explanation: The facial nerve in the pons hooks around the 6th (abducens) nerve nucleus. It exits the pons ventrally at the pontomedullary (ponto-olivary) junction. It then runs in the cerebellopontine angle to reach the internal auditory meatus.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is false about the first genu of the facial nerve?
options: Contains a ganglion which supplies the lacrimal gland
Gives the first branch of the facial nerve
Lies on the posterior wall of the middle ear
Between the fundus of the internal acoustic meatus and the geniculate ganglion.
explanation: The 1st genu of the facial nerve lies on the medial wall of the middle ear and not posterior wall. It is formed at the geniculate ganglion when the facial nerve from the fundus of the internal acoustic meatus takes a turn posteriorly. Then the facial nerve continues as a tympanic or horizontal segment. It homes the geniculate ganglion which supplies the lacrimal gland (via greater superficial petrosal nerve). It gives off the first branch of the facial nerve.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is true for the 2nd genu of the facial nerve?
options: It gives the second branch of the facial nerve
It lies on the inferior wall of the middle ear
It is at the junction of 3rd and 4th intratemporal segments
explanation: The 2nd genu of the facial nerve lies at the junction of the 3rd and the 4th intratemporal segments, between the tympanic and the mastoid segments. The 2nd genu of the facial nerve is formed where the horizontal facial nerve takes a turn inferiorly at the junction between the medial and posterior walls of the middle ear. It continues as the vertical segment of the facial nerve behind the posterior wall of the middle ear. It does not contain a ganglion and does not give any branches. The course of the facial nerve has 3 parts- Intracranial Intratemporal Extracranial. Intratemporal part of the facial nerve has 4 segments- Meatal Labyrinthine Tympanic/horizontal Mastoid/vertical segments. Option A: Gasserian ganglion is present in the trigeminal nerve. Option B: The temporal segment of the facial nerve ends with the 2nd genu. The nerve then passes vertically downward to form the mastoid segment. The 2nd branch of facial nerve (nerve to stapedius) arises from this segment close to the level of 2nd genu and not from the 2nd genu.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is the shortest and narrowest segment of the facial nerve?
explanation: The shortest and narrowest segment of the facial nerve is the labyrinthine segment (length 4.0 mm, diameter 0.61–0.68 mm). The labyrinthine segment is from the fundus of meatus to the geniculate ganglion where the nerve takes a turn posteriorly forming a genu. The nerve in the labyrinthine segment has the narrowest diameter and the bony canal in this segment is also the narrowest. Thus edema or inflammation can easily compress the nerve and cause paralysis.
subject: ENT

question_text: In the examination of a patient with facial nerve palsy, the Schirmer test was positive. Involvement of which of the following branches of the facial nerve is responsible for this?
explanation: Involvement of the greater superficial petrosal nerve causes a decrease in lacrimation, detected by the Schirmer test. It is the first branch of the facial nerve and arises from the geniculate ganglion. It carries secretomotor fibres to the lacrimal gland and the glands of nasal mucosa and palate.
subject: ENT

question_text: A young man who underwent surgery for chronic suppurative otitis media presented with a loss of taste sensation. Which segment of the facial nerve gives rise to the involved branch?
explanation: The injury to chorda tympani nerve produces loss of taste sensation in the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue and it arises from the mastoid or vertical segment of the facial nerve. Chorda tympani nerve carries the taste sensation from anterior 2/3rd of the tongue. It is a branch of the facial nerve arising from the mastoid/vertical segment after the nerve to stapedius before exiting the stylomastoid foramen. It relays in the nucleus of tractus solitarius.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is the most common site for congenital dehiscence of the fallopian canal?
explanation: The congenital dehiscence (absence of bony cover) of the fallopian canal of the facial nerve occurs most commonly in the tympanic or horizontal segment over the oval window. It is the most common anomaly of the facial canal. A dehiscent nerve is prone to injury at the time of surgery. It gets easily compressed or inflamed in mastoid and middle ear infections.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is not a terminal branch of the facial nerve?
explanation: The frontal branch is not a terminal branch of the facial nerve. The five terminal branches of the facial nerve are: Temporal Zygomatic Buccal Mandibular Cervical The extratemporal course of the facial nerve starts at the stylomastoid foramen where it exits the temporal bone and runs anteriorly to enter the substance of the parotid gland. Here it divides into 2 main terminal trunks, the temporofacial and the cervicofacial. These further divide and re-anastomose to give the five terminal branches.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient with an acoustic neuroma at the cerebellopontine angle presents with a facial nerve palsy. Which of the following muscles will not be paralyzed in this case?
explanation: Anterior belly of digastric is not paralyzed in facial nerve palsy. Muscles supplied by facial nerve: Nerve to stapedius - stapedius muscle. Posterior auricular nerve - muscles of the pinna and the occipital belly of occipitofrontalis. Muscular branches - stylohyoid and posterior belly of digastric. Terminal branches - muscles of facial expression.
subject: ENT

question_text: The facial nerve is not supplied by which of the following vessels?
explanation: Facial artery does not supply the facial nerve Vascular Supply of facial nerve: Anterior-inferior cerebellar artery supplies the nerve in the cerebellopontine angle Labyrinthine artery, a branch of the anterior-inferior cerebellar artery supplies the nerve in the internal auditory canal Superficial petrosal artery, a branch of the middle meningeal artery supplies geniculate ganglion and the adjacent region Stylomastoid artery, a branch of the posterior auricular artery supplies the mastoid segment.
subject: ENT

question_text: You are an ENT resident assisting on a modified radical mastoidectomy in a patient with cholesteatoma. Which of the following landmarks will not help you to identify the facial nerve?
explanation: Posterior semicircular canal is not used as a surgical landmark to identify the facial nerve. Surgical Landmarks of the facial nerve for middle ear and mastoid surgery: Processus cochleariformis - It demarcates the geniculate ganglion which lies just anterior to it. The tympanic segment of the nerve starts at this level. Oval window and horizontal semicircular canal - The horizontal segment of the facial nerve runs above the oval window (stapes) and below the horizontal/lateral semicircular canal. Short process of incus - The vertical segment of the facial nerve lies medial to the short process of incus at the level of aditus. Pyramid - The vertical segment of the facial nerve runs behind the pyramid and the posterior tympanic sulcus.
subject: ENT

question_text: While performing a parotidectomy, which of the following landmarks would you use to identify the facial nerve?
explanation: Tragus is used as a surgical landmark to identify facial nerve in parotid surgery. Surgical landmarks of the facial nerve for parotid surgery: Tragal pointer - triangular inferior portion of the tragus. The main trunk lies 1 cm deep to it. Tympanomastoid suture - the main trunk lies 6-8 mm deep to it. Styloid process - the nerve lies lateral to it Posterior belly of digastric attachment at the digastric groove - the nerve can be found emerging rom the stylomastoid foramen under the muscle but lateral to the styloid process.
subject: ENT

question_text:
While performing mastoid exploration, which of the following is not useful in preventing the injury to the facial nerve?
Constant saline irrigation
options: Drilling parallel to course of nerve
explanation: A larger burr is used to prevent facial nerve injury in the mastoid exploration and not a smaller burr. Measures to reduce facial nerve injury during mastoid exploration: Good anatomical knowledge Working parallel to the nerve, never at an angle. Use the biggest burr available. Smaller burrs are more harmful. Constant irrigation prevents thermal injury Granulations present over the facial nerve are best left alone. Good magnification. Facial Nerve Disorders
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is the most common type of facial nerve injury?
explanation: The most common type of nerve injury, in general, is neuropraxia. It is also true for facial nerve injury.
subject: ENT

question_text: You are a final-year student examining a patient with a right supranuclear facial palsy. Which of the following findings you will see?
options: Loss of taste from anterior 2/3rd of tongue
Paralysis of lower facial muscle on left side
Paralysis of lower facial nerve on right side
Loss of corneal reflex on left side
explanation: Right upper motor neuron (UMN) facial nerve palsy causes paralysis of lower facial muscles on the left side. The upper part of the facial nerve’s motor nucleus, which innervates forehead muscles, receives fibers from both the cerebral hemispheres. The lower part of the nucleus, which supplies the lower face, only receives crossed fibers from the contralateral hemisphere. Therefore, the upper part of the face gets bilateral innervation and the lower part of the face gets crossed innervation from the opposite side. Hence, in supranuclear lesion (UMN palsy), forehead is spared and muscles of the lower half of the opposite side of the face are affected. In LMN palsy, all muscles of the same side are affected.
subject: ENT

question_text: While examining a patient with upper motor neuron facial nerve palsy, you notice emotional expressions such as smiling and crying are unaffected. How will you explain this?
options: Innervation by fibres from prefrontal cortex
explanation: The fibres from the thalamus are responsible for the involuntary movements of facial muscles in emotional states. These fibres reach the facial nerve nucleus via alternate pathways and are unaffected by UMN causes.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is the most common cause of LMN facial nerve palsy?
explanation: Bell’s palsy is the most common cause of LMN facial nerve palsy. It is defined as idiopathic, ipsilateral lower motor neuron (LMN) facial paralysis, or paresis of acute onset. Causes of facial nerve palsy: UMN LMN Unilater al Vascular (infarct)Cerebral tu morMultiple sclerosis Bell's palsy (most common ov erall)Parotid tumorHead inju riesSkull base tumorsDiabete sHypertension Bilateral Vascular (infarct)Motor neur on disease Guillain-Barre syndromeSarc oidosisLeukemiaLymphomaL eprosy
subject: ENT

question_text: A 35-year-old housewife presents with facial weakness on the right side, difficulty in closing the right eye, and loss of taste sensation. A diagnosis of Bell’s palsy is made. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?
options: Males are affected more commonly than females
explanation: Bell’s palsy affects both males and females equally. It is an acute onset idiopathic ipsilateral LMN facial nerve palsy. Most of the evidence supports the viral etiology due to herpes simplex, herpes zoster, or the Epstein–Barr virus. Positive family history is present in 6–8% of patients. Most of the patients recover fully and the remaining require surgery. Recurrent facial palsy is seen in 3–10% of cases.
subject: ENT

question_text: While examining a patient with LMN facial palsy, you observe Bell's phenomenon. In which direction would you expect the eyeball to move?
explanation: In Bell’s phenomenon, the eyeball turns upwards and outwards on the affected side while attempting to close the eyes. This phenomenon is seen in LMN facial palsy. The following image shows Bell's phenomenon.
subject: ENT

question_text: You are an ENT resident examining a patient with Bell’s palsy. Which of the following findings is unlikely to be present in this patient?
explanation: Ptosis is not seen in patients with Bell’s palsy. Clinical presentation of Bell’s palsy: Sudden onset Bell's phenomenon Asymmetrical face Some may complain of noise intolerance (stapedial paralysis) or loss of taste (involvement of chorda tympani). The following image shows a patient with Bell's palsy.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient with facial nerve palsy is intolerant to loud sounds. Involvement of which muscle will cause this?
explanation: Noise intolerance in a patient with facial nerve palsy is due to stapedius muscle paralysis. The stapedius muscle is supplied by the facial nerve via nerve to stapedius. It acts by dampening the loud sounds and the loss of this function results in hyperacusis. Tensor veli palatini helps in opening the eustachian tube, hence also called dilator tubae muscle. Tensor tympani, supplied by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve, also helps in dampening the loud sounds. It is not involved in facial nerve palsy.
subject: ENT

question_text: In the evaluation of a patient with facial nerve palsy, what is the ideal time to do electroneuronography?
explanation: Electroneuronography is most useful when done between 4 and 21 days of the onset of complete paralysis. Degeneration of the nerve fibers cannot be detected earlier than 48–72 h of its commencement. Hence electrodiagnostic tests are done after 72 hours following injury.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 2nd year ENT resident is evaluating a patient with Bell’s palsy. Which of the following tests he will not do to identify the site of the lesion?
explanation: Electromyography is not a topodiagnostic test used in facial palsy. It is used to monitor nerve degeneration in facial palsy. Topodiagnostic tests are done to identify the site of lesion in the intratemporal part of the facial nerve. They are: Schirmer test - quantification of lacrimation Stapedial reflex Taste test by electrogustometry Submandibular salivary flow test.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient with facial nerve palsy presented with dry eye. Injury to which part of the facial nerve will produce this symptom?
explanation: Injury at the level or proximal to the geniculate ganglion will produce dry eye due to decreased lacrimation. Geniculate ganglion gives the secretomotor fibers to the lacrimal gland via the greater superficial petrosal nerve.
subject: ENT

question_text: A middle-aged man presents with facial asymmetry. On examination, there is loss of taste from anterior 2/3rd of the tongue, absent acoustic reflex, and normal Schirmer test. What is the site of the lesion?
explanation: The site of lesion in this patient with loss of taste from anterior 2/3rd of tongue and absent acoustic reflex is at the tympanic segment. Injury to the greater superficial petrosal nerve leads to loss of lacrimation which is detected by the Schirmer test. It is the first branch given at the level of the geniculate ganglion. Injury to the nerve to stapedius, the first motor branch of the facial nerve, leads to loss of stapedial reflex and hyperacusis, which can be detected by tympanometry. Injury to chorda tympani nerve leads to loss of taste from anterior 2/3rd of the tongue which is detected by electrogustometry and reduced submandibular and sublingual salivary flow detected by salivary flow test. So in this patient, the lesion is proximal to the origin of nerve to stapedius i.e. tympanic segment, and not proximal to geniculate ganglion as the lacrimation is normal.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 30-year-old man presented with the following findings which he noticed when he woke up in the morning. There was no history of associated fever or rash. A panel of investigations was done and were found to be normal. Which of the following is false regarding the treatment of this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Bell's palsy and statements 2,4 and 5 are false with respect to the treatment. Management of Bell's palsy: Steroids are the drug of choice for Bell's palsy. If the patient reports within 1 week, the adult dose of prednisolone 1 mg/kg/day in 2 divided doses for 5 days should be given. Steroids can be combined with acyclovir for herpes zoster oticus or if viral etiology is suspected in Bell's palsy. General measures include reassurance, physiotherapy, or massage of facial muscles, and care of the eye to prevent exposure keratitis. It includes artificial tears drops, eye ointment, and taping of eyes during the night. If the recovery is prolonged, temporary tarsorrhaphy is indicated. Surgical treatments like nerve decompression are done only when the medical management fails.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following would you not expect to see in a patient with Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome?
explanation: Cleft palate is not seen in a patient with Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome. Melkersson-Rosenthal Syndrome is an idiopathic disorder consisting of a triad of: Facial paralysis Swelling of lips and Fissured tongue. The following image shows a patient with Melkersson-Rosenthal syndrome.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient with the following findings in the image comes to the OPD. What is the most likely causative agent for this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Ramsay-Hunt syndrome and it is caused by the Herpes zoster virus. The image shows right-sided LMN facial paralysis along with vesicular rash in the external auditory canal and pinna which is a classical presentation of this syndrome.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 30-year-old woman presented with left-sided facial weakness. On examination, she has vesicles in the external auditory canal and over the tympanic membrane. Which of the following is false about this condition?
options: 8th cranial nerve may also be involved
Surgery is the mainstay of treatment
explanation: The given clinical scenario with facial nerve palsy and vesicles in the external auditory canal is suggestive of Ramsay-Hunt syndrome (Herpes Zoster oticus). Surgery is not the mainstay of treatment. Steroids and antivirals are the mainstays of treatment. There may also be anesthesia of the face, giddiness, and hearing impairment due to the involvement of the 5th and 8th cranial nerves.
subject: ENT

question_text: An anxious woman presents to you with complaints of watering of the right eye while eating. She gives a history of transient facial weakness a few months back. Which of the following is the most likely cause for this condition?
options: Faulty regeneration of facial nerve fibres
Faulty regeneration of trigeminal nerve fibres
Faulty regeneration of vagal nerve fibres
Faulty regeneration of auriculotemporal nerve fibres
explanation: The given clinical scenario is crocodile tear syndrome or Bogard syndrome (gustatory lacrimation) and is due to faulty regeneration of facial nerve fibres. It presents as unilateral lacrimation during eating and drinking. It is seen in cases where the facial nerve is damaged proximal to the geniculate ganglion. During regeneration, the fibres supplying the salivary gland aberrantly supply the lacrimal gland. It can be treated by section of the greater superficial petrosal nerve.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 50-year-old woman presented with sweating over the right cheek while eating. She underwent parotid surgery 6 months back. The finding of the starch iodine test is shown in the image. Which of the following best explains the pathophysiology of this condition?
options: Aberrant reinnervation of parasympathetic fibres of auriculotemporal nerve with sympathetic sweat glands
Aberrant cross innervation of the facial nerve with greater auricular nerve
Aberrant reinnervation of sympathetic fibres of auriculotemporal nerve with parasympathetic sweat glands
Aberrant cross innervation of the facial nerve with auriculotemporal nerve
explanation: The given clinical scenario is Frey’s syndrome or gustatory sweating. It is due to aberrant reinnervation (or cross innervation) of parasympathetic fibers of the auriculotemporal nerve (which supplies parotid) with sympathetic sweat glands. The patient usually presents with sweating and flushing over the parotid area during mastication. This usually occurs after parotid surgery. It is diagnosed by Minor's test or starch iodine test. The affected area is painted with iodine and is allowed to dry. Then dry corn starch is applied. The starch turns blue on exposure to iodine in the presence of sweat.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is the most common cause of hemifacial spasm?
explanation: A vascular loop abutting the facial nerve at the cerebellopontine angle is the most common cause of hemifacial spasm. This usually presents as a unilateral involuntary uncontrollable twitching of the face. Treatment is microvascular decompression or removal of any other inciting cause like acoustic neuroma, congenital cholesteatoma, glomus tumor. In refractory cases, botulinum toxin and selective nerve sectioning are done.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which temporal bone fracture is most commonly associated with facial nerve palsy?
explanation: The transverse fracture of the petrous temporal bone is most commonly associated with facial nerve palsy.
subject: ENT

question_text: Following a blow to the head by a metal rod during a gang fight, a patient presented with clear watery discharge from the ear. The discharge is positive for beta-2 transferrin. Which of the following is the most likely cause for this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of CSF otorrhea and it is seen in longitudinal fracture of the petrous part of the temporal bone. The transverse fracture of petrous temporal bone and fracture of cribriform plate leads to CSF rhinorrhea.
subject: ENT

question_text:
You suspect a temporal bone fracture in a patient who presented with right side facial weakness, decreased hearing, vertigo, and bleeding from the ear. What is the investigation of
choice to confirm the diagnosis?
explanation: HRCT (High-resolution CT) is the investigation of choice for the temporal bone fractures complicated by facial nerve palsy or CSF leak.
subject: ENT

question_text:
An intern is assisting the surgeon in total parotidectomy. During the procedure, he accidentally injured the facial nerve. Which of the following cannot be used as a graft for repair in this case?
Sural nerve
explanation: The mandibular nerve cannot be used as a graft for facial nerve surgeries. Only those nerves whose functions can be sacrificed are chosen as grafts and these are usually sensory nerves. The most commonly used grafts for facial nerve are: Greater auricular nerve (can be extracted from the same incision) Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh Sural nerve (when a large segment is required). Eustachian Tube
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the length of the eustachian tube?
explanation: The length of the eustachian tube is 36 mm (Bony part: 12 mm and Cartilaginous part: 24 mm). It is directed forward, downward, and medially with an angle of 45° to the horizontal axis. Note: The eustachian tube in infants is 18 mm, i.e. about half the size of an adult eustachian tube.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is false regarding the eustachian tube?
options: Outer 1/3rd is bony and inner 2/3rd is cartilaginous
explanation: The eustachian tube also called the auditory or pharyngotympanic tube connects the nasopharynx with the tympanic cavity. It is 36 mm long in adults and is divided into two parts: Bony part - forms the outer one-third of the tube as it is located near the middle ear and is 12 mm in size. Fibrocartilaginous part - forms the inner two-third as it is located near the nasopharynx and is 24 mm in size. In the middle ear it opens in the anterior wall and in the nasopharynx it opens 1-1.25 cm posterior to the posterior end of the inferior turbinate.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is the narrowest part of the eustachian tube?
explanation: The narrowest part of the eustachian tube is the isthmus. It is the junction of the bony and cartilaginous parts. Infundibulum is not a part of eustachian tube.
subject: ENT

question_text: You are an intern asking a patient to perform a Valsalva manoeuvre for the relief of an ear block. Which of the following structure helps in opening the eustachian tube during this manoeuvre?
explanation: Tensor veli palatini helps in opening the Eustachian tube during the Valsalva manoeuvre. It is closed at rest and opens intermittently during swallowing, yawning and sneezing. Opening of the tube The medial fibres of the tensor veli palatini are attached to the lateral lamina of the tube and contract to open the tubal lumen. It is also called the dilator tubae muscle. Accessory muscles for opening are levator veli palatine & salpingopharyngeus Closure of the tube It is mainly due to the elastic recoil of the cartilage aided by the high degree of elastin on the roof. Ostmann’s pad of fat helps to keep the tube closed.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following supplies the tensor veli palatini muscle?
explanation: The mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve supplies the tensor veli palatini which opens the Eustachian tube. Muscles of the Eustachian tube: Sensory & parasympathetic supply to ET: Glossopharyngeal Nerve Muscle Nerve supply Action Tensor veli palatine/ Dilator t ubae Mandibular branch of trigem inal nerve Opens the tube ˜evator veli palatine Pharyngeal plexus Opens & lifts the tube Salpingopharyngeus Pharyngeal plexus Opens the tube
subject: ENT

question_text: A child presented with recurrent attacks of acute otitis media. Which of the following properties of the eustachian tube predisposes to this?
explanation: The Eustachian tube in children is wider, shorter (13-18mm), and more horizontal. The cartilaginous part is flaccid due to less elastin. The above differences make children more prone to retrograde reflux of nasopharyngeal secretions and middle ear infections. In infants along with the secretions, the milk also refluxes back while feeding in the supine position.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is a cause for functional eustachian tube obstruction?
explanation: Cleft palate is a cause for functional Eustachian tube (ET) obstruction. Eustachian tube obstruction can be mechanical, functional or both. Mechanical obstruction can result from intrinsic causes such as inflammation or allergy or extrinsic causes such as tumour or adenoids. Functional obstruction is caused by collapse of the tube due to increased cartilage compliance or failure of active tubal opening mechanism due to poor function of tensor veli palatini. In the cleft palate, the obstruction is due to high elastin content at torus tubaris and the poor function of tensor veli palatini.
subject: ENT

question_text: You are evaluating the patency and function of the Eustachian tube in a patient with a right earache and ear block. Which of the following test you will not do?
explanation: Stenger test is not used for the assessment of patency or function of the eustachian tube. It is used to detect malingering of hearing loss. Tests of Eustachian tube patency: Pneumatic otoscopy Nasopharyngoscopy Valsalva manoeuvre ET catheterizatio Politzer test. Tests of Eustachian tube function: Toynbee’s test Tympanometry Saccharine/dye tests in perforated ears Sonotubometry.
subject: ENT

question_text: An ENT resident is performing the following maneuver in a patient as shown in the image. Which of the following is false regarding the same?
options: It builds negative pressure in the nasopharynx
explanation: The given image depicts the Valsalva manoeuvre and it builds up positive pressure in the nasopharynx and not negative pressure. In this test, the patient is asked to close the mouth and nostrils and blow. This produces positive pressure within the nasopharynx which opens the patent eustachian tube and is confirmed by the tympanic membrane bulge via otoscopy. It is used to assess the Eustachian tube patency and to auto-inflate the middle ear. It is contraindicated in: Atrophic tympanic membrane as it might get ruptured. URTI as the infection can spread into the middle ear.
subject: ENT

question_text: An otolaryngologist is performing the following procedure in a patient. Which of the following is true about this procedure?
options: Used to instill medications into middle ear
explanation: The procedure depicted in the image is Eustachian tube (ET) catheterization and it uses Politzer’s bag and an ET catheter. The catheter is passed along the nasal floor and manoeuvred into the ET opening and the bag is insufflated. The outward movement of the tympanic membrane is then noted with an otoscope. It is an unsafe and outdated ET function test. It can lead to complications like TM rupture, scarring of ET, epistaxis, spread of nasal/pharyngeal infection to the middle ear. In the methylene blue dye test, the dye is instilled into the middle ear and the time taken by it to stain the pharynx is noted. Politzer test is a non-invasive alternative for this and works on the same principle. It uses a nasal olive instead of a catheter and is useful in children who can’t perform the Valsalva or Toynbee test.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 3-year-old child was brought to the OPD with fever, earache, and poor feeding after an episode of URTI. You suspect this as acute suppurative otitis media due to an eustachian tube defect. Which is the most accurate test to detect this?
explanation: Tympanometry is the most accurate test to assess eustachian tube (ET) dysfunction. It is an objective measure of ET function and does not rely on patient cooperation. In this test, the movement of TM is visualized to the variation in external canal pressure. The disadvantage is middle ear pathologies can overshadow ET function.
subject: ENT

question_text: A middle-aged retropositive woman presented with complaints of hearing her own voice and breath sounds with ear fullness. She has lost significant weight in the past 6 months. What is the likely diagnosis in this case?
explanation: The given clinical scenario describes autophony which is seen patulous eustachian tube. Autophony is a symptom where the patient hears his own voice and breath sounds. Patulous eustachian tube is usually idiopathic where the tube is abnormally patent. But it is also seen in rapid weight loss, pregnancy especially the third trimester and patients with multiple sclerosis. Treatment includes weight gain, administration of potassium iodide solution. In long-standing cases, specific treatment could include cauterization of tubes or insertion of the grommet. Option A: In HIV-related psychosis, there will be persecutory delusion, hallucination, and no ear fullness. Option B: The autophony of superior canal dehiscence syndrome usually involves hearing their own voice but not their breathing when compared with patients who have patulous eustachian tube. Option D: Patient with blocked eustachian tube does not present with autophony.
subject: ENT

question_text: For a patient to get barotraumatic otitis media, what is the critical level of the atmospheric pressure required?
explanation: The critical level of the atmospheric pressure required to cause barotraumatic otitis media is 90 mm Hg. At this point, the atmospheric pressure is higher than the middle ear and it causes the eustachian tube blockage.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following activities is least likely to cause otitic barotrauma?
explanation: A pilot performing take-off (i.e. rapid ascent in the air) is least likely to cause otitic barotrauma compared to other options. The usual causes for otitic barotrauma are Rapid descent during air travel (skydiver) Underwater diving (scuba diving) Compression in a pressure chamber (hyperbaric oxygen therapy).
subject: ENT

question_text:
Which of the following is not a feature of otitic barotrauma?
Conductive hearing loss
explanation: Hyperacusis is not a feature of otitic barotrauma. Otitic barotrauma is a non-suppurative condition resulting from the failure of the eustachian tube to maintain middle ear pressure at ambient atmospheric level. It is usually caused by rapid descent during air flight, underwater diving or compression in the pressure chamber. Severe earache, deafness, and tinnitus are common complaints. The TM appears retracted and congested. It can get ruptured in severe cases. The middle ear may show air bubbles or hemorrhagic effusion. Hearing loss is usually conductive. Rarely, there is a rupture of labyrinthine membranes causing vertigo and sensorineural hearing loss. Physiology of hearing and Tuning fork tests
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is not a function of the middle ear?
explanation: Transduction of sound (mechanical energy to electrical impulses) is done by the sensory system of the cochlea. It is not a function of the middle ear. The functions of the middle ear are: Conduction of sound through impedance matching or transformer action Protection of inner ear Amplification of sound intensity
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the lever ratio of the ear ossicles?
explanation: The lever ratio of the ear ossicles is 1.3:1. The handle of the malleus is 1.3 times longer than the long process of the incus, providing a mechanical advantage of 1.3.
subject: ENT

question_text: The effective vibratory area of the tympanic membrane is much larger than the area of stapes footplate. Which of the following is the most accurate value of the average ratio between the two?
explanation: The ratio of effective vibratory area of the tympanic membrane to the area of footplate of stapes (areal ratio) is 17:1 . Effective vibratory area of TM = 55 mm2 Footplate area = 3.2 mm2 Areal ratio = Effective vibratory area of tympanic membrane ÷ stapes footplate area
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the transformer ratio of the middle ear?
explanation: The transformer ratio of the middle ear is 22:1 The middle ear has to conduct sound waves from a low impedance tympanic membrane to a high impedance oval window. This is done by matching their impedances. It is called transforming action. Transformer ratio =Areal ratio × Lever ratio
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the natural resonance of the tympanic membrane?
explanation: The natural resonance of the tympanic membrane is 800 – 1600 Hz. Aging causes a decrease in the external ear resonance amplitude due to the collapse of the external auditory canal and the tympanic membrane becoming senile. This factor has to be considered to appropriately diagnose hearing loss and in the selection of hearing aids. Natural resonance and efficiency of auditory apparatus: External auditory canal- 3000 Hz Tympanic membrane- 800–1600 Hz Middle ear- 800 Hz Ossicular chain- 500–2000 Hz
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following factors do not contribute to the impedance matching mechanism of the middle ear?
options: Lever action of ossicles providing mechanical advantage of 1.3
Phase difference between the oval and round windows
Relatively large area of the tympanic membrane compared to stapes footplate
More movements at the centre of the tympanic membrane than at periphery
explanation: Movements of the tympanic membrane are more at the periphery than at the center, where the malleus handle is attached. This is called the curved membrane effect and it contributes to the impedance matching mechanism of the ear. Other factors responsible for the impedance matching mechanism of the middle ear are: The lever action of the ossicles- handle of malleus is 1.3 times longer than the long process of incus, providing a mechanical advantage of 1.3. Hydraulic action of the tympanic membrane- relatively large area of the tympanic membrane compared to the stapes footplate. The medial side of the tympanic membrane is multiphasic whereas the lateral side is uniphasic. This provides a multiple integrated multilever mechanical advantage.
subject: ENT

question_text: Who proposed the travelling wave theory of cochlear mechanics?
explanation: The traveling wave theory was proposed by von Békésy. It states that a sound wave, depending on its frequency, reaches maximum amplitude on a particular place on the basilar membrane and stimulates that segment. Higher frequencies are represented in the basal turn of the cochlea and the progressively lower ones towards the apex.
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the endocochlear potential recorded from the scala media?
explanation: Endocochlear potential is a direct current (DC) potential recorded from scala media. It is +80 mV and is generated from the stria vascularis by Na+/K+-ATPase pump and provides a source of energy for cochlear transduction. It is present at rest and does not require a sound stimulus.
subject: ENT

question_text: You are an intern performing the tuning fork tests on a patient who presented to the ENT OPD with complaints of decreased hearing in the left ear. Which of the following tuning forks is most commonly used for the routine clinical assessment for such patients?
explanation: A tuning fork of 512 Hz is most commonly used for routine clinical assessment in ENT. Tuning forks of lower frequencies produce a sense of bone vibration while those of higher frequencies have a shorter decay time and are thus not routinely preferred.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 45-year-old man presents to the ENT OPD with hearing loss in the right ear. A 512 Hz tuning fork is used, which highlights the Rinne test is positive bilaterally. What is the likely inference?
options: Air conduction is better than bone conduction
Bone conduction is better than air conduction
Air conduction is equal to bone conduction
Bone conduction is worse than that of examiner's
explanation: Rinne test is positive when the air conduction (AC) is longer or louder than bone conduction (BC).
subject: ENT

question_text: What should be the minimum hearing loss in a patient for the Rinne test to be negative?
explanation: The minimum hearing loss for the Rinne test to be negative is 15-20dB. Negative Rinne (BC > AC) is seen in conductive deafness.
subject: ENT

question_text: In a patient presenting with a conductive type of hearing loss, a negative Rinne test with a 512 Hz tuning fork indicates a minimum air-bone gap of?
explanation: The negative Rinne test for 512 Hz indicates a minimum air-bone gap of 30 dB. Rinne’s test is a tuning fork test performed commonly with tuning forks of frequencies such as 128, 256, 512, and 1024 Hz. Rinne’s test is done by placing a vibrating tuning fork on the patient’s mastoid and when he stops hearing, it is brought beside the external auditory meatus (EAC). If he still hears the sound, air conduction (AC) is better than bone conduction (BC) i.e. AC>BC. The inferences are as follows: Rinne's test is considered positive (normal) when the air conduction AC>BC is seen in norma people and people with sensorineural deafness. It is considered negative when the BC>AC, and is seen in patients with conductive deafness. As a general prediction, a negative Rinne's test with any tuning fork frequency suggests a minimum hearing loss of at least 15 - 20 dB.The table below indicates a rough minimum air-bone gap for negative Rinne's test at different frequencies: A prediction of the air-bone gap can be made based on the combination of tuning fork tests of 256, 512, and 1024 Hz: A Rinne test negative for 256 Hz but positive for 512 Hz indicates an air-bone gap of 20-30 dB. A Rinne test negative for 256 and 512 Hz but positive for 1024 Hz indicates an air-bone gap of 30-45 dB. A Rinne test negative for 256, 512, and 1024 Hz indicates an air-bone gap of 45-60 dB. Negative Rinne te st Minimum air-bone gap 256 Hz 15 dB 512 Hz 30 dB 1024 Hz 45 dB
subject: ENT

question_text: You are a first-year resident performing the tuning fork tests on the following patients to assess their hearing loss. Which one of them will you expect to have a positive Rinne test?
options: A child with chronic suppurative otitis media
An adolescent man with impacted wax
explanation: A positive Rinne test is seen in presbycusis, which is a type of sensorineural deafness. A positive Rinne test indicates that air conduction is longer than bone conduction, as seen in normal ear and sensorineural deafness. A negative Rinne test indicates that bone conduction is longer than air conduction, as seen in conditions causing in conductive deafness such as chronic suppurative otitis media, impacted wax, and otosclerosis.
subject: ENT

question_text: A middle-aged man diagnosed with Ménière's disease presented with severe unilateral hearing loss. Which of the following would be the most likely finding on performing the Rinne test on this patient?
explanation: Patients diagnosed with Ménière's disease present with a sensorineural type of hearing loss. A false negative Rinne test is seen in severe unilateral sensorineural hearing loss. The patient doesn’t respond to air conduction but is able to hear when a tuning fork is placed over the mastoid process i.e. bone conduction > air conduction. Hence reported as negative. This is a false negative because this response to bone conduction is from the opposite ear due to transcranial transmission of sound.
subject: ENT

question_text: A young lady presented to the ENT OPD with a history of sudden onset unilateral hearing loss, tinnitus, and dizziness following an episode of acute otitis media two weeks back. Rinne test and fistula test were positive. She had refused treatment then and currently came with complaints of worsened hearing loss in the affected ear. On examination, the fistula test was negative. What would be the most likely finding on the Rinne test in this scenario?
explanation: The given clinical scenario indicates severe sensorineural hearing loss as a consequence of untreated suppurative labyrinthitis and Rinne's test is a false negative in this case. Initially, the patient had a positive fistula test, which implies that the labyrinth is still functioning. Rinne's test is positive which could be due to normal hearing or sensorineural hearing loss. Currently, the patient has a negative fistula test which implies that the labyrinth is dead. This is an example of severe sensorineural hearing loss and here, Rinne test is a false negative. If intermittent pressure applied to the external ear produces vertigo and nystagmus, it is a positive fistula test. The pressure changes in the external ear are transmitted to the labyrinth. This is suggestive of abnormal communication between the middle ear and the inner ear.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is false about the test being performed on a patient by an ENT resident as shown below?
options: It is lateralized to worse ear in superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome
It is heard equally on both sides in normal individua
It is lateralized towards better ear in cochlear otosclerosis
It is lateralized towards worse ear in Ménière’s disease
explanation: The image shows the Weber test being performed. Ménière’s disease causes sensorineural hearing loss and hence Weber test is lateralized towards the better ear. In Weber's test, a vibrating tuning fork is placed in the middle of the forehead or the vertex and the patient is asked in which ear the sound is heard. It is lateralized to the worse ear in conductive deafness and to the better ear in sensorineural deafness. Option A: Superior semicircular canal dehiscence syndrome causes conductive hearing loss. Thus, Weber is lateralized to the worse ear. Option B: In normal individuals, the sound is heard equally in both ears. So Weber is not lateralized. Option C: Cochlear otosclerosis causes sensorineural deafness, whereas stapedial otosclerosis causes conductive hearing loss. Thus, Weber is lateralized to the better ear in case of cochlear otosclerosis.
subject: ENT

question_text: A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the mastoid while the examiner alternately closes and opens the ear canal of the patient by pressing the tragus inwards to examine the effect of occlusion on hearing. What is the test being performed here?
explanation: Bing test is being performed in the given clinical scenario. It is a test of bone conduction and examines the effect of occlusion of the ear canal on hearing. A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the mastoid. The examiner alternately closes and opens the ear canal by pressing the tragus inwards. Bing positive: A normal person or one with sensorineural hearing loss hears louder when the ear canal is occluded and softer when the canal is open. Bing negative: A patient with conductive hearing loss will appreciate no change.
subject: ENT

question_text: A young female diagnosed with otosclerosis presented to the ENT OPD with worsening hearing loss. Which of the following will be the most likely observation on the Bing test?
options: Hears louder when canal is occluded
Hears softer when canal is occluded
The test is said to be positive
explanation: The patient diagnosed with otosclerosis will have a conductive type of hearing loss and will appreciate no change in the Bing test. Here, the Bing test is said to be negative. Bing test is a test of bone conduction and examines the effect of occlusion of the ear canal on hearing. A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the mastoid. The examiner alternately closes and opens the ear canal by pressing on the tragus inwards. Bing positive: A normal person or one with sensorineural hearing loss hears louder when the ear canal is occluded and softer when the canal is open. Bing negative: A patient with conductive hearing loss will appreciate no change.
subject: ENT

question_text: In which of the following diseases would you find a negative Gelle's test?
explanation: Gelle’s test is negative in otosclerosis. It is based on the fact that in a normal ear if pressure is increased in the external ear the stapes footplate will get medialized and will stop conducting sound (positive Gelle's test). But, in an ear with otosclerosis of the footplate, there will be no movements and the patient will continue to hear the sound (negative Gelle's test). It was once a popular test to find out stapes fixation in otosclerosis but has now been superseded by tympanometry.
subject: ENT

question_text: A second-year resident performs the tuning fork tests on a patient with hearing loss. The Rinne test is positive in both ears and Weber is lateralized towards the right. What is the interpretation?
explanation: The patient has left-sided sensorineural deafness. Weber's test lateralized towards the right indicates right-sided conductive deafness or left-sided sensorineural deafness. Since Rinne's test is positive on both the ears, conductive deafness can be ruled out and hence, the interpretation here is left-sided sensorineural hearing loss.
subject: ENT

question_text:
A metal factory worker suffers from noise-induced hearing loss. Which of the following structures will be affected?
Crista ampullaris
explanation: Noise-induced hearing loss (NIHL) damages the outer hair cells, starting in the basal turn of the cochlea. Outer hair cells are affected before the inner hair cells. NIHL occurs after chronic exposure to less intense sounds. The damage caused by noise trauma depends on the frequency of noise (frequency of 2000 to 3000 Hz causes more damage) intensity, duration of the noise, and preexisting ear disease. The audiogram in noise-induced hearing loss shows a typical notch at 4000Hz both for air and bone conduction known as acoustic dip/boiler's notch. Patients at this stage complain of high-pitched tinnitus and difficulty hearing in noisy surroundings. Pre-employment and annual audiograms for persons working at places where noise is above 85 dB (A) help in the early detection of NIHL. The human ear can hear frequencies from about 20 to 20,000 Hz. Below 20 Hz, the vibrations are infra-audible, and above 20,000 Hz, they are ultra-sonic. Pure tone audiometry can detect only up to 8000 Hz. Extended high-frequency audiometry is recommended for early detection of hearing loss, as it can identify hearing impairments before the frequencies necessary for speech comprehension are affected. Distortion product otoacoustic emissions is a more sensitive tool than conventional audiometry, particularly in children under 5 years old for early detection of hearing loss. A noise of ˜0 dB(A) SPL (acceptable noise levels, sound pressure level), 8 hours a day for 5 days per week is the maximum safe limit as recommended by the Ministry of Labour. As per WHO, 85 dB(A) is considered the highest safe exposure level up to a maximum of 8 hours. The silence zone extends to a distance of 100 meters around the premises of hospitals, nursing homes, educational institutions, and courts. Permissible limits of noise as per the noise pollution (Regulation and Control) rules: Noise levels are measured in dB(A), which prioritizes middle-range frequencies for assessing noise-induced hearing loss while giving less weightage to low and high frequencies. The image below shows an acoustic dip at 4000Hz: ™one/Are a Day(6 am to 10 pm) limits in dB(A) Night(10 pm to 6 am) limits i n dB(A) Industria 75 70 Commerc ia 65 55 Residenti al 55 45 Silence 50 40 Other options: Option A: Crista ampullaris is a thickened ridge of neuroepithelium in the ampullated end of semicircular ducts. Option B: Macula is the sensory epithelium of the utricle Option C: Cupula is a gelatinous mass extending from the surface of the crista (peripheral receptor located in the ampullated end of semicircular ducts) to the ceiling of the ampulla, into which project the cilia of sensory hair cells. Audiometric tests and Special tests of hearing
subject: ENT

question_text: The audiogram of a patient with difficulty in hearing is given below. What is your interpretation?
explanation: The patient has left-sided conductive hearing loss. Interpretation of the above audiogram: Blue color indicates left ear. ] indicates BC and threshold is <25dB. BC is normal which means the sensorineural pathway is normal. × indicates AC and threshold is >15 dB and hence AC is abnormal. So, it indicates conductive deafness. The air-bone gap is a feature of conductive hearing loss. Hence, the chart is suggestive of left-sided conductive deafness.
subject: ENT

question_text: A middle-aged woman presents to the ENT OPD with complaints of difficulty in hearing. A pure tone audiometry test is performed and the result is given below. What is the interpretation?
explanation: The given pure tone audiometry is suggestive of right-sided sensorineural deafness. Interpretation of the result: Red indicates the right ear. O indicates air conduction(AC). The threshold here is >15 dB indicating abnormal AC. < indicates bone conduction(BC). The threshold is >25 dB indicating abnormal BC. Both AC and BC are abnormal which indicates a sensorineural hearing loss. There is no air-bone gap. Hence, it is right side sensorineural hearing loss.
subject: ENT

question_text: The audiogram of a patient who presented with a gradually progressive hearing loss is given below. Which among the following would be the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given audiogram is seen in Ménière's disease in its early stages. It shows an upsloping/ascending curve suggesting that the lower frequencies are affected first. Presbycusis, ototoxicity, and sound-induced hearing loss have downsloping audiograms since the higher frequencies are affected first in these conditions.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 25-year-old woman presented with hearing loss that developed shortly after her first pregnancy. Her audiometry report is given below. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: The clinical scenario describes a patient with post-pregnancy hearing loss. The audiogram shows conductive deafness along with Carhart's notch (dip in bone conduction at 2000 Hz). These findings are highly suggestive of otosclerosis. Ototoxicity, Meniere’s disease, and noise-induced hearing loss cause sensory neural hearing loss (SNHL) and not conductive hearing loss. Otosclerosis is caused by bony overgrowth involving the enchondral layer of the bony otic capsule. It presents with bilateral progressive conductive hearing loss and tinnitus. It has an autosomal dominant inheritance and can worsen with stress and hormonal changes like during pregnancy and menopause. Stapedial otosclerosis is the most common type of otosclerosis. Here the lesion starts just in front of the oval window in an area called fistula ante fenestrae. The presence of a reddish hue on the promontory through the tympanic membrane, known as the Schwartze sign, suggests an active focus. PTA shows loss of air conduction with air-bone gap, more for lower frequencies and Carhart's notch may be seen. Tympanometry shows an As type of tympanogram in which there is reduced compliance at or near the ambient air pressure. Medical management with sodium fluoride is used in the active stage. Definitive treatment is stapedectomy/stapedotomy with the placement of a prosthesis. Carhart notch usually disappears after a successful stapedectomy. Other options: Option A: Ototoxicity causes SNHL and shows a high-frequency hearing loss in the SNHL curve. Option B: In Meniere's disease, pure tone audiometry shows an SNHL pattern with a rising curve in the early stages (as lower frequencies are involved first) and as the disease progresses higher frequencies are involved, the curve becomes flat or a falling type. Option D: Noise-induced hearing loss is SNHL and PTA shows a characteristic acoustic dip at 4000 Hz both for air and bone conduction.
subject: ENT

question_text: A prisoner who was brought to the hospital with deafness after a brawl with another inmate is suspected of malingering. Which of the following tests can be used to assess the authenticity of his complaints?
explanation: Impedance audiometry can be used to test malingering. It is an objective test and consists of tympanometry and acoustic reflex measurements. A person who feigns total deafness and does not give any response on pure tone audiometry but shows a positive acoustic reflex is a malingerer.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient with hearing loss is being evaluated with the following instrument. What is the frequency of the probe used?
explanation: The given image shows impedance audiometry and the frequency of the probe used here is 220 Hz. Impedance audiometry consists of tympanometry and acoustic reflex measurements. Tympanometry equipment consists of a probe that snugly fits into the external auditory canal and has three channels. To deliver a tone of 220Hz To absorb reflected sound To change the pressure in EAC
subject: ENT

question_text: The tympanogram of a young patient who presented with a progressive hearing loss is given below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The tympanogram shows As type of curve suggestive of otosclerosis. It indicates that pressure is normal but compliance is reduced.
subject: ENT

question_text: Using impedance audiometry, stapedial reflexes are being assessed in a child with cranial nerve palsy. Which of the following cranial nerves is being tested here?
explanation: The 7th and 8th cranial nerves are being tested in a child by assessing the stapedial reflexes. The afferent of stapedial reflex is the 8th cranial nerve and efferent is the 7th cranial nerve.
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the instrument shown below?
explanation: The instrument shown is Barany’s noise box which is used to mask non-test ear while testing bone conduction.
subject: ENT

question_text: A woman is brought by her son to the ENT OPD due to hearing problems. He says that she always requests him to speak loud and whenever he speaks slightly louder, she tells him to stop shouting. Which of the following is the likely cause for this patient's condition?
explanation: The given symptom is indicative of a recruitment phenomenon and is seen in cochlear hearing loss (e.g. Ménière’s disease and presbycusis). It refers to abnormal growth of loudness. It is tested by ABLB (Alternate Binaural Loudness Balance) test. Lesser intensity sounds are heard louder in the normal ear. However, a greater intensity sound is heard equally, or even better in the abnormal ear. This is referred to as abnormal growth of loudness. However, in the conductive hearing loss, a constant difference of intensity is maintained throughout.
subject: ENT

question_text: Patient with hearing loss undergoes speech audiometry whose report is given below. What is it suggestive of?
explanation: The given speech audiometry shows roll-over phenomenon suggestive of retrocochlear hearing loss. With an increase in speech intensity above a particular level, the speech discrimination score falls rather than maintaining a plateau as seen in the cochlear type of sensorineural hearing loss.
subject: ENT

question_text: A middle-aged woman presents to you with a progressive hearing loss accompanied by tinnitus. An MRI of the patient with gadolinium contrast is given below. Which of the following results is consistent with the diagnosis?
options: <25 dB decay in threshold tone decay test
explanation: The given clinical scenario and the MRI are suggestive of vestibular schwannoma which is a retrocochlear disease. The presence of otoacoustic emissions is a feature consistent with the diagnosis. Vestibular schwannoma typically presents at 40-60 years of age. Progressive unilateral sensorineural hearing loss, often accompanied by tinnitus, is the presenting symptom in the majority of cases. The MRI shows left cerebellopontine angle mass causing widening of the porous acousticus. The mass is seen extending into intracanalicular portion of the internal acoustic meatus which is suggestive of vestibular schwannoma.
subject: ENT

question_text: What does summating potential in electrocochleography indicate?
options: Electrical activity of distal part of auditory nerve
explanation: Summating potential in electrocochleography indicates the sum of electrical activity in hair cells within the organ of Corti. Electrocochleography (ECoG) is an objective test which records the electrical activity of the cochlea and 8th nerve in response to auditory stimuli. The recording electrode is passed through the tympanic membrane to rest over the promontory. The three parameters measured in ECoG are: Cochlear microphonics – measures the electrical activity that follows the stimulus and reflects the instantaneous displacement of the basilar membrane. Summating potential (SP) – measures the electrical activity of the hair cells within the organ of Corti. Action potential (AP) – electrical activity in the distal part of the auditory nerve. Normal SP: AP ratio is <30% but it is increased in Meniere’s disease.
subject: ENT

question_text: A preterm neonate with an Apgar score of 4 at 5 minutes of birth undergoes otoacoustic emission study. Which of the following is false about this test?
options: Otoacoustic emissions are generated by inner hair cells
It is used as a screening test for hearing loss in infants
Spontaneous type is present in 50% of normal individuals
Evoked type is present in all individuals with normal hearin
explanation: The otoacoustic emissions (OAEs) are generated by the outer hair cells of the cochlea. Presence of otoacoustic emissions is used to test hearing in a high-risk neonate as given in the clinical scenario.
subject: ENT

question_text: Wave V in brainstem evoked response audiometry is produced by which of the following structures?
explanation: Wave V in BERA is produced by lateral lemniscus. The generators of ABEPs (Auditory nerve and brainstem evoked potentials) have been the subject of much research and controversy and are still not entirely agreed upon. The literature available to us states the following: Scott Brown's Otorhinolaryngology- wave IV–V complex probably arises from neural activity within the superior olivary complex and nuclei of the lateral lemniscus, possibly some contribution from the inferior colliculus. So lateral lemniscus is the better option. Current Diagnosis and Treatment in Otorhinolaryngology- auditory brainstem response waves 2, 3, 4, and 5 represent the sequential activation of neurons as the signal is passed up the brainstem from the proximal part of the cochlear nerve, cochlear nucleus, superior olivary complex, and lateral lemniscus. NIH Journals- generation of wave V reflects the activity of multiple anatomic auditory structures. A sharp positive peak of wave V arises mainly from the lateral lemniscus, following a slow negative wave represents dendritic potential in the inferior colliculus.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient undergoes hearing assessment using cortical evoked response audiometry. Which of the following is false regarding this test?
options: Recording is made from cortical potentials
explanation: In CERA or cortical evoked response audiometry, a tone stimulus is used instead of a click stimulus. It is an objective hearing test, that records the signals from the auditory cortex (part of the brain that recognizes sound) that have been generated in response to sounds introduced to the ears. The test gives information about the level of sound needed to produce a signal and confirms the status of the auditory cortex. This is valuable information that we can not obtain from a normal hearing test. Difference between BERA and CERA: BERA CERA The recording is made from brain stem potentials The recording is made from c ortical potentials Click stimulus is used Tone stimulus is used Responses are not frequency specific Responses are frequency spe cific Can be performed in awake a nd restless patients The patient must lie still thro ughout the process Responses begin after 1 -10 milliseconds after stimuli Responses begin after 50 – 3 00 milliseconds after stimula tion Suitable for even younger chi ldren Unsuitable for children
subject: ENT

question_text: As a medical officer in an occupational health program, you encounter an employee with hearing loss. You are suspicious that he is faking it to claim compensation. Which of the following tests is least useful in this scenario?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of malingering and Rinne's test is least useful here. Tests for malingering or nonorganic hearing loss: Stenger test Lombard test Stapedial reflex Inconsistent results on repeat pure tone and speech audiometry tests BERA
subject: ENT

question_text: While performing a caloric test, what type of nystagmus would you expect on cold water irrigation?
options: Horizontal nystagmus towards the same side
Vertical nystagmus towards the same side
Horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side
Vertical nystagmus towards the opposite side
explanation: In caloric testing, cold water irrigation produces horizontal nystagmus towards the opposite side of irrigation. The direction of nystagmus can be remembered by the mnemonic, COWS (cold–opposite, warm–same). The mechanism for the nystagmus is the creation of a temperature gradient by the cold water, which pulls the cupula away from the utricle, causing nystagmus towards the oppsite side. As the horizontal semicircular canal is closer to the outer ear canal, most of the response comes from it and the nystagmus is horizontal. The Fitzgerald–Hallpike test (bithermal caloric test) is done to assess this phenomenon. The patient lies in a supine position with head tilted forward at a 30° angle, ensuring the horizontal canal becomes vertical. Alternatingly, water at temperatures of 30°C and 44°C (7° below and above normal body temperature, respectively) is irrigated into the ears for a duration of 40 seconds each. The examiner closely observes the patient's eyes for the emergence of nystagmus until its endpoint is reached. The time taken from the start of irrigation to the endpoint of nystagmus is recorded and plotted on a calorigram. If no nystagmus is evoked from either ear, the test is repeated with water at a temperature of 20°C for a duration of 4 minutes before labeling the labyrinth dead. A 5-minute interval should be allowed between testing each ear to ensure accurate results.
subject: ENT

question_text:
Which of the following are the objective tests for the hearing?
1, 2, and 4
explanation: BERA, OAE, and tympanometry are the objective tests for hearing. PTA (pure tone audiometry) is a subjective test for hearing as it relies on patient responses to pure tone stimuli. Other examples of subjective tests include tuning fork tests and speech audiometry. Tympanometry is an objective test of the middle ear and eustachian tube functions (conductive compartment of hearing). Here, the compliance of the TM, i.e., how much it moves to the pressure differentials applied from the external ear is measured. The image below shows the types of tympanogram: Anatomy of Nose
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is correct about the framework of the external nose?
options: Upper ½ is bony and lower ½ is cartilaginous
Upper 2/3rd is bony and lower 1/3rd is cartilaginous
explanation: Upper 1/3rd of the external nose is bony, whereas lower 2/3rd is cartilaginous.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is true about the cartilaginous part of the external nose?
explanation: The external nose is made up of 3 paired and 1 unpaired cartilages. Paired cartilages: Upper lateral cartilage - From nasal bone above to alar cartilage below. Lower lateral (alar) cartilage - U-shaped. Lateral crus forms the ala and medial crus runs in the columella. Limen nasi or limen vestibuli is the junction of the upper and lower lateral cartilages. Lesser alar (sesamoid) cartilage - multiple, above, and lateral to the alar cartilage. The septal cartilage is the only unpaired cartilage.
