It forms the midline of the lower 2/3rd of the dorsum of nose and supports lower 2/3rd of the dorsum of external nose.
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the shape of the septal cartilage?
explanation: Septal cartilage is a quadrilateral cartilage.
subject: ENT

question_text: A boxer suffered a blow to the nose. You suspect a fracture of his external nasal bones. Which of the following will you not expect to contribute to the fracture?
explanation: Sphenoid bone does not contribute to the bony part of the external nose. The bony part of the external nose consists of Two nasal bones Frontal process of maxilla lateral to nasal bones on each side. Nasal process of frontal bone in the midline between 2 nasal bones. Nasion is the site of the junction of nasal bone with the nasal process of the frontal bone.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following structures does not contribute to the formation of the nasal septum?
explanation: Perpendicular plate of sphenoid does not contribute to the formation of the nasal septum.
subject: ENT

question_text: What are the choanae also known as?
explanation: The choanae are also known as posterior nares. Each nasal cavity communicates with the exterior through the anterior nares or nostril and with the nasopharynx through the posterior nares, posterior nasal aperture or the choanae. Limen nasi or the nasal valve is the upper limit of nasal vestibule on the lateral wall. It demarcates the skin-lined vestibule with the mucosa-lined nasal cavity proper. Agger nasi is an elevation just anterior to the attachment of middle turbinate.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient presents with nasal congestion and the following test is performed. Which of the following does not contribute to the boundaries of the involved structure?
explanation: The given image shows Cottle's test being performed and the structure involved is the nasal valve. Middle turbinate does not contribute to the boundaries of the nasal valve. In Cottle's test, the cheek of the patient is drawn laterally during quiet breathing. If this improves the airway on the test side, the test is considered to be positive. This suggests an abnormality of the vestibular component of the nasal valve causing nasal obstruction.
subject: ENT

question_text: Given below is the endoscopic view of the right nasal cavity. Identify the marked structure?
explanation: The marked structure is the lowermost projection in the lateral wall of the nose, the inferior turbinate. The middle turbinate (Option B) is seen as superior to it. The lateral wall of the nose contains three or sometimes four projections of variable size namely superior, middle, and inferior turbinates along with a corresponding meatus under each turbinate. The inferior turbinate is the largest turbinate and occupies the lower third of the lateral nasal wall. It is a separate bone. Middle and superior turbinates (Option C) are ethmoturbinal, part of the ethmoid bone. Other important structures which could be seen in the above image are: IT: Inferior turbinate S: Septum, MT: middle turbinate Uncinate process (Option D) is a hook-like structure running parallel to the anterior border of bulla ethmoidalis. The posteroinferior end of the uncinate process is attached to the inferior turbinate. The image below shows a CT image of the uncinate process.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following articulates with the maxilla?
explanation: The inferior turbinate articulates with the nasal surface of the maxilla and the perpendicular plate of the palatine bone. The superior, middle, and supreme turbinates are present in the labyrinth of the ethmoid bone. The image given below shows the nasal cavity, inferior turbinate and opening of maxillary sinus.
subject: ENT

question_text: A middle-aged woman was admitted with complaints of longstanding breathing difficulties and headaches. On evaluation, a deviated nasal septum was noted. CT image is given below. Which of the following structures is involved in this case?
explanation: The given clinical scenario and CT findings are suggestive of concha bullosa. It is the pneumatization of the middle turbinate and is one of the anatomic variations of the paranasal region. Concha bullosa can be either unilateral or bilateral and generally occurs together with a septal deviation to the contralateral side. In the image given below, the star-marked area is the enlarged, ballooned out middle turbinate called concha bullosa.
subject: ENT

question_text: In a patient with refractory posterior epistaxis, a transnasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation is planned. During the operation, the surgeon asks you to clip the artery at the sphenopalatine foramen. Where will you locate the site of ligation?
explanation: Transnasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation (TESPAL) is done to control refractory posterior epistaxis by ligating the sphenopalatine artery. It emerges from the sphenopalatine foramen which is situated at the posterior end of the middle turbinate. Branches of sphenopalatine ganglion also emerge from the sphenopalatine foramen. It supplies most of the posterior 2/3rd of the nasal cavity. It can be anaesthetized by placing a pledget of cotton soaked in anaesthetic solution at the foramen. The sphenopalatine foramen is also the most common site for the origin of angiofibroma.
subject: ENT

question_text: Where is hiatus semilunaris present?
explanation: Hiatus semilunaris is present in the middle meatus. It is a two-dimensional space bounded by bulla ethmoidalis above and uncinate process below. It opens into a three-dimensional area called infundibulum bounded by uncinate process, frontal process of maxilla medially, and lamina papyracea laterally. The maxillary sinus opens into lower part of infundibulum. The image given below shows the opening of maxillary sinus
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following sinuses does not open into the middle meatus?
explanation: The posterior ethmoidal sinus does not open into the middle meatus. It opens into the superior meatus. Frontal, maxillary, and anterior ethmoidal sinuses open into middle meatus.
subject: ENT

question_text: Where is the ethmoidal bulla present?
explanation: Ethmoidal bulla (Bulla ethmoidalis) is an ethmoidal cell situated behind the uncinate process. It forms the posterior boundary of the hiatus semilunaris.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 10-month-old child presents with congenital dacryocystitis and requires probing of the nasolacrimal duct to relieve the obstruction. Where will the probe emerge in the nasal cavity?
explanation: The probe emerges in the inferior meatus because the opening of the nasolacrimal duct is present in the inferior meatus. The nasolacrimal duct runs downwards, backward, and laterally from the lacrimal sac and opens into the inferior meatus. It is bounded by a mucosal valve called the valve of Hasner in the inferior meatus. Note: In congenital dacryocystitis, probing of the nasolacrimal duct is done at 9-12 months of age if symptoms persist past 6 months of age and aren't relieved by local massage and topical antibiotics.
subject: ENT

question_text: While performing diagnostic nasal endoscopy, which of the following structures would you not see during the third pass?
explanation: The third pass in diagnostic nasal endoscopy involves the examination of the middle meatus in detail. The nasolacrimal duct opens into the inferior meatus, hence it will not be visualized here. Option A: Agger nasi is an elevation just anterior to the attachment of the middle turbinate. When pneumatised and enlarged it encroaches on the frontal recess area and causes mechanical obstruction to drainage of the frontal sinus leading to sinusitis. Option B: Atrium of the middle meatus is a shallow depression lying in front of the middle turbinate and above the nasal vestibule. Option C: Fronto-nasal duct/frontal recess is the opening of the frontal sinus into the infundibulum. Note: In diagnostic nasal endoscopy three passes are performed - First pass is the examination of the nasopharynx and inferior meatus. Second pass is the examination of sphenoethmoidal recess, superior meatus, and openings of sphenoid sinus and posterior ethmoidal cells. Third pass is the examination of the middle meatus in detail.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following statements is false about the olfactory area of the nose?
options: The olfactory area is known as the dangerous area of the nose
Bounded laterally by superior turbinate, medially by corresponding part of septum, above by cribriform plate of ethmoid bone
Trauma can lead to spread of infection intracranially and can cause CSF rhinorrhea
The olfactory area is very well ventilated and it aids in olfaction
explanation: The olfactory area is not well ventilated, and very little air passes through the olfactory region during quiet inspiration. Weak odors need to be sniffed, due to the same. The upper 1/3rd of the nasal cavity forms the olfactory area which is also known as the dangerous area of the nose. Olfactory nerve fibers pass through the cribriform plate of the ethmoid. Spread of infection to the intracranial space can occur through this route. Trauma to the cribriform plate can lead to CSF rhinorrhea. It is bounded by the following structures: Laterally by superior turbinate Medially by corresponding part of the septum Superiorly by cribriform plate of the ethmoid It is lined by olfactory epithelium. Note: The danger triangle of the face consists of the area from the corners of the mouth to the bridge of the nose. This is because retrograde infection from these areas can spread to the brain, through the venous communication (via the ophthalmic veins) between the facial vein and the cavernous sinus.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 32-year-old woman presented with nasal obstruction and rhinorrhea refractory to medical treatment. On examination, turbinates were hypertrophied. She was scheduled for vidian neurectomy. Which of the following statements is incorrect about the nerve supply of the region?
options: Parasympathetic supply is from greater superficial petrosal nerve
Sympathetic supply is by upper two thoracic segments of spinal cord
Parasympathetic stimulation causes vasodilatation and sympathetic stimulation causes vasoconstriction
Sympathetic fibres of the nerve of pterygoid canal relay in the sphenopalatine ganglion
explanation: The given case scenario with rhinorrhea, nasal obstruction, and turbinate hypertrophy is suggestive of vasomotor rhinitis (VMR). Vidian neurectomy is the treatment of choice in VMR refractory to medical treatment. The autonomic nerve supply of the nose is unstable in cases of VMR. Sympathetic fibres of the nerve of the pterygoid canal do not relay in the sphenopalatine ganglion. Parasympathetic supply Sympathetic supply Nerve fibres arise from Greater superficial petrosal n erve Upper two thoracic segments of spinal cord Course Travel in the nerve of pterygo id canal (Vidian nerve) to the sphenopalatine ganglion Superior cervical ganglion to deep petrosal nerve to parasy mpathetic fibres of greater pe trosal nerve - nerve of pteryg oid canal Parasympathetic supply Sympathetic supply Relay Relays in the sphenopalatine ganglion before reaching nas al cavity Doesn't relay in sphenopalati ne ganglion Function Vasodilation Vasoconstriction
subject: ENT

question_text:
At what site does the maxillary sinus open into the middle meatus?
Hiatus semilunaris
explanation: Maxillary sinus opens into middle meatus at the lower part of infundibulum, in its medial wall. Infundibulum is the space limited medially by the uncinate process and frontal process of maxilla, and laterally by the lamina papyracea. Anatomy of Paranasal Sinuses
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is not a paranasal sinus?
explanation: Pyriform sinus (fossa) is a part of hypopharynx. It lies on either side of the larynx and extends from pharyngoepiglottic fold to the upper end of oesophagus. Sinuses are air-containing cavities in certain bones of skull. It is divided into 2 groups. Anterior group includes Maxillary Fronta Anterior ethmoidal sinuses. Posterior group includes Posterior ethmoid Sphenoid sinuses.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which is the largest paranasal sinus?
explanation: Maxillary sinus is the largest of paranasal sinuses and occupies the body of maxilla.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is also known as antrum of Highmore?
explanation: Maxillary sinus is also known as antrum of Highmore.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following statements is correct about the maxillary sinus?
options: Pyramidal in shape with base towards lateral wall of nose and apex towards zygomatic arch
Pyramidal in shape with base towards zygomatic arch and apex towards lateral wall of nose.
explanation: Maxillary sinus is pyramidal in shape, with base towards lateral wall of nose and apex directed laterally into the zygomatic process of maxilla and sometimes in the zygomatic bone itself.
subject: ENT

question_text: A pathologist is examining the specimen of a maxillectomy. Which of the following epithelium do you expect to find lining the maxillary sinus?
explanation: Paranasal sinuses are lined by ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells which secrete mucus. They're lined by the mucous membrane, which is continuous with that of the nasal cavity through the ostia of sinuses.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is most superior in location?
explanation: Frontal sinus is the most superiorly located sinus. It is situated between the inner and outer tables of frontal bone, above and deep to the supraorbital margin.
subject: ENT

question_text: An anxious father brings his newborn baby to the pediatrician after dropping his baby when shifting from one arm to another. The pediatrician orders a CT head, which is normal. Which of the following structures would you not expect to find in the CT?
explanation: The frontal sinus is absent or rudimentary at birth. Radiologically, the frontal sinus is able to be identified at 6 years and reaches full size only after puberty. At birth, only the maxillary and ethmoidal sinuses are present and are large enough to be clinically significant. Sphenoid sinus, though may be present, is usually undeveloped and non-aerated. Sinuse s At birth First radiological evidence Reaches adult size b y Maxill ary Present 4-5 months after birth 15 years Ethmoi dal Present 1 year 12 years Frontal Absent/rudiment ary 6 years Post-puberty Sphen oid Present 4 years 14 years
subject: ENT

question_text: Where does the posterior ethmoidal sinus open?
explanation: The posterior ethmoidal sinus opens into the superior meatus.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is true about sphenoid sinus?
options: Present in greater wing of sphenoid
Lateral wall is related to the pituitary gland
explanation: Sphenoid sinus opens into sphenoethmoidal recess.
subject: ENT

question_text: You are an ENT resident performing endoscopic biopsy from the sphenoid sinus in a COVID patient with suspected mucormycosis. Through which of the following areas will you access the sinus?
explanation: The sphenoid sinus is accessed through the sphenoethmoidal recess which is situated above the superior turbinate. The ostium of the sphenoid sinus can be located endoscopically 1cm above the upper margin of the posterior choana near the posterior border of the septum.
subject: ENT

question_text: Optic nerve injury following sinus surgery (FESS) is due to removal of which of the following ethmoidal cells?
explanation: Onodi cell is the posterior ethmoidal cell, related superiorly or laterally to the sphenoid sinus. The optic nerve lies in its lateral wall and can be injured while operating in the cells. Option A: Haller cells are a type of ethmoidal cells that are situated on the roof of the maxillary sinus. Sometimes they may enlarge and block the opening of the maxillary sinus leading to maxillary sinusitis. Option B: Agger nasi is an elevation just anterior to the attachment of middle turbinates. Option D: Bulla ethmoidalis is the ethmoidal cell situated behind the uncinate process and forms the posterior boundary of hiatus semilunaris through which the maxillary, frontal and anterior ethmoidal sinuses drain.
subject: ENT

question_text: While performing functional endoscopic sinus surgery, the surgeon points out the Haller cells and their clinical significance. Which of the following is correct about these cells?
options: They are related to the maxillary sinus
They are related to the optic nerve
They are related to the sphenoid sinus
They are related to the facial nerve
explanation: Haller cells (infraorbital ethmoidal air cells) are a type of ethmoidal cells that are situated in the roof of the maxillary sinus. Sometimes they may enlarge and block the opening of the maxillary sinus leading to maxillary sinusitis. The star-marked area in the given CT scan shows the Haller cell
subject: ENT

question_text:
What is occipitomental view with open mouth also known as?
Water's view
explanation: Occipitomental view is called Water's view. Water's view with an open mouth is known as Pierre's view. Among the given options, Water's view is the best answer. In Water's view, the patient’s head is positioned such that the nose and the chin touch the film while the X-rays are projected from backward. The mouth is usually kept open, which allows visualizing the sphenoid sinus. Structures seen in Water’s view are: Maxillary sinuses (seen best) Frontal sinuses Sphenoid sinus (if the film is taken with an open mouth) Zygoma Zygomatic arch Nasal bone Frontal process of the maxilla Superior orbital fissure Infratemporal fossa Other options: Option B: Towne's view is an angled anteroposterior radiograph of the skull. Structures seen are the petrous part of the pyramids, arcuate eminence, superior semicircular canal, mastoid antrum, internal auditory canal, tympanic cavity, cochlea, and external auditory canal. This view is taken for acoustic neuroma and apical petrositis. Option C: Law's view is a lateral oblique X-ray view of the mastoid. Structures seen are the external auditory canal, mastoid air cells, tegmen, lateral sinus plate, and temporomandibular joint. Option D: Stenver's view is an X-ray view of the skull where the long axis of the petrous bone is parallel to the film. Structures seen are the entire petrous pyramid, arcuate eminence, internal auditory meatus, labyrinth with its vestibule, cochlea, and mastoid antrum. Physiology of Nose and Paranasal Sinuses
subject: ENT

question_text: During inspiration, through which part of the nasal cavity does the main current of airflow take place?
options: Upper part of nasal cavity in a parabolic curve
Middle part of nasal cavity in a parabolic curve
Lower part of nasal cavity in a parabolic curve
explanation: The main current of airflow in the nasal cavity flows through the middle part of nose between the turbinates and nasal septum. Very little air passes through the inferior meatus or olfactory region of nose.
subject: ENT

question_text: What percentage of total airflow through nose reaches the olfactory region?
explanation: About 15% of inspired air reaches the olfactory area within the nose, where it interacts with the mucus secreted by the Bowman’s glands in the lamina propria and respiratory epithelium.
subject: ENT

question_text: How frequently does the rhythmic congestion and decongestion of nasal mucosa occur?
explanation: Rhythmic cyclical congestion and decongestion of the nasal mucosa is called nasal cycle. It occurs every 2.5-4 hours and is usually characteristic of an individual.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following statements is false about nasal secretions?
options: pH of nasal secretions is around 7.
They increases in response to noxious stimuli.
Lactoferrin is not a component of nasal secretions.
explanation: Nasal secretions contain muramidase (lysozyme), Lactoferrin and immunoglobulins IgA and IgE, and interferon and thus have antibacterial properties. Their pH is around 7. Copious flow of nasal secretions that follows irritation by noxious substance helps to wash them out.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following causes movement of the mucus blanket of the nose?
explanation: The movement of the mucus blanket of the nose is by ciliary action. The mucus blanket consists of a superficial mucus layer and a deeper serous layer, floating on the top of cilia, which are constantly beating to carry it like a conveyer belt towards the nasopharynx. The mucus blanket moves at a speed of 5–10 mm/min and the complete sheet of mucus is cleared into the pharynx every 10–20 min. In mammals, cilia beat 10–20 times per second at room temperature.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following does not affect movements of the cilia?
explanation: Nasal valve does not affect the movements of the nasal cilia. Movements of cilia are affected by: Drying Drugs (adrenaline) Excessive heat or cold Smoking Infections Noxious fumes like sulfur dioxide and carbon dioxide
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient presents to you with bronchiectasis and chronic sinusitis. Chest X-Ray shows the following finding. Which of the following is the method of protection of the lower airway that's compromised in this patient?
explanation: The given clinical scenario of chronic sinusitis, bronchiectasis and the X-ray showing dextrocardia (situs inversus) is suggestive of Kartagener syndrome. The mucociliary mechanism is compromised in this case, due to immotile cilia. The lower airway is protected by the following mechanisms: Mucociliary mechanism - The inspired pathogens and dust are trapped on the viscous mucous blanket. By beating of the cilia, the mucus is carried to the nasopharynx to be swallowed. Chemical mechanisms - Immunoglobulins such as IgA, IgE, and Lactoferrin, lysozyme provide innate immunity. Sneezing - It is a protective reflex due to irritation of the nasal mucosa. Temperature regulation and humidification are due to the large surface area of mucosa and highly vascular cavernous spaces. This is achieved by an increase or decrease in blood flow which in turn increase or decrease the size of turbinates.
subject: ENT

question_text: As a first-year ENT resident, you receive a patient complaining of a complete lack of smell for the past week. Which of the following will not be part of your differential diagnosis?
explanation: Anosmia refers to a complete loss of the sense of smell. Allergic rhinitis is more commonly associated with hyposmia, hence it'll not be part of differential diagnosis. Anosmia only occurs in case it leads to nasal polyposis Causes of anosmia: Nasal obstruction due to nasal polyps, enlarged turbinates, or mucosal edema due to infections. Atrophic rhinitis, a degenerative disorder of nasal mucos Peripheral neuritis (toxic or influenzal) Injury to olfactory nerves or olfactory bulb in fractures of anterior cranial foss Intracranial lesions like abscesses, tumors, or meningitis, which cause pressure on olfactory tracts. COVID-19 is associated with a complete lack of taste and smell and is a common presenting symptom
subject: ENT

question_text: A 17-year-old girl was evaluated for delay in the onset of puberty. On further enquiry, she revealed that she has always had a very poor sense of smell. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario of delay in puberty along with an impaired sense of smell is suggestive of Kallmann syndrome. K llmann syndrome and familial causes like primary congenital anosmia are congenital causes of anosmia.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 32-year-old female patient was found to be positive for SARS-CoV-2 and had a loss of taste and smell. After regaining her ability to smell after 2 months, she reported to the OPD with the complaint that all the smells she perceived were distorted, similar to the smell of burnt rubber. What is this called?
explanation: Parosmia is the perversion of smell. It is seen classically in the recovery phase of postinfluenzal anosmia, and has been recently reported as a rare complication in post-COVID patients. The probable explanation is misdirected regeneration of nerve fibers. Intracranial tumors should be ruled out in all cases of parosmia. Option A: Anosmia is the complete lack of smell Option B: Phantosmia is the sensation of olfaction in the absence of a stimulus Option D: Olfactory agnosia is the inability to recognize an odour sensation
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following statements is true about ventilation of the nose and paranasal sinuses?
options: Paranasal sinuses are filled with air during inspiration
Paranasal sinuses are filled with air during expiration
During inspiration, positive pressure is created in the nose
During expiration, negative pressure is created in the nose
explanation: Paranasal sinuses are ventilated during expiration. Ventilation of sinuses is paradoxical, as they are emptied of air during inspiration and filled with air during expiration. During inspiration, negative pressure is created in the nose by the air current, whereas during expiration, positive pressure is created in the nose, and this sets up eddy currents, which ventilate the sinuses.
subject: ENT

question_text:
Which of the following is not a function of the paranasal sinuses?
Air conditioning of inspired air
explanation: Airway resistance is not a function of paranasal sinuses. Resistance to the flow of air in the nose maintains the positive pressure needed to keep the alveoli open. It is due to two factors: Bones, cartilages, and attached muscles - fixed Mucosa - variable Epistaxis
subject: ENT

question_text: A 15-year-old boy was brought to the ER with a nose bleed secondary to trauma. The bleeding started an hour ago and has not stopped. Where is the bleed most likely to be from?
explanation: The bleeding is most likely from the Little's area. Little’s area, situated at the anteroinferior part of the nasal septum is the most common site of epistaxis in children and young adults. Factors that increase the risk of epistaxis in children when compared to adults, include the habit of nose picking and increased friability of mucosa due to frequent upper respiratory tract infections.
subject: ENT

question_text: Where is Little’s area situated?
explanation: Little’s area is situated in the anterior inferior part of the nasal septum, just above the vestibule.
subject: ENT

question_text: A worried mother brought her 4-year-old son to the ER with complaints of a nose bleed. On examination, the bleed was found to be from the Kiesselbach’s plexus. Which of the following arteries does not contribute to its formation?
explanation: The posterior ethmoidal artery does not contribute to the formation of Kiesselbach’s plexus. Kiesselbach’s plexus is the vascular anastomosis situated at Little’s area (anteroinferior part of the septum). The contributing arteries are as follows: Sphenopalatine and greater palatine branches of the maxillary artery, which in turn is a branch of the external carotid artery. Septal branch of the superior labial artery which in turn is a branch of the facial artery. The facial artery is a branch of the external carotid artery. Anterior ethmoidal branch of the ophthalmic division of internal carotid artery.
subject: ENT

question_text: Identify the artery of epistaxis in the given image.
explanation: The structure marked 3 is the sphenopalatine artery which is also known as the artery of epistaxis. It is called the artery of epistaxis because the majority of the blood supply to the nasal cavity is derived from it. It is also the most commonly involved artery in epistaxis. Other structures marked in the diagram are as follows: - Anterior ethmoidal artery - Posterior ethmoidal artery 4 - Greater palatine artery
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following marked structures is a branch of the internal carotid artery?
explanation: The structure marked 1 is the anterior ethmoidal artery, which is a branch of the ophthalmic division of the internal carotid artery. Other structures marked in the diagram are as follows: – Sphenopalatine artery – Greater palatine artery – Superior labial artery 2, 3 and 4 are derived from branches of the external carotid artery. The nasal septum is supplied by branches of both internal and external carotid arteries.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 40-year-old male patient with a history of uncontrolled, chronic hypertension was rushed to the casualty after he had an episode of coughing out frank blood. On further evaluation, a diagnosis of posterior epistaxis, secondary to hypertension, was made. What is the site of the blood vessel most likely to be involved in this case?
explanation: The most common cause for posterior epistaxis is arterial and the vessel involved is the sphenopalatine artery. It is located in the posterior end of the middle turbinate. Woodruff's plexus is a venous plexus located in the posterior end of the inferior turbinate and is also sometimes implicated in epistaxis associated with systemic conditions such as hypertension and coagulopathy. However, it only accounts for about 5-10% of all nose bleeds. Note: Most common vessel involved in both anterior and posterior epistaxis is the sphenopalatine artery and not Woodruff's plexus.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is the most common cause of epistaxis in children?
explanation: Microtrauma due to nose pricking is the most common cause of epistaxis in children. Other common aetiological associations include upper respiratory tract infections. Note: In children presenting with recurrent epistaxis, bleeding disorders, hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia, and tumors, etc. have to be ruled out.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is the most common cause of epistaxis in elderly patients?
explanation: The most common cause of epistaxis in elderly patients is idiopthic. Other causes are: Trauma Coagulopathy Tumor - high suspicion in elderly patients presenting with epistaxis Infection Medication Note: Due to the failure of studies to establish a causal relationship between hypertension and epistaxis, hypertension is now considered an associated risk factor and not a cause. Risk factors associated with epistaxis are weather changes and alcohol consumption.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 4-year-old child presents with persistent unilateral foul-smelling nasal discharge which is blood-stained. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
explanation: In a child presenting with persistent unilateral, foul-smelling nasal discharge, which is blood-stained, the most likely cause is a foreign body. Foreign body can cause unilateral nasal obstruction and subsequent superimposed infection which causes malodorous discharge. It may often be blood-stained. Option B: Atrophic rhinitis usually starts at puberty and mainly presents with nasal obstruction and foul smell from the nose. Epistaxis occurs only after the removal of crusts. Option C: Epistaxis is a rare manifestation of polyps. Option D: Unilateral nasal angiofibroma also presents as painless, progressive unilateral nasal obstruction, often associated with epistaxis and rhinorrhea. But it is more common in the adolescent age group.
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the maneuver depicted in the image given below?
explanation: The given image shows Trotter’s method in which the patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood and breathe quietly from the mouth. It is the first step to control epistaxis. Other options: Option A: Epley’s maneuver is used in the treatment of BPPV (Benign Paroxysmal Positional Vertigo). Option C: McGovern’s technique is used in choanal atresia. A feeding nipple with a large hole provides a good oral airway. Option D: Valsalva maneuver is performed by forceful attempted exhalation against a closed nose and mouth. It is used as a test of cardiac function and autonomic nervous control of the heart, or to clear the ears and sinuses.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 60-year-old woman came to the casualty with a history of an episode of spontaneous epistaxis yesterday night. On examination, her BP was 200/110, and there was no active bleeding from the nose. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in managing this case?
explanation: The most appropriate next step is observation and blood pressure management as there is no active bleeding from the nose.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 65-year-old hypertensive patient presented with a history of recurrent episodes of spontaneous nose bleeds over the past two weeks, each requiring medical attention. After evaluating the patient, the ENT surgeon recommended endoscopic artery ligation to prevent further episodes. Which of the following arteries is most commonly ligated in this procedure?
explanation: The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of refractory posterior epistaxis. The artery which is most commonly ligated in a case of refractory posterior epistaxis is the sphenopalatine artery. Posterior epistaxis is most commonly seen in older age groups. The bleeding is spontaneous, often due to hypertension, and is severe, requiring hospitalization. Refractory epistaxis is defined as recurrent or persistent bleeding after appropriate packing or multiple episodes of epistaxis during a short period, each requiring medical attention. Sphenopalatine artery ligation gives high success in the control of refractory posterior bleed. Therefore, transnasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation (TESPAL) is the preferred method. It is ligated at sphenopalatine foramen situated 1 cm behind the posterior end of middle turbinate. Anterior epistaxis Posterior epistaxis Age Children & young adults >40 years Incide nce Most common type Less common Cause Trauma Spontaneous; often due to H ypertension or arteriosclerosi s Site Little’s area - anteroinferior p art of the nasal septum Posterosuperior part of the n asal cavity; difficult to localiz e Bleedi ng Mild- can be controlled by lo cal pressure or nasal packing. Severe-often requires hospita lization and posterior nasal p acking.
subject: ENT

question_text: As a first-year resident, you have scrubbed in to assist for a maxillary artery ligation procedure on a patient with intractable epistaxis. After opening the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus, the surgeon asks you to ligate the maxillary artery. Where would you ligate the artery at?
explanation: The maxillary artery is ligated at the pterygopalatine fossa (sphenopalatine fossa) situated behind the maxillary sinus’s posterior wall. The internal maxillary artery is accessed transantrally via a Caldwell-Luc approach. After the posterior sinus wall is removed, the internal maxillary artery and its terminal branches are identified and clipped. The posterior sinus wall is then packed with Gelfoam, and the gingivobuccal incision is closed. More recently, transoral and transnasal endoscopic approaches have also been described.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which artery among the following could be the source of bleeding in a case of epistaxis not controlled by external carotid artery ligation?
explanation: Ethmoidal artery can cause epistaxis not controlled by external carotid artery ligation. The ethmoidal artery is a branch of internal carotid artery, whereas sphenopalatine, greater palatine and facial artery are branches of the external carotid artery. Hence if the bleeding is not controlled by external carotid artery ligation, the subsequent step would be to ligate the ethmoidal artery. Epistaxis may be classified as anterior or posterior epistaxis. Little's area is situated in the anterior inferior part of the nasal septum, just above the vestibule. It is the site of epistaxis in 90% of the cases. Four arteries anastomose here to form a vascular plexus called the Kiesselbach’s plexus. This area is exposed to the drying effect of inspiratory current and to fingernail trauma and is the usual site for epistaxis in children and young adults. The four contributing arteries are as follows: Septal branch of sphenopalatine and greater palatine branches of the maxillary artery, which in turn is a branch of the external carotid artery. Septal branch of the superior labial artery which in turn is a branch of the facial artery. The facial artery is a branch of the external carotid artery. Anterior ethmoidal branch of the ophthalmic division of internal carotid artery. Anterior epistaxis Posterior epistaxis Site Little's area or anterior part o f the lateral wall Posterosuperior part of the n asal cavity, or difficult to loca lize Age Children, young adults >40 years of age Cause Usually trauma Spontaneous, due to hyperte nsion or IHD Bleedi ng Mild, easily controlled with c onservative measures (pressu re, anterior nasal pack) Severe requires hospitalisatio n and posterior nasal pack The stepwise management of epistaxis: Pinching the nose Hippocratic or Trotter’s method Cauterisation Anterior nasal packing Posterior nasal packing Endoscopic Cauterisation Ligation Embolization Ligation should be performed as close as possible to the likely bleeding point. The recommended hierarchy of ligation to be followed is Sphenopalatine artery  Internal maxillary artery  External carotid artery  Anterior /posterior ethmoidal artery. Ethmoidal vessels are exposed in the medial wall of the orbit by an external ethmoid (Lynch) incision.
subject: ENT

question_text:
Which of the following vessels would you never ligate for the control of recurrent spontaneous epistaxis?
Internal carotid artery
explanation: Internal carotid artery is not ligated for controlling epistaxis due to the high percentage of cerebral complications and mortality. Ligation of the following arteries is done in epistaxis control : Trans nasal Endoscopic Sphenopalatine artery ligation (TESPAL) If not controlled, maxillary artery ligation If still not controlled, external carotid artery ligation In case, bleeding site is superior to the level of middle turbinate, then anterior and posterior ethmoidal vessels should be ligated. Congenital Anomalies of Nose and Disease of Nose
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient presented with a deformity as shown in the image below. What is this deformity known as?
explanation: In the given image, the midline of the dorsum of the nose from the frontonasal angle to the tip is curved in a C- or S-shaped manner which is known as crooked nose deformity. Option B: Deviated nose - midline is straight but deviated to one side. Option C: Hump nose is due to excess of bony or cartilaginous dorsum. Option D: Saddle nose is depressed nasal dorsum.
subject: ENT

question_text: In which of the following patients will you not expect a saddle nose deformity?
options: A VDRL positive patient with gumma of the nasal septum
A patient with lateral madarosis and leonine facie
A boxer who developed bilateral nasal obstruction after a trauma to the nose
A patient with growth hormone excess and a large nose.
explanation: Option D is a case of acromegaly, in which there may be enlargement of the nose. Saddle nose deformity only occurs when the bridge of the nose collapses. Causes for saddle nose/depressed dorsum of nose: Nasal trauma causing depressed fractures - most common etiology. Excessive removal of septum in submucous resection Destruction of septal cartilage by haematoma or absce Leprosy Syphili Tuberculosis. Option A is a case of tertiary syphilis. Option B is a case of lepromatous leprosy. Option C is a case of septal hematoma.
subject: ENT

question_text: A newborn developed respiratory distress immediately after delivery. The paediatrician was unable to pass the nasogastric tube through both the nares. Which of the following statements is false about the above diagnosis?
options: It is due to persistence of bucconasal membrane
Can be associated with CHARGE syndrome.
Bony obstruction is more common than membranous obstruction
Immediate tracheostomy to be done to maintain the airway.
explanation: The above clinical scenario is suggestive of bilateral choanal atresia and immediate tracheostomy is not indicated. Simply securing a feeding nipple with a large hole provides a good oral airway and forces the infant to breathe through the mouth. This is known as McGovern’s technique and obviates the need for tracheostomy.
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the most common presentation of a patient with the pathology shown in the CT below?
explanation: Neonates with bilateral choanal atresia (image) present with respiratory distress at birth. Neonates are natural nose breathers, and do not breathe from their mouths.
subject: ENT

question_text: Choanal atresia is not associated with which of the following defects?
explanation: Choanal atresia may be associated with CHARGE syndrome. Renal angiomyolipoma is not a part of CHARGE syndrome. C- Coloboma of the eye H- Heart defect A- Atresia of the choana R- Retarded growth and development G- Genital anomalie E- Ear anomalies and hearing loss. Renal angiomyolipoma - It is one of the major features of tuberous sclerosis complex.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 2-year-old child was brought with a soft, compressible swelling at the root of the nose. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The above clinical scenario of isolated solitary mass arising from the root of the nose should raise the index of suspicion of nasal meningocele or meningoencephalocele. It is the herniation of brain tissue along with its meninges through a congenital bony defect. Nasal obstruction is the most common symptom. It presents as a cystic, bluish, compressible, translucent mass at the root of the nose (nasofrontal variety), side of the nose (nasoethmoid variety), or at the anteromedial aspect of the orbit (nasoorbital variety). Furstenberg's test: compression of the ipsilateral internal jugular vein usually causes an encephalocele to enlarge. Investigation: CT or MRI. Treatment: Transnasal endoscopic excision with the closure of the defect using bone or cartilage graft along with temporalis fascia and fat.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following statements about nasal glioma is false?
explanation: There is no CSF leakage in nasal glioma. It is a nipped-off portion of an encephalocele with no communication with the cranial cavity. They usually present as a firm, subcutaneous swelling causing nasal obstruction. Furstenberg's test - compression of the ipsilateral internal jugular vein usually causes an encephalocele to enlarge, but not a glioma. So, this test is negative in nasal glioma. 60% of nasal gliomas are extra-nasal, 30% are intranasal, and 10% are both intranasal and extra-nasal. CT scan reveals bony details while MRI reveals soft tissue details of a nasal glioma.
subject: ENT

question_text: A surgeon suspects a rodent ulcer in a patient who presented with a finding as shown in the image. What is this condition also called?
explanation: Basal cell carcinoma also known as rodent ulcer is the most common malignant tumour involving skin of nose.
subject: ENT

question_text: In a patient with findings as shown in the image, which of the following statements is false?
options: It is known as elephantiasis of the nose
It is seen in long standing cases of acne rosacea
It is commonly seen in middle aged women
It is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous gland
explanation: The given image is diagnostic of rhinophyma. It is commonly seen in men past middle age. Rhinophyma or potato tumour or elephantiasis of nose is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous glands. It is usually associated with long-standing cases of acne rosacea. Mostly seen at the tip of the nose and causes unsightly appearance and obstruction to breathing and vision. Treatment: Debulk of the tumor with carbon dioxide laser and the area is allowed to re-epithelialize. Sometimes the tumor is completely excised and skin is grafted over the raw area.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient presented with atrophic dry nasal mucosa, extensive crustations, and a woody hard external nose. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical condition is suggestive of rhinoscleroma. Rhinoscleroma is caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis (Frisch bacillus). It has 3 stages: Atrophic stage– Crusting and foul smelling nasal discharge similar to atrophic rhinitis. Granulomatous stage– Painless, non ulcerative Granulomatous nodules with subdermal infiltration giving feel of woody/hebra nose. Cicatricial stage– Fibrosis leading to stenosis of vestibule, pharynx, larynx. Deformity is called tapir nose. Option A: Atrophic rhinitis doesn’t cause woody nose. Option B: Rhinophyma or potato tumor is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous gland and presents as swelling over tip of nose. Option C: Rhinosporidiosis is a granulomatous condition caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and presents with nasal discharge, epistaxis and nasal obstruction by a polypoidal mass.
subject: ENT

question_text: A pathologist observed Mikulicz cells and Russell bodies on microscopy in a biopsy specimen taken from the nose. Which of the following is a false statement regarding the diagnosis?
options: Medical management include streptomycin and tetracycline.
Surgery is the treatment of choice for this disease
explanation: Biopsy findings of Mikulicz cells and Russell's bodies are characteristic findings in rhinoscleroma. Medical management is the mainstay treatment for rhinoscleroma. Streptomycin(1 g/day) and tetracycline (2 g/day) are given for a minimum of 4-6 weeks and continued till 2 consecutive biopsies are negative. Surgery is reserved to establish airway or correct deformity. Biopsy in the case of rhinoscleroma shows infiltration of submucosa with plasma cells, lymphocytes, eosinophils, Mikulicz cells, and Russell bodies. Mikulicz cells are large foam cells with a central nucleus and vacuolated cytoplasm containing causative bacilli. Russell bodies are homogenous eosinophilic inclusion bodies found in the plasma cells. They occur due to the accumulation of immunoglobulins secreted by the plasma cells. The following image shows rhinoscleroma with Mikulicz cells. H&E showing a mixture of plasma cells (arrow), lymphocytes (short arrow), Miculikz cells which are vacuolated macrophages containing causative bacilli (double arrow). Option A: Rhinoscleroma is endemic in several parts of the world. In India, it is seen more often in the northern than in the southern parts. Option D: Organism can be cultured from biopsy material.
subject: ENT

question_text: Snuffles are seen in which stage of syphilis?
explanation: Snuffles is seen in early congenital syphilis. Nasal features in different stages of syphilis: Stage Feature Early congenital syphilis Snuffles Late congenital syphilis Gumma on the nasal septum Primary syphilis Primary chancre of the vestib ule of nose Secondary syphilis Simple rhinitis with crusting and fissuring in the nasal ves tibule Tertiary form of acquired syp hilis Gumma on the nasal septum
subject: ENT

question_text: An eighteen-year-old boy presented with a lesion over the nose as shown in the image. What is your diagnosis?
explanation: The image shows apple jelly nodules seen in lupus vulgaris which is a low-grade tuberculous infection. These are brown, gelatinous nodules commonly affecting nasal vestibule or the skin of nose and face.
subject: ENT

question_text: Given below is a histological section of a biopsy taken from a farmer who presented with a vascular polypoidal mass protruding from his left nostril. What is the causative organism for this condition?
explanation: The above clinical scenario along with the histology (showing sporangia) is suggestive of rhinosporidiosis caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi. Rhinoscleroma is caused by Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis.
subject: ENT

question_text: Rhinosporidium seeberi belongs to which group of organisms?
explanation: Rhinosporidium seeberi is an aquatic protista. Molecular biological techniques have demonstrated that this organism is an aquatic protistan parasite and it is currently included in a new class, the Mesomycetozoea, along with organisms causing similar infections in amphibians and fish.
subject: ENT

question_text: A farmer presented with a mass protruding from his right nostril as shown in the figure below. On examination, mass bleeds easily on touch. Which of the statements is false regarding the diagnosis?
options: Water borne is the most common route of transmission
Endemic in southern states of India
explanation: Rhinosporidiosis affects immunocompetent individuals.
subject: ENT

question_text: A man who works in a cattle ranch presented with complaints of a mass protruding from the left nostril and blood-stained nasal discharge. The mass is pink, leafy, and polypoidal and is attached to the nasal septum. Biopsy from the lesion showed several sporangia. What is the treatment of choice for the above condition?
explanation: Surgical management (excision of the lesion with cauterisation of the base), is always the treatment of choice in rhinosporidiosis. No drug treatment has proved effective, although dapsone is tried in some cases. Followup of the patient after surgical management is necessary, as recurrence is common.
subject: ENT

question_text:
Which of the following statements is false about nasal T-cell lymphoma?
It is also known as Stewart’s granuloma
options: It is a locally invasive tumor.
Surgery is the treatment of choice
explanation: T-cell lymphoma is treated by radiation when it is localised and by chemotherapy when it is disseminated. The condition is also called as: Non-healing midline granuloma Midline granulomas reticulosi Stewart’s granuloma Nasal T-cell lymphoma Lethal midline granuloma It is associated with EBV. Cells express T cell markers like CD56. Nasal obstruction and epistaxis are the presenting features. Destruction of mid-facial structures may be caused by the local invasion. Histologically, polymorphic lymphoid tissue with angiocentric and angioinvasive features are seen. Rhinitis
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is the most common cause of common cold?
explanation: The most common cause of the common cold is Rhinovirus. Adenovirus, picornavirus and its subgroups such as Coxsackievirus and enteric cytopathic human orphan (ECHO) virus are also usually implicated. Influenza and parainfluenza virus causes the flu.
subject: ENT

question_text: You are an intern examining a patient with nasal obstruction and nasal discharge. The anterior rhinoscopy shows mulberry appearance of the inferior turbinate. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The mulberry appearance of turbinate is seen in patients with hypertrophic rhinitis. It is characterized by thickening of mucosa, submucosa, seromucinous glands, periosteum and bone. Maximum changes are seen in the inferior turbinate.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following disease is also called ozaena?
explanation: Atrophic rhinitis is also known as ozaena.
subject: ENT

question_text: A middle-aged woman with nasal discharge and crusting is diagnosed to have primary atrophic rhinitis. Which of the following organisms is most commonly associated with this condition?
explanation: The most common organism causing primary atrophic rhinitis is Klebsiella ozaena. Various organisms have been cultured from cases of atrophic rhinitis such as Coccobacillus foetidus ozaenae, Proteus vulgaris, Escherichia coli, staphylococci, diphtheroids, and streptococci but they are all considered to be secondary invaders responsible for foul smell rather than the primary causative organisms of the disease. Etiology of atrophic rhinitis: Primary atrophic rhinitis: Hereditary- Involves more than one member of a family Endocrinal- More common in females, starts at puberty and regresses after menopause Racial- More common in mongoloid and caucasian races Nutritional deficiency- Vitamin A, D, iron deficiencies Autoimmune- Antigens of the nasal mucosa Organism- Klebsiella ozaenae. Secondary atrophic rhinitis: Specific infections like syphilis, lupus, leprosy and rhinoscleroma Long-standing purulent sinusitis Radiotherapy to nose Excessive surgical removal of turbinates Diphtheroids, Proteus vulgaris, Escherichia coli, staphylococci and streptococci.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is false about atrophic rhinitis?
explanation: Atrophic rhinitis is mostly a bilateral condition.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 25-year-old woman presented to the OPD with foul-smelling nasal discharge and obstruction. On examination, crusts are present bilaterally and on the removal of the crust, bleeding is present. Which of the following is least likely to cause this?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of bilateral atrophic rhinitis. Only deviated nasal septum causes unilateral atrophic rhinitis. The others cause bilateral atrophic rhinitis. Etiology of atrophic rhinitis: Primary atrophic rhinitis: Hereditary- Involves more than one member of a family Endocrinal- More common in females, starts at puberty and regresses after menopause Racial- More common in mongoloid and caucasian races Nutritional deficiency- Vitamin A, D, iron deficiencies Autoimmune- Antigens of the nasal mucosa Organism- Klebsiella ozaenae. Secondary atrophic rhinitis: Specific infections like syphilis, lupus, leprosy and rhinoscleroma Long-standing purulent sinusitis Radiotherapy to nose Excessive surgical removal of turbinates Diphtheroids, Proteus vulgaris, Escherichia coli, staphylococci and streptococci.
subject: ENT

question_text: In a patient with atrophic rhinitis, what is the main reason for nasal obstruction?
explanation: Nasal obstruction in a patient with atrophic rhinitis is due to excessive crust formation. Turbinates are atrophied here.
subject: ENT

question_text: You are an intern in the ENT department preparing the alkaline nasal solution for a patient with atrophic rhinitis. Which of the following will you not use for the preparation?
explanation: Potassium chloride is not a part of the alkaline nasal solution used in the treatment of atrophic rhinitis. The composition of the alkaline solution is: Sodium chloride - 2 parts Sodium bicarbonate - 1 part Sodium biborate - 1 part It is dissolved in 280 mL of water and the nasal cavities are irrigated to loosen the crusts and ease its removal. Other treatment options: 25% glucose in glycerine Estradiol spray Submucosal placental extract Local antibiotics Potassium iodide Systemic streptomycin
subject: ENT

question_text: An adolescent girl with atrophic rhinitis is using kemicetine antiozaena solution. Which of the following is not a component of this solution?
explanation: Sodium bicarbonate is not a component of kemicetine antiozaena solution. It is used in alkaline nasal solution. The components of kemicetine antiozaena solution are: Chloramphenico Oestradio Vitamin D2. It is used in the medical management of atrophic rhinitis.
subject: ENT

question_text:
A housewife presents with complaints of a blocked nose, loss of smell and dry, greenish crusty nasal discharge. On examination, nasal cavities appear roomy and turbinates are atrophied.
Which of the following surgeries can be done in this patient?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of atrophic rhinitis. Young’s and modified Young’s operations are done for the treatment of atrophic rhinitis. In Young’s operation, both the nostrils are closed completely just within the nasal vestibule by raising flaps. They are opened after 6 months or later where the mucosa may revert back to normal and crusting will be reduced. Modified Young’s operation aims at partially closing the nostrils. Options A and C: Submucous resection and septoplasty are done for deviated nasal septum. Option D: Vidian neurectomy is done for vasomotor rhinitis.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 40-year-old ironsmith came to the ENT clinic with complaints of dry nose, nasal crusting and bleeding on removal of the crusts. A diagnosis of rhinitis sicca was made. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?
options: More common in people working in hot, dry, dusty surroundings
Antibiotic & steroid ointment is used for treatment
explanation: Rhinitis sicca affects the anterior 1/3rd of the nose since this part is exposed to the effect of the dry, dusty air. Rhinitis sicca is a crust-forming disease seen in patients who work in hot, dry, and dusty surroundings, e.g. bakers, iron- and goldsmiths. It is usually confined to the anterior third of the nose particularly of the nasal septum. The ciliated columnar epithelium undergoes squamous metaplasia with atrophy of the seromucinous glands. Treatment consists of correcting occupational surroundings and application of bland ointment with an antibiotic and steroid combination to the affected part.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is false about rhinitis caseosa?
explanation: Rhinitis caseosa is a unilateral condition and not bilateral. It is also known as nasal cholesteatoma and is more common in males. There will be an accumulation of secretions in the nasal cavity which undergoes putrefaction resulting in the formation of caseous material. It is usually associated with suppurative sinusitis. Treatment includes the removal of debris and granulation tissue and free drainage of the affected sinus.
subject: ENT

question_text: Allergic rhinitis is mediated by which of the following?
explanation: Allergic rhinitis is an IgE-mediated immunologic response of nasal mucosa to airborne allergens. Patients typically present with recurrent bouts of sneezing, nasal obstruction, watery nasal discharge, and itching and clinical signs include allergic shiners (dark circles around the eyes) and allergic salute (black transverse nasal crease on the dorsum of the nose due to repeated upward rubbing). Treatment options include: Avoidance of the allergen Treatment with drugs like oral antihistamines, intranasal corticosteroids, intranasal cromolyn sodium Immunotherapy is through the delivery of allergen in gradual increasing doses till the maintenance dose is reached. It suppresses the development of IgE. It has to be given for a year to see significant improvement in symptoms. Intranasal corticosteroids (INCS) remain the preferred monotherapy for persistent allergic rhinitis (AR). However, additional studies support the additive benefit of combination treatment with INCS and intranasal antihistamines in AR. For patients receiving INCS, an intranasal decongestant may be added to the treatment for up to 4 weeks.
subject: ENT

question_text: A mother brought her a 6-year-old child with watery nasal discharge, nasal obstruction, frequent sneezing and itching in the nose. She also adds that the symptoms occur during the winter season and there is a history of asthma in the family. Which of the following is not associated with this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario of a child with watery nasal discharge, frequent sneezing, itching of the nose, and seasonal variation is suggestive of allergic rhinitis, and hypertrophy of turbinates is seen, not atrophy. Other features of allergic rhinitis: Option A: Dennie-Morgan lines - transverse skin creases in the infraorbital area. Option B: Allergic salute - is a transverse nasal crease that appears as a black line across the middle of the dorsum of the nose due to constant upward rubbing of nose simulating a salute. Option D: Serous otitis media occurs as a result of eustachian tube blockage.
subject: ENT

question_text: An ENT resident is evaluating a patient with suspected allergic rhinitis. On anterior rhinoscopy, which of the following is most likely to be seen?
explanation: A patient with perennial allergic rhinitis will have a pale and edematous nasal mucosa with swollen turbinates. Crusts that bleed on removal and atrophied turbinates are features seen in atrophic rhinitis. Note: Typical allergic mucosa appears pale and swollen, while the mucosa is reddened in acute infections and after the overuse of topical medications.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 30-year-old man came with complaints of excessive nasal discharge, sneezing, and nasal obstruction. There is no history of allergen exposure or asthma in the family. You are suspecting vasomotor rhinitis. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?
options: It occurs due to sympathetic overactivity.
Vidian neurectomy is a treatment option.
Pale and atrophied turbinates are seen.
explanation: Vidian neurectomy is a treatment option in vasomotor rhinitis. Vasomotor rhinitis is a non-allergic condition that occurs due to parasympathetic overactivity, causing vasodilatation and congestion of nasal mucosa. The vidian nerve carries the parasympathetic supply to the nose. The usual presentation is excessive rhinorrhea, sneezing, and nasal obstruction which is similar to allergic rhinitis. But the turbinates will be congested and edematous. Treatment includes antihistamines, oral nasal decongestants, and topical steroids. In case of failed medical treatment, vidian neurectomy is done.
subject: ENT

question_text: Prolonged use of which of the following drugs can cause rhinitis medicamentosa?
explanation: Rhinitis medicamentosa is caused by the prolonged use of nasal decongestants. The treatment includes the withdrawal of nasal decongestant drops, a short course of systemic steroid therapy, and in some cases, surgical reduction of turbinates if they have become hypertrophied.
subject: ENT

question_text:
Surgery where nostrils are partially or completely occluded is done for which condition?
Vasomotor rhinitis
explanation: Complete closure of the nostrils (Young's operation) or partial closure of the nostrils (Modified Young's operation) is done for the treatment of atrophic rhinitis. In Young's operation, both nostrils are closed completely by raising flaps within the nasal vestibule. They are opened after 6 months. During this time, the mucosa becomes normal, and the crusting is reduced. In Modified Young's operation, the procedure has been modified to avoid discomfort from complete closure of the nostrils. Here the nostrils are only partially closed. The results are the same when compared to Young's operation. Atrophic rhinitis (ozaena) is a chronic inflammation of the nose with atrophy of nasal mucosa and turbinate bones. Roomy nasal cavities with foul-smelling crusts are seen. The patient presents with a foul smell from the nose, marked anosmia (merciful anosmia), and paradoxical nasal obstruction (nasal obstruction despite wide nasal passages). Paradoxical nasal obstruction occurs due to degenerative changes in the sensory nerves of the nasal mucosa, leading to an inability to sense airflow. Medical management includes nasal irrigation and removal of crusts. 25% glucose in glycerine, antibiotics (quinolones or metronidazole), estradiol nasal spray, and mucolytics can be used. Disorder of Nasal Septum and Nasal Polyposis
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is not a cause for deviated nasal septum?
explanation: Allergic rhinitis does not cause deviated nasal septum (DNS). Etiology of DNS: Trauma - during passage through the birth canal or trauma after birth leading to fracture of the nasal septum Developmental error - may be associated with cleft lip, cleft palate Racial factor - more common in Caucasians Hereditary - affects more than one member of the same family
subject: ENT

question_text: A 3rd-year MBBS student is examining a case of deviated nasal septum. Which of the following findings is unlikely to be seen in this patient?
explanation: Nasal polyp will not be seen in a patient with deviated nasal septum. Clinical features of DNS: Nasal obstruction - unilateral in C-shaped deviation and bilateral in S-shaped deviation Headache - may be due to associated sinusitis or due to spur pressing on the lateral wall of the nose Sinusitis - due to obstruction of ostia and poor ventilation of sinuses Epistaxis - from vessels over spur or due to crusting of the nasal mucosa Anosmia - especially in bilateral nasal obstruction Compensatory hypertrophy of turbinates on roomier side Frequent middle ear infections Association with external deformities
subject: ENT

question_text: What clinical test is depicted in the image?
explanation: The clinical test depicted in the image is Cottle’s test where the cheek is drawn laterally while the patient breathes quietly. This test is used to assess the patency of the nasal valve in patients with a deviated nasal septum. If the nasal airway improves on the test side, the test is positive and indicates an abnormality of the vestibular component of the nasal valve on that side. Option A: Epley’s maneuver is used in the treatment of BPPV. Option B: Heimlich manoeuvre is used in the treatment of accidental inhalation of foreign body. Procedure: Stand behind the person and place your arms around his lower chest and give four abdominal thrusts. The residual air in the lungs can dislodge the foreign body providing some airway. Option D: Trotter’s method is used in the treatment of epistaxis. In Trotter’s method, the patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood. He should pinch the nose firmly for 5 to 10 mins and breathe quietly from the mouth.
subject: ENT

question_text: An ENT surgeon is performing septoplasty in a patient with deviated nasal septum. Which of the following is not an indication for the surgery?
explanation: Nasal discharge is not an indication for surgery in a patient with deviated nasal septum (DNS). Indications for surgery in DNS: Symptoms of nasal obstruction and recurrent headaches Recurrent sinusitis and otitis media Recurrent epistaxis from the septal spur Septal deviation causing sleep apnea or hypopnoea syndrome Other indications for SMR (submucous resection) and septoplasty: As a part of septorhinoplasty for cosmetic correction of external nasal deformities As a preliminary step in hypophysectomy (trans-septal trans-sphenoidal approach) or vidian neurectomy (transseptal approach) For the approach to middle meatus or frontal recess in endoscopic sinus surgery when deviated septum obstructs the view and access to these areas To gain access for endoscopic dacryocystorhinostomy
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient diagnosed with deviated nasal septum is undergoing submucous resection. What is the key incision is used in this procedure?
explanation: Killian’s incision is used in submucosal resection. It is a slightly curvilinear incision, taken 2–3 mm above the caudal end of septal cartilage on the concave side of the deviated nasal septum. Option B: Shobinger incision is used in modified radical neck dissection. Option C: Freer’s hemitransfixation incision is used in septoplasty. It is a septocolumellar incision taken between the caudal end of septal cartilage and columella. Option D: Weber Ferguson incision is used in maxillectomy.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 20-year-old college student presented with complaints of facial pain, nasal discharge, headache, and nasal bleeding. He has a history of recurrent sinusitis in the past. On anterior rhinoscopy examination, the nasal septum is deviated. Which of the following is the treatment of choice?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is a case of deviated nasal septum and septoplasty is the treatment of choice. Both submucous resection and septoplasty can be done for DNS. Septoplasty is a conservative approach and more commonly done nowadays. Septoplasty is also the preferred surgery for DNS in less than 18 yrs, if DNS is bilateral and severe. Submucous resection Septoplasty Non-conservative procedure with extensive dissection of c artilage Conservative procedure Not done in < 18 yrs Can be done adults and perso ns < 18 yrs if bilateral and se vere Killian’s incision is used Freer’s incision is used Mucoperichondrial/periosteal flaps raised on both sides of the septum Flaps raised on only one side More complications Less complications Reoperation is difficult Reoperation is easier
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is a false statement regarding septoplasty?
options: It is done in cases of symptomatic nasal obstruction.
Mucoperiosteal flap is raised on both sides.
explanation: Septoplasty is a conservative approach where mucoperichondrial/periosteal flap is generally raised only on one side. As much of the septal framework as possible is retained. Submucous resection Septoplasty Non-conservative procedure with extensive dissection of c artilage Conservative procedure Not done in < 18 yrs Done children and adults Killian’s incision is used Freer’s incision is used Mucoperichondrial/periosteal flaps raised onbothsides of t he septum Flaps raised on onlyonesid e More complications Fewer complications Reoperation is difficult Reoperation is easier
subject: ENT

question_text: A mother brought her 5-year-old child with complaints of pain and swelling in the nose and difficulty in breathing after an alleged history of fall while playing. On examination, there is bilateral swelling of the nasal septum which is tender and erythematous. Which of the following is false about the given condition?
options: Can result in hump nose deformity
Accumulation of blood under the perichondrium
explanation: The given clinical scenario with bilateral septal swelling following trauma is suggestive of a septal hematoma and can result in saddle nose deformity, not hump nose deformity. Septal hematoma is a collection of blood under the perichondrium or periosteum of the nasal septum. It is caused due to trauma, septal surgery, and bleeding disorders. Clinical features include pain, swelling, and bilateral nasal obstruction (the most common presenting feature), and sometimes, frontal headache. Complications include septal abscess, depression of dorsum (saddle nose), and permanently thickened septum.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 6-year-old boy fell from the bed and developed swelling in the nose and difficulty in breathing. Which of the following is the best management for this child?
explanation: The given clinical scenario with swelling in the nose after trauma is suggestive of septal hematoma and it needs immediate surgical drainage. Treatment of septal hematoma: Aspiration of small hematomas Incision and drainage of large hematomas followed by nasal packing Systemic antibiotics to prevent abscess formation
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is the most common cause of septal perforation?
explanation: Trauma is the most common cause of septal perforation. Causes of septal perforation: Trauma - nasal surgery, nose picking, septal cauterization, nasal packing, septal hematoma, foreign bodies Surface irritants - cocaine, heroin, decongestant nasal sprays Infections - syphilis, typhoid, tuberculosis, lepromatous leprosy, rhinosporidiosis, rhinoscleroma, aspergillosis Neoplastic - melanoma, SCC, adenocarcinoma, lymphoma Inflammatory - sarcoidosis, Crohn's disease, RA, Granulomatosis with polyangitis Small anterior perforations may present with a whistling sound during respiration. Large perforations may obstruct the nose or even bleed due to the formation of crusts. Treatment depends on the cause. Small asymptomatic perforations can be closed by plastic flaps. In larger perforations treatment is aimed at keeping the nose crust-free using nasal douches and b and ointments.
subject: ENT

question_text: A middle-aged man with tertiary syphilis presented with complaints of epistaxis, nasal crusting, and nasal twang on speaking. On examination, nasal septal perforation was noted. What is the most likely site for the perforation?
options: Junction of the bony and cartilaginous septum
explanation: The given patient is having nasal septal perforation due to syphilis. The most common site of involvement in syphilis is the bony nasal septum. Other chronic granulomatous conditions like lupus, tuberculosis, and leprosy can cause perforation in the cartilaginous part. Wegener’s granulomatosis causes perforation of both bony and cartilaginous parts.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 30-year-old woman from a rural area presented with foul-smelling nasal discharge, nasal crusts, and epistaxis. She was diagnosed with atrophic rhinitis. On examination, maggots were seen in the nasal cavity. Which of the following is used in the treatment for this patient?
explanation: Myiasis (maggots in the nasal cavity) is a complication of atrophic rhinitis. It is treated with chloroform diluted with water. The maggots are larval forms of flies especially genus Chrysomia. The flies are attracted by the foul-smelling nasal discharge in conditions like atrophic rhinitis, syphilis, leprosy, and lay eggs in the nasal cavity. These eggs hatch into larvae within 24 hrs and cause intense irritation, lacrimation, sneezing, and blood-tinged nasal discharge. Treatment: All visible maggots should be picked up with forceps Instillation of chloroform water and oil kills them Nasal douche with warm saline is used to remove slough, crusts, and dead maggots.
subject: ENT

question_text: Bernoulli’s phenomenon explains the pathogenesis of which of the following conditions?
explanation: Bernoulli’s phenomenon explains the pathogenesis of nasal polyp formation. Bernoulli’s principle states that when the velocity of air increases, the lateral pressure will decrease. When air passes through the nasal valve area which is the narrowest region of the nasal cavity, velocity increases. This creates a negative pressure that sucks mucosa of sinuses into the nasal cavity leading to polyp formation.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 45-year-old man was prescribed aspirin for post-MI prophylaxis. But whenever he takes the medication, he develops difficulty in breathing, sneezing, and lacrimation. He has a known family history of bronchial asthma. Which of the following is related to the his condition?
explanation: The given scenario is suggestive of Samter’s triad where the patient will have aspirin intolerance, asthma, and ethmoidal polyps. Other etiological factors of ethmoidal polyp: Chronic rhinosinusitis especially non-allergic rhinitis with eosinophilia syndrome Allergic fungal sinusitis Asthma Cystic fibrosis Kartagener syndrome - This consists of bronchiectasis, sinusitis, situs inversus and ciliary dyskinesis Young syndrome - It consists of sinopulmonary disease and azoospermia Churg–Strauss syndrome - Consists of asthma, fever, eosinophilia, vasculitis and granuloma
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is not part of Kartagener’s syndrome?
explanation: Azoospermia is not a component of Kartagener's syndrome. Kartagener syndrome is characterized by the triad of: Bronchiectasis Sinusitis Situs inversus Kartagener syndrome is one of the etiology for ethmoidal polyps.
subject: ENT

question_text: What is Young’s syndrome?
explanation: Young's syndrome consists of sinopulmonary disease and azoospermia. Option A: Neutrophilia with red papular rash is seen in Sweet’s syndrome/acute febrile neutrophilic dermatosis. Option C: Mitral stenosis with ASD forms part of Lutembacher syndrome. Option D: Nasal polyp, asthma, aspirin hypersensitivity form Samter’s triad.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 40-year-old woman came to OPD with complaints of bilateral nasal obstruction, headache, sneezing and nasal discharge. On examination, multiple smooth pale glistening masses are present bilaterally that don't bleed on touch. Which of the following is false about the diagnosis?
options: The site of origin is lateral wall of the nose
FESS is the treatment of choice
The mass can grow posteriorly and occupy the choana
explanation: The given case scenario with multiple bilateral nasal masses in a middle-aged woman is suggestive of ethmoidal polyp and it doesn’t grow posteriorly to occupy choana.
subject: ENT

question_text: You are an intern examining a child who presented with nasal obstruction and discharge. On anterior rhinoscopy, there is a single smooth glistening mass in the right nasal cavity which can be moved up and down with a probe and doesn’t bleed on touch. The mass is extending posteriorly and occupying the choana. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?
options: Infection and allergy are the main etiological factors
The site of origin is maxillary antrum
FESS is the treatment of choice
explanation: The given clinical scenario with findings of a single, unilateral polyp that extends posteriorly to occupy the choana in a child is suggestive of antrochoanal polyp. It can present with hyponasal voice and not hypernasal voice.
subject: ENT

question_text:
A middle-aged man with recurrent diffuse ethmoidal polyps is scheduled for a laser-assisted FESS procedure. Which of the following lasers is ideal in this scenario?
ND-YAG laser
explanation: KTP laser (potassium titanyl phosphate) is the ideal laser for the treatment of nasal polyps. Option A: Nd-YAG laser due to its greater depth of penetration has a higher risk of complications within the nasal cavity. Option C: CO2 lasers are primarily used for laryngeal interventions. Its use in nasal sinus surgery is restricted as it causes extensive scarring and it cannot be delivered through a flexible fiber-optical system. Option D: The use of argon lasers is limited in sinus surgery due to the high cost of the laser tube and the need for a high current power supply and water flow for cooling. Trauma of Nose and Face
subject: ENT

question_text: A biker met with an accident and sustained a maxillofacial injury. Which of the following is the first step in the primary care of this patient?
explanation: The first step in primary care of a patient with a maxillofacial injury is securing an adequate airway. Evaluation of facial fractures: A & B – Airway & Breathing: the first objective is to ensure an adequate airway by intubation or tracheostomy. C – Circulation: control of haemorrhage by pressure or ligation of bleeding vessels. Rule out head and spinal injuries. Neurological evaluation. Examine for injuries in other parts of the body. Care of the wound. Documentation of the injuries for medico-legal purposes. Examination of the facial skeleton – mandible, maxilla, zygomatic and orbital fracture.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following facial bones is most commonly fractured?
explanation: The most commonly fractured bone of the face is the nasal bone because of the projection of the nose on the face.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 30-year-old man presented with a nasal bleed after sustaining a blow to the nose in a fistfight. On evaluation, a nasal septal fracture similar to the one in the image below was identified. What is your diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario of nasal bleed following trauma and the image showing a horizontal fracture line is suggestive of Jarjaway fracture. It is a fracture of the nasal septum that results from direct blows from the front. The fracture line runs horizontally from just above the anterior nasal spine to just above the junction of septal cartilage with vomer. Option C: Chevallet fracture results from blows from below. The fracture line runs vertically from the anterior nasal spine upwards to the junction of the bony and cartilaginous dorsum of the nose. Option D: Tripod fracture is another name for zygoma fracture.
subject: ENT

question_text: A young adult presents with a deformed nose after falling from a ladder. The CT scan shows a displaced nasal fracture. What is the ideal time to reduce the fracture in this patient?
