explanation: The ideal time for reduction of fracture of the nasal bone is 5-7 days following injury, once the edema has subsided. The presence of edema interferes with the accurate reduction of the fracture. In most cases, the deformity is due to edema. So, ice packs and head elevation are advised initially after injury. After 3-5 days, the edema would subside and the underlying deformity will be apparent on clinical assessment. After 2 weeks it is difficult to reduce since the process of callus formation and the bony and fibrous union would have started.
subject: ENT

question_text: As an ENT resident, you are assisting in the reduction of a nasal bone fracture. Which of the following instruments would you use?
explanation: Walsham forceps (Image 2) is used to reduce a nasal bone fracture. Asch forceps is mainly used to reduce nasal septum fracture. Option A: Luc’s forceps is used in Caldwell Luc operation, submucous resection, and polypectomy. Option C: Tilley’s forceps is used in nasal packing in the epistaxis. Option D: Citelli’s forceps is used for bone punch.
subject: ENT

question_text: A boxer is wheeled into the ER with complaints of seeing double after having suffered a severe blow to his face during a match. On examination, there is a flattening of malar prominence, trismus and a step deformity of the infraorbital margin. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario of diplopia, flat malar prominence, trismus, and step deformity in the infraorbital margin is suggestive of fracture of zygoma or tripod fracture. Zygoma is the second most frequently fractured bone in the face. The zygoma fracture is separated at its three processes - the zygomaticofrontal suture, infraorbital margin, and the zygomaticotemporal suture. It has the following clinical features: Flattening of malar prominence. Trismus, due to depression of zygoma on the underlying coronoid process. Anesthesia in the distribution of the infraorbital nerve. Step deformity of infraorbital margin. Oblique palpebral fissure, due to the displacement of lateral palpebral ligament. Restricted ocular movements, due to entrapment of inferior rectus muscle. It may cause diplopia. Periorbital emphysema, due to escape of air from the maxillary sinus on nose blowing. The following x-ray shows a right-sided zygoma fracture:
subject: ENT

question_text: You are an ENT resident evaluating a patient with a fracture of the zygoma. Which of the following findings would you not expect to see in this patient?
explanation: CSF rhinorrhea is not seen in patients with fractures of the zygoma. It has the following clinical features: Flattening of malar prominence. Step deformity of infraorbital margin. Anesthesia in the distribution of the infraorbital nerve. Trismus, due to depression of zygoma on the underlying coronoid process. Oblique palpebral fissure, due to the displacement of lateral palpebral ligament. Restricted ocular movements, due to entrapment of inferior rectus muscle. It may cause diplopia. Periorbital emphysema, due to escape of air from the maxillary sinus on nose blowing. The following x-ray shows a right-sided zygoma fracture:
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient with a tripod fracture is having decreased sensation over the cheek. Which of the following nerve injuries can result in this?
explanation: Infraorbital nerve injury results in decreased sensation over the cheek in tripod(zygomatic) fracture.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is called blow-out fractures?
options: Fracture of lateral wall of orbit
Fracture of medial wall of orbit
explanation: Fracture of the floor of the orbit is called blow-out fracture. It occurs when a large blunt object strikes the globe.
subject: ENT

question_text: A teenage boy suffered trauma to his left eye while playing cricket. He is rushed to the ER in severe pain. His X-ray appears as below. What is the characteristic sign noted?
explanation: The given X-ray shows the tear-drop sign. It is seen in orbital floor or blow-out fractures when the orbital contents herniate into the maxillary antrum. Option B: Phelp’s sign is seen in CT scan in glomus jugulare tumor. It is the erosion of the normal crest of bone between the carotid canal and jugular foramen. Options C and D: Antral and Holman Miller signs are the same. It is the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus and is pathognomonic of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 19-year-old college student presented with complaints of seeing double after sustaining a blow to his face in a scuffle with his seniors. On examination, there is a step deformity and periorbital emphysema. Entrapment of which of the following muscles is likely to be responsible for his double vision?
explanation: The given clinical scenario with diplopia, periorbital emphysema, and a step deformity can be seen in both orbital floor fracture as well as tripod fracture. In both conditions diplopia is due to: Entrapment of inferior rectus and inferior oblique muscles Displacement of the eyeball. The common features seen in both orbital floor fracture and tripod fracture are: Periorbital emphysema Step deformity of infraorbital margin Diplopia Enophthalmos.
subject: ENT

question_text: In which of the following fractures Le-Fort classification is used?
explanation: Le-Fort classification is used in the fracture of the maxilla. The 3 types are: Le Fort I (transverse fracture) Le Fort II (pyramidal fracture) Le Fort III (craniofacial disjunction).
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following bones is not involved in Le-Fort fractures?
explanation: The mandible is not involved in Le-Fort’s fractures.
subject: ENT

question_text: The CT scan of a patient who met with a motorcycle accident shows a fracture of the maxilla. The fracture line passes through the floor of the nose separating the palate from the rest of the face. How will you classify the fracture?
explanation: The CT findings describe a Le-Fort I fracture of the maxilla. It is also known as Guerin’s fracture.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is the most common site for fracture of the mandible in children?
explanation: The most common site of fracture of the mandible in children is the condyle. It is because the condylar head is connected to the vertical ramus of the bone by a thin neck which gives away easily to an impact. Mandibular fractures: Children: Due to falls and sports injuries. Most common site - condyle. Adults > 50 years: Most commonly due to falls. Most common site - body (the molar area is the weakest area in an edentulous mandible). Young Adults: Due to falls, assaults, and accidents. The site of fracture depends on the nature of impact and the direction of force applied.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 23-year-old college student presented with jaw pain and trismus after falling from a bike. A diagnosis of mandibular fracture was made. Which of the following classification is used for this?
explanation: Dingman’s classification is used in the classification of fractures of the mandible. Dingman's classification is based on the region in which the fracture is located. The seven regions used in this classification are as shown below: Option A: Le-Fort classification is used in maxillary fractures. Option C: Gartland classification is used in supracondylar fractures of the humerus. Option D: Pauwell classification is used in the neck of femur fractures.
subject: ENT

question_text: Following trauma, a patient presented with clear watery nasal discharge that cannot be sniffed back. Fractures of which of the following bones is the most likely cause for this?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of CSF rhinorrhea and fracture of the cribriform plate of the ethmoid is the most common cause for this. Causes of CSF rhinorrhea: Trauma (accidental or surgical) - most of the cases follow trauma. Surgical trauma includes endoscopic sinus surgery, trans-sphenoidal hypophysectomy, nasal polypectomy, or skull base surgery. Inflammations - mucoceles of sinuses, sinonasal polyposis, the fungal infection of sinuses and osteomyelitis, can all erode the bone and dura. Neoplasms - tumours, both benign and malignant, invading the skull base. Congenital lesions - meningocele, meningoencephaloceles, and gliomas can have associated skull base defects. Idiopathic - where the cause is unknown and the patient has a spontaneous leak.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following fractures is not associated with CSF rhinorrhea?
explanation: Le-Fort I fracture is not associated with CSF rhinorrhea. Whereas, fractures like Le-Fort II, III and naso-orbito-ethmoid fracture are associated with CSF rhinorrhea.
subject: ENT

question_text: A middle-aged woman, who had undergone a polypectomy complains of watery nasal discharge on bending forward. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of CSF rhinorrhea secondary to surgery. Identifying features of CSF Rhinorrhea: The CSF discharge is thin, watery, and clear in appearance. It cannot be sniffed back. (Option D) It does not stiffen a handkerchief. It shows positional variation: The watery CSF discharge occurs suddenly and gushes in drops only on bending the head forward/straining. The Halo sign is a marker of CSF rhinorrhea post-head trauma. It is considered positive when a clear ring surrounds a central bloody spot after the discharge is dropped on a handkerchief/paper towel. Reservoir sign: The discharge is seen on rising in the morning and bending the head, as fluid accumulated in the sinuses empties into the nose.
subject: ENT

question_text: In a patient with suspected CSF rhinorrhea, the presence of which of the following in the nasal discharge will confirm the diagnosis?
explanation: Presence of  2 transferrin protein in the nasal discharge confirms the presence of CSF in the specimen.  2 transferrin protein detection by electrophoresis is a sensitive and specific test for CSF. It is secreted by meninges and choroid plexus. Since it is absent in nasal secretions it helps to differentiate CSF from nasal secretions. It is also present in aqueous humor and perilymph. Another method is glucose testing by oxidase peroxidase or biochemical estimation. CSF glucose is 60% of blood glucose whereas it is <10mg/dl in nasal secretions. It is not reliable in associated meningitis (reduced levels giving false-negative results) and when CSF is mixed with blood.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is false about CSF rhinorrhea?
options: Ethmoid is the most common site of leak
Intrathecal fluorescein study can be used to detect site of leak
explanation: Double ring sign is present in a case of CSF rhinorrhea. Double ring sign or Halo sign or Target sign - when CSF mixed with blood is collected on a piece of filter paper, it will show a central red spot (blood) and a peripheral lighter halo. Option A: Fracture cribriform plate of ethmoid is the most common cause. Option B: CSF glucose is 60% of blood glucose. Option C: Intrathecal fluorescein study is used to detect the site of leak of CSF.
subject: ENT

question_text:
What is the preferred line of management in a patient with CSF rhinorrhea who is otherwise stable?
Immediate surgical repair
explanation: Patients with CSF rhinorrhea who are stable, are managed conservatively. The conservative measures are: Bed rest Elevation of the head end Stool softeners Avoidance of nose-blowing, sneezing, and straining. Prophylactic antibiotics can be used to prevent meningitis and acetazolamide to decrease CSF formation. Surgery is done if the conservative management fails. Tumors of Nose and PNS
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following statements about inverted papilloma is false?
options: Arises from the lateral wall of nose
Presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and epistaxis
explanation: Inverted papilloma is more common in males.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 46-year-old man presented with left-sided nasal blockage and discharge for 3 years. On anterior rhinoscopy, a pale, red polypoidal mass is seen in the left nostril. He was diagnosed with inverted papilloma. Which of the following statements is false about the management of his condition?
options: MRI is the first imaging modality in follow-up
explanation: Radiotherapy is not advised in inverted papilloma since it may induce malignancy. Option A: Endoscopic approach is preferred to surgical resection. Option C: There is a high rate of recurrence of inverted papillomas. Option D: MRI is the first imaging modality to perform during follow up.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is the most common malignant tumor of the nasal cavity?
explanation: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the nasal cavity, seen in about 80% of cases.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is also known as nose picker’s carcinoma?
explanation: Squamous cell carcinoma of the nasal cavity arising from the nasal septum is called nose picker’s cancer. Option A: Inverted papilloma is also known as transitional cell papilloma or Ringertz tumor or Schneiderian papilloma. Option B: Basal cell carcinoma is also known as rodent ulcer. Option D: Esthesioneuroblastoma is also known as olfactory neuroblastoma.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 15-year-old presented with a cherry red, polypoidal mass detected on anterior rhinoscopy. Biopsy of the mass suggested that it originated from the olfactory neural epithelium. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario suggests the diagnosis of esthesioneuroblastoma. It arises from the olfactory epithelium of the upper third of the nose.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient is planned for surgical resection of esthesioneuroblastoma. Which of the following statements is false about the same?
options: Lymph node metastasis does not occur
explanation: Lymph node metastasis occurs in 10-15% of the cases.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is the most common site for osteomas?
explanation: Osteomas are most commonly seen in the frontal sinus followed by ethmoid and maxillary sinuses. They remain asymptomatic and are incidentally found on x-rays. Treatment is required only when they cause obstructive symptoms or pressure effects. The image given shows the x-ray image of an osteoma in the frontal sinus.
subject: ENT

question_text: The most common site of occurrence of fibrous dysplasia is
explanation: The maxilla is the most common site for fibrous dysplasia. Fibrous dysplasias and ossifying fibromas are both skeletal lesions where normal architecture is replaced by vascularized fibrous tissue. However, the difference between the two is as follows - Fibrous dysplasia Ossifying fibroma Site More common in the maxilla. question_text: Which of the following is the most common site for ossifying fibroma?
explanation: The mandible is the most common site for the occurrence of ossifying fibroma. Fibrous dysplasias and ossifying fibromas are both skeletal lesions where normal architecture is replaced by vascularized fibrous tissue. However, the difference between the two is as follows - Fibrous dysplasia Ossifying fibroma Site More common in the maxilla. More common in the mandib le Radiol ogy No well-defined edge, lesion merges with surroundings Well demarcated lesion Pathol ogy Strongly reactive for osteocal cin Weakly reactive for osteocalci n
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient is referred to the ENT OPD with left-sided nasal obstruction, disfigurement of the face, and displacement of his left eye. Imaging of paranasal sinuses shows an ill-defined expanding lesion with ground glass appearance in the maxillary sinus. What is the diagnosis?
explanation: The diagnosis is fibrous dysplasia. A ground-glass appearance in CT or x-ray is characteristic of fibrous dysplasia. In fibrous dysplasia, bone is replaced by fibrous tissue. The most common site is the maxillary sinus, followed by the ethmoid and frontal sinuses. It can present with disfigurement of the face, nasal obstruction, and displacement of the eye. The x-ray image below shows a ground-glass appearance present in the left maxillary sinus due to fibrous dysplasia. The lesion is not well demarcated and merges with the surrounding area. There is orbital displacement on the left side.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following histological varieties is the most common among paranasal sinus carcinomas?
explanation: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the paranasal sinuses.
subject: ENT

question_text: Where is squamous cell carcinoma most commonly found in the paranasal sinuses?
explanation: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common in the maxillary sinuses followed in turn by ethmoids, frontal and sphenoid sinuses.
subject: ENT

question_text: A carpenter was diagnosed with sinonasal carcinoma and planned for surgical resection. Which of the following histological varieties would be most likely in this case?
explanation: Adenocarcinoma is the most common variety in this case. Workers of the furniture industry or woodworkers develop adenocarcinoma. It is most commonly found in the ethmoid sinuses and upper nasal cavity. Workers engaged in nickel refining may develop squamous cell carcinoma and anaplastic carcinoma.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is an early feature of maxillary carcinoma?
explanation: Blood-tinged nasal discharge is an early feature of maxillary carcinoma. Other early features include: Nasal stuffiness Facial paraesthesias Pain Epiphora. These symptoms may be missed or simply treated as sinusitis. Option B: Lymphatic spread occurs in the late stages of the disease. Among the cervical lymph nodes, submandibular and upper jugular lymph nodes are enlarged. Option C: Proptosis is a late feature that occurs after the invasion of the orbit. Option D: Dental pain is a late feature that occurs due to expansion of the alveolus after the tumor spreads inferiorly.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following conditions is classified using Ohngren’s classification?
explanation: Ohngren’s classification is used for maxillary carcinoma. An imaginary plane is drawn, extending between medial canthus of eye and the angle of mandible. Ohngren's line(below image): Growths situated above this plane (suprastructural) have a poorer prognosis than those below it (infrastructural).
subject: ENT

question_text: A 43-year-old factory worker presents to you with nasal obstruction, cheek swelling, and diplopia. The ENT resident suspects maxillary carcinoma and uses the following image to classify the same. Which one of the following classification systems are used?
explanation: Ledermann’s classification is used to classify maxillary carcinoma in this case. It uses two horizontal lines of Sebileau; one passing through the floors of orbits and the other through floors of antra.
subject: ENT

question_text: You have a patient with maxillary sinus carcinoma. Which of the following lymph nodes will be most commonly involved?
explanation: The submandibular and jugulodigastric nodes are the most commonly involved in maxillary sinus carcinoma. Maxillary and ethmoid sinus drain primarily into retropharyngeal nodes but, these nodes are inaccessible for palpation.
subject: ENT

question_text:
In a known case of maxillary carcinoma, histopathology of the surgically resected region shows that the tumor has eroded into the floor and medial wall of the orbit and the frontal sinus. Which of the following is the best management strategy?
Surgery
explanation: Radiotherapy is preferred here, as in this case surgery has already been performed. The tumor staging is T4 by AJCC classification. T3 and T4 lesions are treated by combined modalities of radiation and surgery. Radiation in such cases may be given preoperatively or postoperatively. T1 and T2 lesions without nodal or distant metastasis are treated with surgery or radiation with equal results. Stag e Description T1 Tumour restricted to maxilla ry sinusmucosa T2 Bony erosion- extension into hard palate or middle meatus, except posterior wall and pte rygoid plates Stag Description e Stag Description e T3 Invasion intosuprastructures such as:Posterior wall of max illary sinusSubcutaneous tiss uesFloor or medial wall of or bitPterygoid fossaEthmoid si nus T4a Tumour invades any of the fo llowing:Anteriororbital conte ntsThe skin of the nose or ch eekInfratemporal fossaPteryg oid platesCribriform plateSp henoid or frontal sinuses T4b Tumour invades any of the fo llowing:Orbital apexBrain/du raMiddle cranial fossaNasop harynx Sinusitis and its Complication
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is the most common cause of sinusitis?
explanation: Nasal infections are the most common cause of sinusitis since sinus mucosa is a continuation of nasal mucosa and infections from the nose can travel directly by continuity or by way of submucosal lymphatics. The most common cause of acute sinusitis is viral rhinitis followed by bacterial invasion. Other causes: Dental infections cause maxillary sinus infections. Trauma Swimming and diving.
subject: ENT

question_text: Identify the most common sinus involved in sinusitis in adults.
explanation: The structure marked 4 is the maxillary sinus and is the most common sinus involved in acute sinusitis in adults. Order of frequency of sinuses involved in acute sinusitis in adults is maxillary > ethmoid > frontal > sphenoid.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient with sinusitis is least likely to present with which of the following symptoms?
explanation: Diplopia is least likely to be seen in sinusitis. Patients with sinusitis typically present with a dull throbbing headache which worsens on moving the head or bending forward, nasal discharge and blockage, & constitutional symptoms like fever, general malaise and bodyache. Option A: Occipital headache can be seen in sphenoid sinusitis. Option B: Eyelid edema can be seen in frontal and ethmoidal sinusitis. Option D: Post-nasal drip and nasal discharge is a common finding in sinusitis.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 28-year-old IT professional with a recent history of upper respiratory tract infection has a headache that worsens during office hours. The headache comes upon waking, tends to be at its worst by about midday and improves as the day progresses. This characteristic periodicity is seen in?
explanation: Headache in frontal sinusitis shows characteristic periodicity, i.e. comes upon waking, gradually increases, reaches its peak by about midday, and then starts subsiding. It is also called office headache because of its presence only during office hours.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is the most common sinusitis in children?
explanation: The ethmoid sinus is the most common sinus involved in pediatric sinusitis. It usually occurs when the infection spreads through the lamina papyracea.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 12-year-old child diagnosed with sphenoid sinusitis was brought to the hospital with complaints of a fever and headache. The headache would most likely be localised to?
explanation: Headache in sphenoid sinusitis is localized to occiput or vertex. Frontal headache is seen in maxillary and frontal sinusitis. Headache in frontal sinusitis has characteristic periodicity.
subject: ENT

question_text: A middle-aged man with a history of recurrent episodes of sinusitis for two years presented with complaints of a dull aching pain over his cheek, persistent nasal obstruction which worsens at night and an urge to constantly clear his throat. Which of the following anterior rhinoscopy findings is pathognomonic of the condition?
explanation: The given clinical history is suggestive of chronic maxillary sinusitis. Mucoid or mucopurulent discharge in the middle meatus seen on anterior rhinoscopy is a pathognomonic finding in chronic maxillary sinusitis. Other signs include mucosal edema primarily in the middle meatus as well as polyps. Clinically, patients present with nasal blockage, congestion, postnasal drip, reduced olfaction, and facial pain or pressure. On CT, mucosal changes within the osteomeatal complex and sinuses may be seen.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 21-year-old female patient presented with fever, headache and, hawking sensation. Suspecting severe sinusitis, you order an X-ray of the PNS. Which view would be best in capturing all the paranasal sinuses in a single film?
explanation: The lateral view shows all the paranasal sinuses in a single film. The lateral side of the skull lies against the film, and an X-ray beam is projected perpendicular to the other side. Structures seen are: Anterior and posterior extent of the sphenoid, frontal sinus Maxillary sinuses Ethmoid sinuses Sella turcica Alveolar process Condyle and neck of the mandible. Note: Though all the abnormalities and diagnoses of Paranasal sinuses cannot be concluded through the lateral view alone, the lateral view radiographically covers all the sinuses in the same view.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient with deviated nasal septum presents with a headache that starts upon waking and reaches its peak by about midday. On examination, she has upper eyelid oedema and tenderness on pressing just above the medial canthus. Which of the following X-ray views is preferred to best evaluate the sinus involved?
explanation: The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of frontal sinusitis. The best view for evaluating the frontal sinus is Caldwell's view. It is also known as occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position. Structures seen are: Frontal sinuses Ethmoid sinuses Maxillary sinuses Frontal process of the zygoma and the zygomatic process of the frontal bone Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea Superior orbital fissure Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure)
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is used to make a definitive diagnosis of sinusitis?
explanation: Diagnostic nasal endoscopy findings are used to confirm the diagnosis of sinusitis. Indications of diagnostic nasal endoscopy: To diagnose any disease of the nose and PNS To find the source of bleeding in epistaxis To assess response to medical or surgical treatment of the nose and PNS disease To take a precise biopsy from the nose and nasopharynx
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following complications would you not expect to see in a patient diagnosed with sinusitis?
explanation: Soft palate paralysis is not a known complication of sinusitis. Complications of paranasal sinus infection: Loca Mucocele/Mucopyocele Mucous retention cyst Osteomyelitis - Frontal bone (more common), maxilla Orbita Preseptal inflammatory oedema of lids Subperiosteal abscess Orbital cellulitis Orbital abscess Superior orbital fissure syndrome Orbital apex syndrome Intracrania Meningitis Extradural abscess Subdural abscess Brain abscess Cavernous sinus thrombosis Descending infections Focal infections
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is the most common complication following acute rhinosinusitis?
explanation: Orbital cellulitis is the most common complication following acute rhinosinusitis. Complications of acute rhinosinusitis are typically classified as orbital (60–75 per cent), intracranial (15–20 per cent) and osseous (5–10 per cent), and local and descending infections.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 60-year-old lady presents with pain and swelling around the left upper eyelid region, diplopia and a headache. She gives a history of recurrent episodes of rhinosinusitis in the past. On examination, there is a downward, and outward deviation of the eyeball & the most prominent part of the swelling has a punctum with a mucopurulent discharge, just above the upper eyelid. Which of the following sinuses is most commonly involved in this complication?
explanation: The given clinical history and findings are suggestive of a mucocele secondary to frontal sinusitis. The frontal sinus is most commonly involved in mucocele formation. The sinuses commonly affected by mucocele in the order of frequency are the frontal>ethmoidal>maxillary>sphenoid The image given below shows a coronal MRI demonstrating a frontal mucocele and an orbital cystic mass.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following statements is false about mucoceles?
options: Frontal sinus is most commonly involved
Presents as a cystic swelling in the superomedial quadrant
Eyeball is pushed downwards, forwards and medially
explanation: Eyeballs are pushed downwards, forwards and laterally. Option A: Frontal sinus is most commonly involved in mucocele. Option B: It presents as a cystic swelling in the superomedial quadrant of orbit. Option D: Treatment is frontoethmoidectomy with free drainage of the frontal sinus into the middle meatus.
subject: ENT

question_text: A young man was referred to the maxillofacial surgeon with complaints of pain and tenderness over the left cheek, inability to move the left eye, and numbness over the left forehead. He gave a history of chronic sinusitis for two years. Superior orbital fissure syndrome was suspected. Which of the following nerves is least likely to be involved in this condition?
explanation: The maxillary division of trigeminal nerve does not pass through the superior orbital fissure and thus, is the least likely nerve to be involved in this condition. Superior orbital fissure syndrome is characterized by the compression of cranial nerves III, IV, VI, and ophthalmic division of V. The superior orbital fissure lies between the greater and lesser wings of the sphenoid. The structures passing through include cranial nerves III, IV, VI, the ophthalmic branch of V, and the superior ophthalmic vein. Orbital apex syndrome is superior orbital fissure syndrome with additional involvement of optic nerve and maxillary division of trigeminal nerve.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following statements is not true?
options: Osteomyelitis of maxilla is more common in children
Osteomyelitis of frontal bone is more common in adults
Ethmoidal sinusitis spreads through lamina papyracea
Pott’s puffy tumor is related to osteomyelitis of maxilla
explanation: Pott's puffy tumor refers to osteomyelitis of the frontal bone with the development of a subperiosteal abscess manifesting as a puffy swelling on the forehead or scalp. It usually occurs as a complication of frontal sinusitis. Option A: Osteomyelitis of the maxilla is more often seen in infants and children than adults because of the presence of spongy bone in the anterior wall of the maxilla. Option B: Osteomyelitis of frontal bone is more often seen in adults as frontal sinus is not developed in infants and children. Option C: Ethmoidal sinusitis spreads through lamina papyracea
subject: ENT

question_text: A middle-aged patient with a history of recurrent upper respiratory tract infections presents with diplopia and protrusion of the left eyeball. Inflammation of which of the following paranasal sinuses would most likely lead to this complication?
explanation: The given clinical vignette is suggestive of orbital complications secondary to sinusitis. The orbit and its contents are closely related to the ethmoid, frontal, and maxillary sinuses, but most of the complications, however, follow infection of ethmoids as they are separated from the orbit only by a thin lamina of bone called lamina papyracea.
subject: ENT

question_text: A procedure that involves puncturing and irrigating the sinus is planned for a patient with a history of chronic sinusitis. For which of the following paranasal sinuses is this procedure performed?
explanation: Proof puncture or antral lavage involves puncturing the medial wall of maxillary sinus in the region of inferior meatus to allow for irrigation and drainage of the sinus. It is called proof puncture, as the presence of an infection can be proven during the procedure.
subject: ENT

question_text: In which of the following conditions is antral lavage not indicated?
explanation: In acute maxillary sinusitis, antral lavage is actually contraindicated for the risk of osteomyelitis. Antral lavage is usually done therapeutically to remove pus and diagnostically for confirmation of chronic maxillary sinusitis. It can also be done to collect the specimen of the antral contents for culture and sensitivity, or cytological examination to exclude early malignancy.
subject: ENT

question_text: While performing a therapeutic antral lavage of the maxillary sinus, the patient developed a fatal complication. He stopped breathing, the colour of his face became ashen grey, and the pupils became dilated. Attempts to resuscitate the patient were futile, and he was declared dead after 20 minutes. Which of the following could be the most likely cause?
explanation: Air embolism is a rare but fatal complication that can occur during antral lavage through the veins that are damaged during the puncture. This complication can be prevented by avoiding the insufflation of air into the antrum after lavage.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following sinuses is accessed via the Caldwell-Luc approach?
explanation: Caldwell–Luc operation is a surgery where the maxillary antrum is opened through canine fossa by sublabial approach and pathology inside the antrum dealt with.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following structures is pierced while creating a nasoantral window in Caldwell Luc operation?
explanation: Nasoantral window of <1.5cm in diameter is created through the inferior meatus.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is the most common complication of Caldwell Luc operation?
explanation: The most common complication of Caldwell Luc operation is infraorbital nerve injury. Paraesthesia due to damage of the infraorbital nerve may be temporary or permanent and is reported in 21% of cases.
subject: ENT

question_text: What does FESS stand for?
explanation: FESS stands for Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery. FESS is a minimally invasive procedure that uses nasal endoscopes to enlarge the nasal drainage pathways of the paranasal sinuses to improve sinus ventilation and allow access to topical medications.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following conditions is not an indication for functional endoscopic sinus surgery?
explanation: Cavernous sinus thrombosis is not an indication for functional endoscopic sinus surgery(FESS). Indications of FESS: Chronic bacterial sinusitis unresponsive to adequate medical treatment Recurrent acute bacterial sinusitis Fungal sinusitis with fungal ba Nasal polyps Mucocele Control of epistaxis Removal of foreign body from the nose or sinus Barotrauma sinusitis (pain in the face during descent in aircraft or descent whilst scuba diving)
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following conditions is a contraindication for endoscopic sinus surgery?
explanation: Acute rhinosinusitis with epidural abscess is a contraindication for functional endoscopic sinus surgery. The endoscopic approach is contraindicated in the presence of an intracranial complication of acute infection such as: Meningitis Subperiosteal abscess Epidural abscess Cavernous sinus thrombosis Any visual loss Note: Endoscopic sinus surgery is indicated in chronic bacterial rhinosinusitis, allergic fungal sinusitis with mycetoma and repair of cerebrospinal fluid leak.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following structures cannot be accessed by performing an endoscopic nasal surgery?
explanation: Cerebellum cannot be accessed by performing endoscopic nasal surgery. Apart from the nose and paranasal sinuses, endoscopic surgery can be used to access the orbit, optic nerve, lacrimal sac, and pituitary gland. Indications of advanced nasal endoscopic techniques: Removal of benign tumors, e.g. inverted papillomas or angiofibromas Orbital abscess or cellulitis management. Dacryocystorhinostomy Repair of CSF leak Pituitary surgery Optic nerve decompression Orbital decompression for Graves’ disease Control of posterior epistaxis (endoscopic clipping of sphenopalatine artery) Choanal atresia
subject: ENT

question_text: A 45-year-old-man with a history of chronic sinusitis unresponsive to medications is planned for functional endoscopic sinus surgery. Which of the following is the first step in the procedure?
explanation: Uncinectomy where uncinate process is incised with sickle knife and removed with Blakesley forceps is the first definitive surgical step in FESS.
subject: ENT

question_text: You are a third-year ENT resident performing a functional endoscopic sinus surgery on a patient diagnosed with chronic maxillary sinusitis. During the procedure, the lateral wall of the infundibulum is punctured adjacent to the maxillary sinus ostium. Why is this step done?
explanation: Infundibulotomy, also known as uncinectomy, is the first surgical step in FESS and it is done to approach the middle meatus.
subject: ENT

question_text: Water’s view is used to best visualize which of the following sinuses?
explanation: Water’s view is used to best visualize the maxillary sinus. Frontal and ethmoidal sinuses can also be visualized. Sphenoid sinus can be seen in Water's view with open mouth. It is also known as the occipitomental view. The X-ray beam is angled at 37°-45° to the orbitomeatal line. The recommended imaging views for different sinuses are as follows: Ethmoidal sinus: Rheese's view Frontal sinus: Caldwell's view Sphenoid sinus: Hirtz view
subject: ENT

question_text:
The radiograph shown below is done for better assessment of the frontal sinus. What is the common name of this view?

Water’s view
explanation: The frontal sinus is best seen in Caldwell's view (occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position). The structures seen in Caldwell's view include: Frontal sinuses (seen best) Ethmoid sinuses Maxillary sinuses Frontal process of the zygoma and the zygomatic process of the frontal bone Superior margin of the orbit and lamina papyracea Superior orbital fissure Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbital fissure) The nose and forehead are touching the X-ray film and the X-ray beam is projected 15° caudally in Caldwell's view. Other options: Option A: Water's view (occipitomental view or nose-chin position) is a radiographic view where an X-ray beam is angled at 45° to the orbitomeatal line. Structures seen are the maxillary sinus (best seen), sphenoid sinus (if the film is taken with an open mouth), frontal sinus, zygoma, zygomatic arch, nasal bone, and infratemporal fossa. Option C: Pierre's view is the occipitomental with an open mouth. It helps in visualizing the sphenoid sinus as well, in addition to the sinuses that can be seen in water's view. Option D: Towne's view is an angled anteroposterior radiograph of the skull. Structures seen are the petrous part of the pyramids, arcuate eminence, superior semicircular canal, mastoid antrum, internal auditory canal, tympanic cavity, cochlea, and external auditory canal. This view is taken for acoustic neuroma and apical petrositis. Anatomy and Physiology of Pharynx
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the lower limit of the pharynx?
explanation: The pharynx extends from the base of the skull (basiocciput and basisphenoid) to the lower border of the cricoid cartilage. It continues as the oesophagus. Pharynx is a 12-14cm long conical fibromuscular tube forming the common upper part of the air and food passages.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 55-year-old man is diagnosed with carcinoma limited to the hypopharynx. Which of the following sites will not be involved?
explanation: Epiglottis is part of the supraglottic larynx. The hypopharynx is made of 3 parts: Pyriform sinus Posterior Pharyngeal Wall Post-cricoid region
subject: ENT

question_text: On oral examination of a patient with recurrent upper respiratory tract infection, you notice that the Waldeyer’s group of lymph nodes is enlarged. Which of the following is not included in Waldeyer’s group of lymph nodes?
explanation: The submandibular group of lymph nodes is not included as a part of Waldeyer’s ring. Scattered throughout the pharynx in its subepithelial layer is the lymphoid tissue which is aggregated at places to form masses, collectively called Waldeyer’s ring. The masses are: Adenoids or nasopharyngeal tonsils Palatine tonsils or simply tonsils Lingual tonsils Tubal tonsils Lateral pharyngeal bands Nodules in the posterior pharyngeal wall
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is not a part of MALT structures?
explanation: MALT stands for mucosal associated lymphoid tissue. Retropharyngeal lymph nodes are not a part of it. The rest of the structures are a part of Waldeyer’s ring.
subject: ENT

question_text: You are the junior resident in the ENT department performing a posterior rhinoscopy procedure on a patient. Where will you locate the pharyngeal opening of the eustachian tube?
options: 2.25cm behind posterior end of the inferior turbinate
1.25cm behind posterior end of the inferior turbinate
2.25cm behind posterior end of the middle turbinate
1.25cm behind posterior end of the middle turbinate
explanation: The pharyngeal opening of the eustachian tube is situated in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx 1.25cm behind the posterior end of the inferior turbinate.
subject: ENT

question_text: You are observing a tissue sample from the nasopharynx through an electron microscope. Which of the following epithelium will you see?
explanation: The nasopharynx is lined by pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium. Functionally, it is the posterior extension of the nasal cavity. Other parts of the pharynx are lined by stratified squamous epithelium.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is the most common site for nasopharyngeal carcinoma?
explanation: Fossa of Rossenmuller is the most common site for carcinoma in the nasopharynx.
subject: ENT

question_text:
A 50-year-old man has been diagnosed with nasopharyngeal carcinoma which has spread to the sinus of Morgagni. Which of the following structures is least likely to be affected due to
the spread into this space?
explanation: Descending pharyngeal artery does not pass through the sinus of Morgagni and hence least likely to be affected. All the other options are contents of the sinus of Morgagni. The sinus of Morgagni is a space between the base of the skull and the upper free border of the superior constrictor muscle. The structures passing through the space are: Eustachian tube Levator veli palatini Tensor veli palatini Ascending palatine artery- branch of the facial artery Trotter's triad or sinus of Morgagni syndrome is seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma which spreads laterally to involve the sinus of Morgagni. It is characterized by: Conductive hearing loss Ipsilateral immobility of the palate Neuralgic pain
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following structures is present in the oropharynx?
explanation: Lingual tonsils are lymphoid tissues seen in the base of the tongue, hence a part of the oropharynx. Oropharynx includes: Base of tongue Palatine tonsils Vallecula Anterior and posterior pillars Posterior pharyngeal wall The pharyngeal end of the pharyngotympanic tube and fossa of Rosenmuller is present in the lateral wall of the nasopharynx. The pyriform fossa is a part of the hypopharynx.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 50-year-old man has been diagnosed with oropharyngeal carcinoma. Which of the following group of lymph nodes does the sentinel node belong to?
explanation: The jugulodigastric node is the sentinel lymph node and belongs to the level 2 group of lymph nodes. This is the node enlarged in both tonsillitis and base of tongue carcinoma as lymphatics from the oropharynx drain into the upper jugular chain. Level Lymph node 1a Submental 1b Submandibular 2 Upper jugular 3 Middle jugular 4 Lower jugular 5 Posterior triangle 6 Anterior group 7 Mediastinal
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following muscles form the Passavant’s ridge?
explanation: Passavant’s ridge is a mucosal ridge raised by the fibers of the palatopharyngeus. It encircles the posterior and lateral walls of nasopharyngeal isthmus. Soft palate, during its contraction makes firm contact with the ridge to cut off nasopharynx from the oropharynx during deglutition or speech.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 30-year-old woman suffering from iron deficiency anemia presents to you with difficulty in swallowing. On examination, glossitis and cheilitis are observed. There are oesophageal webs seen on direct laryngoscopy. Which of the following is the most common site for carcinoma to develop in this patient?
explanation: The given clinical picture is suggestive of a diagnosis of Plummer-Vinson syndrome. The post-cricoid region is a common site for carcinoma in women suffering from Plummer-Vinson syndrome. Plummer-Vinson syndrome/ Patterson Kelly Brown syndrome is a condition that can occur in people with long-term (chronic) iron deficiency anemia. The triad seen in these patients: Post cricoid webs Glossitis Angular cheilitis Post cricoid region is the part of the anterior wall of the laryngopharynx between the upper and lower borders of the cricoid lamina.
subject: ENT

question_text:
A 30-year-old man presents to you with a foreign body sensation in his throat. On examination, you notice the impaction of a fishbone in his pyriform sinus. Which group of lymph nodes will you find enlarged in case of its infection?
Upper deep cervical nodes
explanation: Pyriform sinus is richly supplied by lymphatics and drains into the upper deep cervical group of lymph nodes. The lymphatics exit through the thyrohyoid membrane to drain into the upper jugular chain. Pyriform sinus lies on either side of the larynx and extends from the pharyngoepiglottic fold to the upper end of the esophagus. It forms the lateral channel for food. The rich lymphatic network of pyriform fossa explains the high frequency of nodal metastasis seen in carcinoma of this region. Adenoids
subject: ENT

question_text: What are adenoids also known as?
explanation: Adenoids are commonly known as nasopharyngeal tonsil. It is situated at the junction of the roof and posterior wall of the nasopharynx.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following statements is false about the structure marked as A?
options: It is part of the Waldeyer's ring
Hypertrophies up to the age of 6 years and starts to regress from puberty
It is surrounded by a capsule
explanation: The structure marked A is the adenoids. It is not surrounded by a capsule. Adenoids are comprised of vertical ridges of lymphoid tissues separated by deep clefts. They form the superior aspect of Waldeyer's ring. They have no crypts and no capsule, unlike palatine tonsils which have both. It is present at birth, enlarges up to the age of 6 years, and then starts regressing from puberty. It completely disappears by the age of 20 years.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is not included in the signs and symptoms of the condition represented below?
explanation: The given x-ray shows enlarged adenoids and suggests the diagnosis of adenoid hypertrophy. Patients show an absent nasolabial fold. Clinical features: Nasal obstruction is the most common symptom. This leads to mouth breathing. Nasal bstruction also interferes with feeding or suckling in a child. As respiration and feeding cannot take place simultaneously, a child with adenoid enlargement fails to thrive. Nasal discharge, sinusitis, and epistaxis. Bilateral conductive hearing loss and serous otitis media due to eustachian tube obstruction. Rhinolalia clausa - hyponasal voice. Adenoid facies - elongated face with a dull expression, pinched up nose, absent nasolabial crease, pen mouth, prominent and crowded upper teeth. Sleep apnoea - chronic cases lead to hypoxemia and pulmonary vasoconstriction. This consequently leads to pulmonary hypertension and cor pulmonale. Aprosexia - lack of concentration.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to you by her mother with complaints of mouth breathing. She has a flat, expressionless long face with an open mouth. On examination, a high arched palate and crowded upper teeth are noted. What is the voice abnormality that can be noted in this child?
explanation: The given clinical picture of a child with adenoid facies is suggestive of a diagnosis of adenoid hypertrophy. Rhinolalia clausa/ hyponasal voice can be seen in these patients. It is also seen in conditions like common cold, nasal allergy, etc. Option A - Hot potato voice is a muffled and thick speech often seen in a peritonsillar abscess (quinsy). Option C - Rhinolalia aperta causes a hypernasal voice. Option D - Staccato voice or scanning speech is a broken speech seen in cerebellar lesions as well as multiple sclerosis.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 5-year-old child is brought by his mother to the ENT OPD with frequent upper respiratory tract infections. His mother gives a history of loud snoring at night and posterior rhinoscopy examination shows enlarged adenoids. Which of the following will you not advise in the management of this patient?
explanation: Beta 2 agonists have no role in conditions of upper airway obstruction like adenoid hypertrophy. They are bronchodilators used in lower airway obstructive diseases. When symptoms of adenoid hypertrophy are not marked, breathing exercises, decongestant nasal drops, and antihistamines for any coexisting nasal allergy can cure the condition without resorting to surgery. Marked adenoid hypertrophy with associated complications can be treated with adenoidectomy and grommet insertion.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is not an indication for an adenoidectomy procedure?
options: Recurrent middle ear infections with deafness
explanation: Multiple adenoids is not an indication for adenoidectomy. Indications of adenoidectomy: Adenoid hypertrophy causing snoring, mouth breathing, sleep apnoea syndrome or speech abnormalities, i.e. (rhinolalia clausa) Recurrent rhinosinusitis Chronic otitis media with effusion associated with adenoid hyperplasia Recurrent ear discharge in benign CSOM associated with adenoiditis/adenoid hyperplasia Dental malocclusion. Adenoidectomy does not correct dental abnormalities but will prevent its recurrence after orthodontic treatment
subject: ENT

question_text: A 6-year-old child has been posted for an adenoidectomy procedure. Which of the following conditions if present in this child will be a contraindication to performing the surgery?
explanation: Cleft palate is a contraindication to perform adenoidectomy as removal of adenoids causes velopharyngeal insufficiency. Velopharyngeal insufficiency is a condition where the soft palate does not close tightly against the back of the throat. This leads to air coming out the nose (characterized by hypernasality) during speech. Contraindications for adenoidectomy: Cleft palate or submucous palate. Hemorrhagic diathesis. Acute infection of the upper respiratory tract.
subject: ENT

question_text: A school-going child presents with a history of recurrent upper respiratory tract infections, mouth breathing, and impaired hearing. On examination, a high arched palate is noted. What is the management of this condition?
explanation: The given clinical picture is suggestive of adenoid hypertrophy. The best line of management is adenoidectomy with grommet insertion. A grommet is inserted to provide continued aeration of middle ear and used in cases where fluid collection recurs.
subject: ENT

question_text: An 8-year-old boy diagnosed with adenoid hypertrophy has undergone an adenoidectomy procedure. Two weeks following the procedure, he developed Grisel syndrome. What is the reason for this condition?
explanation: Grisel syndrome involves paraspinal muscle spasm that occurs post adenoidectomy. Grisel syndrome refers to non-traumatic atlantoaxial joint subluxation. The patient complains of neck pain and develops torticollis. It is mostly due to spasm of paraspinal muscles but can also be due to atlantoaxial dislocation requiring cervical collar and even traction.
subject: ENT

question_text: Where is Thornwaldt cyst located?
explanation: Thornwaldt cyst is located in the midline of the posterior wall of the nasopharynx in the adenoid mass. It is an epithelial-lined median recess found within the adenoid mass and extends from pharyngeal mucosa to the periosteum of the basiocciput. It represents the attachment of notochord to the pharyngeal endoderm during embryonic life. When infected, it may be the cause of persistent postnasal discharge or crusting. Sometimes an abscess can form in the bursa (Thornwaldt’s disease). It is managed surgically by marsupialization of the swelling and complete removal of the lining of the cyst.
subject: ENT

question_text:
A 30-year-old patient has a Thornwaldt abscess that got infected from a Thornwaldt’s cyst. Which of the following will you not recommend for the treatment of his condition?
Antibiotics
explanation: Antitubercular treatment has no role in the treatment of Thornwaldt’s abscess. Thornwaldt’s abscess is formed due to the infection of Thornwaldt cyst. Treatment includes administration of antibiotics to treat the infection and marsupialization of the cystic swelling. There should be adequate removal of its lining membrane. Tonsils
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about tonsils?
options: Bed of the tonsil is formed by the superior constrictor and styloglossus muscles.
It is covered by keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium on the medial surface.
Crypta magna is a remnant of the ventral part of second pharyngeal pouch.
A capsule covers the lateral surface of the tonsils.
explanation: The medial surface of the tonsil is covered by non-keratinizing stratified squamous epithelium. Tonsils are ovoid masses of lymphoid tissue situated in the lateral wall of the oropharynx between the anterior and posterior pillars. The medial surface of the tonsil is covered in 12-15 crypts. Crypta magna or intratonsillar cleft is the largest & deepest of the crypts. It is situated near the upper part of the tonsil and represents the ventral part of the second pharyngeal pouch. The lateral surface of the tonsil presents a well-defined fibrous capsule. The bed of the tonsil is formed by the superior constrictor and styloglossus muscles.
subject: ENT

question_text: At what age do the tonsils attain their maximum size?
explanation: The growth of tonsils is rapid around the age of 5-6 years of age and usually reaches their maximum size by 12 years of age. Tonsillar involution begins at puberty when the reactive lymphoid tissue begins to atrophy, and by old age, only a little tonsillar lymphoid tissue remains.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient diagnosed with oral carcinoma was referred to the ENT department for evaluation. While examining the oral cavity, the consultant asked you to examine the ENT surgeon’s graveyard to check for any induration or ulcers. What is the area being referred to here?
explanation: The area referred to here is the tonsillolingual sulcus which is known as the graveyard of ENT surgeons. The palatine tonsil is separated from the tongue by a sulcus called the tonsillolingual sulcus, which may be the seat of carcinoma. This area is easily missed during oral examination hence known as the graveyard of ENT surgeons.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is the main arterial supply of palatine tonsils?
options: Tonsillar branch of the facial artery
Descending palatine branch of maxillary artery
Ascending palatine branch of facial artery
explanation: The main arterial supply of tonsil is by the tonsillar branch of the facial artery. Five arteries supply the tonsil: Tonsillar branch of the facial artery (the main artery) Ascending palatine branch of the facial artery Ascending pharyngeal branch of the external carotid artery Dorsal lingual branches of the lingual artery Descending palatine branches of the maxillary artery
subject: ENT

question_text: You are the second-year ENT resident performing tonsillectomy in a patient with chronic tonsillitis. While creating a dissection plane between the capsule and the bed of the tonsil, you accidentally deepened the incision, injuring the tonsillar bed. Which of the following structures is least likely to be injured?
explanation: The lateral pterygoid muscle is not related to the bed of the tonsil and is the least likely structure to be injured in this scenario. The bed of the tonsil is formed by the superior constrictor and styloglossus muscles. The lower fossa is related to: The glossopharyngeal nerve The styloid process Outside the superior constrictor, the tonsil is related to: The facial artery Submandibular salivary gland Posterior belly of the digastric muscle Medial pterygoid muscle The angle of the mandible
subject: ENT

question_text: A 7-year-old child was brought to the hospital by his mother with complaints of a sore throat, earache, and pain on swallowing for three days. On examination, the tonsils were enlarged and hyperaemic. Which of the following is the most common organism implicated in this condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute tonsillitis. The most common organism causing acute tonsillitis in children is  hemolytic streptococcus. Other causative organisms include: Staphylococcus aureus Streptococcus pneumoniae Haemophilus influenzae
subject: ENT

question_text: A young lady presents to the ENT OPD with the finding shown below. Which of the following group of lymph nodes will primarily enlarge in this condition?
explanation: The image shows purulent inflammation of the tonsils suggestive of acute tonsillitis. Jugulo-digastric (tonsillar) lymph nodes will primarily enlarge in this condition. The lymphatics from the palatine tonsils pierce the superior constrictor muscle and primarily drain into the upper deep cervical nodes (level II), particularly the jugulo-digastric (tonsillar) node situated below the angle of the mandible. So, it is the most likely group of lymph nodes to enlarge in case of acute tonsillitis.
subject: ENT

question_text: A middle-aged man presented with a history of fever, sore throat, and dysphagia for three days. Which of the following variants is not expected to be seen on oral examination?
explanation: The patient's history is suggestive of acute tonsillitis. The fibroid variety is a type of chronic tonsillitis and is not expected to be seen in this case. Depending on the pathology within the tonsillar tissue, acute tonsillitis can be classified into the following types: Acute catarrhal or superficial tonsillitis: Here tonsillitis is a part of generalized pharyngitis and is primarily seen in viral infections. Acute follicular tonsillitis: The infection spreads into the crypts, which become filled with purulent material, presenting at the openings of crypts as yellowish spots. Acute parenchymatous tonsillitis: Here tonsil substance is affected. Tonsil is uniformly enlarged and red. Acute membranous tonsillitis: It is a stage ahead of acute follicular tonsillitis when exudation from the crypts coalesces to form a membrane on the surface of the tonsil. Types of chronic tonsillitis: Chronic follicular tonsillitis Chronic parenchymal tonsillitis Chronic fibroid tonsillitis
subject: ENT

question_text: An anxious mother brought her 4-year-old-child to the hospital with complaints of sudden onset fever and refusal to eat. On examination, the given finding was noted and he was started on analgesics and antibiotics. Which among the following is not a known complication of this condition?
explanation: The given clinical vignette is suggestive of acute tonsillitis. Excessive bleeding is not a known complication of this condition. Complications of acute tonsillitis: Chronic tonsillitis - chronic infection may persist in lymphoid follicles of the tonsil in the form of microabscesses Peritonsillar abscess Parapharyngeal abscess Cervical abscess due to suppuration of jugulodigastric lymph nodes Acute otitis media Rheumatic fever - often seen in association with tonsillitis due to group A -hemolytic streptococci Acute glomerulonephritis (rare) Subacute bacterial endocarditis - acute tonsillitis in a patient with valvular heart disease may be complicated by endocarditis. It is usually due to Streptococcus viridans infection
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following nerves is responsible for referred otalgia from tonsillitis?
explanation: The tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) is responsible for referred otalgia from tonsillitis. The tonsils and tonsillar fossa are supplied by the glossopharyngeal nerve. The glossopharyngeal nerve and the styloid process lie in relation to the lower part of the tonsillar fossa. Therefore, any irritation or pain can be referred to the ear along the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal (Jacobson's) nerve. Causes of referred otalgia via the glossopharyngeal nerve include acute pharyngitis, tonsillitis, peritonsillar abscess, post-tonsillectomy, foreign bodies embedded in the base of the tongue or tonsillar area and an elongated styloid process (Eagle's syndrome). The ear receives extensive sensory innervation via four cranial nerves (V, VII, IX, and X) and two spinal segments (C2 and C3). The image below shows the anatomic relations of the tonsil and tonsillar bed:
subject: ENT

question_text: A 15-year-old girl presented to the ENT surgeon with a history of loud snoring, restless sleep leading to daytime somnolence, and poor academic performance. Her medical history was unremarkable, except for recurrent episodes of acute tonsillitis. Which of the following types of tonsillitis may be implicated in this condition?
explanation: The given clinical presentation is suggestive of obstructive sleep apnea syndrome(OSAS) secondary to chronic parenchymatous tonsillitis. In parenchymatous tonsillitis, the tonsils grow very large following repeated attacks of acute tonsillitis and lead to obstructive symptoms, including OSAS. Types of chronic tonsillitis: Chronic follicular tonsillitis- tonsillar crypts are full of infected cheesy material, which shows on the surface as yellowish spots. Chronic parenchymatous tonsillitis- there is hyperplasia of lymphoid tissue. Tonsils are very much enlarged and may interfere with speech, deglutition, and respiration. Attacks of sleep apnoea may occur. Long-standing cases develop features of cor pulmonale. Chronic fibroid tonsillitis- tonsils are tiny but infected, with a history of repeated sore throats.
subject: ENT

question_text: You are an intern posted in the ENT department working up a case of chronic follicular tonsillitis. Which of the following clinical signs would you not expect to see in this patient on examining the oral cavity?
explanation: Müller's sign is the pulsation of uvula during systole seen in aortic regurgitation. It is not seen in patients with chronic tonsillitis. The classical signs of chronic tonsillitis are: Irwin-Moore sign- tonsils are tiny, but pressure on the anterior pillar expresses frank pus or cheesy material. Bluish Flushing of anterior pillars compared to the rest of the pharyngeal mucosa is a vital sign of chronic tonsillar infection. Enlargement of jugulo-digastric lymph nodes even in the absence of acute infection is a reliable sign of chronic tonsillitis. During acute attacks, the nodes enlarge further and become tender.
subject: ENT

question_text: An ENT junior resident observed a symptomless yellowish swelling over the tonsil when he was examining a patient for a buccal sore. The swelling was easily drained. What is the likely diagnosis?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a tonsillar cyst. It is a condition due to blockage of a tonsillar crypt and appears as a yellowish swelling over the tonsil. Very often, it is symptomless and can be easily drained. Option A: Intratonsillar abscess is an accumulation of pus within the substance of the tonsil. It usually follows a blockage of the opening of the crypt in acute follicular tonsillitis. There is marked local pain and dysphagia. Tonsil appears swollen and red. Option B: Tonsilloliths (calculus of the tonsil) are seen in chronic tonsillitis when its crypt is blocked with retention of debris. Inorganic salts of calcium and magnesium are then deposited leading to the formation of a stone. It may gradually enlarge and then ulcerate through the tonsil. It generally causes local discomfort or foreign body sensation. Option D: In follicular tonsillitis, purulent material is present at the opening of the crypts as yellow dots. It presents with fever, dysphagia, and sore throat.
subject: ENT

question_text: On examining the oral cavity of a patient who presented with fever and a sore throat, you notice a greyish-white membrane over the tonsils. Which of the following conditions would you not consider as a differential diagnosis?
explanation: Ludwig’s angina is not associated with the formation of a grey-white membrane. It is characterized by rapidly spreading infection of the sublingual space initially and later the submaxillary space, often dentogenic in origin. D/D for membrane over tonsil: Streptococcus & other pyogenic organisms Diphtheria Infectious mononucleosis Vincent’s angina Leukemia Candida Agranulocytosis Malignancy Apthous ulcer Traumatic ulcer
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following organisms is implicated in Vincent’s angina?
explanation: Vincent’s angina is caused by fusiform bacilli and spirochaetes, namely Bacillus fusiformis and Borrelia vincenti. The condition presents with low-grade fever and sore throat, and a membrane over the tonsil. The membrane is easily removed to reveal irregular ulcers over the tonsil. Throat swab will show both the organisms typical of the disease, namely fusiform bacilli and spirochaetes.
subject: ENT

question_text: A worried mother brought her 6-year-old unimmunized child to the ER with complaints of fever, cough, and shortness of breath. On examination, a pseudomembrane was noted in the oral cavity along with the neck finding as shown in the image. Which of the following statements is true regarding the membrane observed?
options: Firmly adherent and bleeds on remova
explanation: The given clinical history and bull-neck appearance (image) point to the diagnosis of diphtheria. The diphtheritic membrane is firmly adherent and bleeds on removal. A greyish-white membrane forms over the tonsils in the oropharynx and spreads to the soft palate and posterior pharyngeal wall. The membrane in diphtheria extends beyond the tonsils onto the soft palate and is dirty grey. It is adherent, and its removal leaves a bleeding surface. In the larynx, the diphtheritic membrane may cause airway obstruction. Cervical lymph nodes, particularly the jugulodigastric, become enlarged and tender, sometimes presenting a bull-neck appearance. The patient is ill and toxaemic, but fever seldom rises above 38°C.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following complications would you not expect to see in a patient diagnosed with diphtheria?
explanation: Hard palate paralysis is not seen in diphtheria. The exotoxin produced by C. diphtheriae is toxic to the heart and nerves. It causes: Myocarditis Cardiac arrhythmias Acute circulatory failure Neurological complications include paralysis of the soft-palate, diaphragm, and ocular muscles. In the larynx, the diphtheric membrane may cause airway obstruction.
subject: ENT

question_text: Following finding was noted in a patient who presented with difficulty breathing and a bull-neck appearance. Which of the following statements is true regarding the treatment of this patient?
options: Treatment is started after the culture comes positive
Sensitivity to antitoxin should be tested prior to therapy
explanation: The pseudomembrane on oral examination and bull neck appearance is characteristic of diphtheria. Sensitivity to diphtheria antitoxin is common and should be tested prior to the initiation of therapy. Treatment is started on clinical suspicion without waiting for the culture report. The aim is to neutralize the free exotoxin still circulating in the blood and to kill the organisms producing this exotoxin. Antitoxins: Dose- based on the site involved, duration, and severity of the disease If < 48 hours or just confined to tonsils: 20,000–40,000 units If > 48 hours or extensive membrane: 80,000–120,000 units Given by i.v. infusion in saline in about 60 min Sensitivity tested by a conjunctival or intracutaneous test with diluted antitoxin If a hypersensitivity reaction occurs, desensitization should be done Antibiotics: Benzyl penicillin 600 mg 6 hourly for 7 days Erythromycin is used in penicillin-sensitive individuals (500 mg 6 hourly orally)
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following cases cannot be posted for an elective tonsillectomy?
options: A young adult with chronic tonsillitis refractory to treatment
A patient with unilateral enlargement of tonsil with suspected malignancy
A middle-aged man with recurrent quinsy
explanation: Acute tonsillitis is a contraindication for tonsillectomy and hence, cannot be posted for elective surgery. Acute tonsillitis or any upper respiratory tract infection is a contraindication for tonsillectomy since there is an increased chance of hemorrhage and sepsis. Indications of tonsillectomy are: Recurrent episodes of acute tonsillitis – most common indication Seven or more episodes in 1 year, or Five episodes per year for 2 years, or Three episodes per year for 3 years, or Two weeks or more of lost school or work in 1 year Febrile seizures due to fever in tonsillitis Peritonsillar abscess (quinsy) - recurrent episodes in adults and a single episode in children Hypertrophy of tonsils causing airway obstruction, difficulty in deglutition, interference with speech Unilateral enlargement of tonsil with suspicion of malignancy Chronic tonsillitis with bad taste or halitosis which is unresponsive to medical treatment (relative indication)
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is not a contraindication to perform a tonsillectomy?
explanation: Diphtheria and streptococcal carriers are relative indications for tonsillectomy and the surgery can be safely performed in patients presenting with the same. Contraindications for tonsillectomy: Haemoglobin level less than 10 g%. Presence of acute infection in upper respiratory tract, even acute tonsillitis. Bleeding is more in the presence of acute infection. Children under 3 years of age. Overt or submucous cleft palate. Bleeding disorders, e.g. leukaemia, purpura, aplastic anaemia or haemophilia. At the time of epidemic of polio. Uncontrolled systemic disease, e.g. diabetes, cardiac disease, hypertension or asthma. Tonsillectomy is avoided during the period of menses.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient develops bleeding from the surgical site five hours after an elective tonsillectomy. Which among the following would best describe the condition?
explanation: Bleeding from the surgical site within a period of 24 hours is categorised as a reactionary haemorrhage. Primary haemorrhage - occurs at the time of operation. Secondary haemorrhage - usually seen between the fifth to tenth postoperative days.
subject: ENT

question_text:
While preparing for a procedure, the patient was kept in a specific position as depicted in the image. In which of the following procedures is this position not adopted?

Tonsillectomy
explanation: The given image shows Rose's position and it is not a suitable position to perform a direct laryngoscopy. The barking-dog position is used for direct laryngoscopy. Rose’s position: The patient lies supine with head extended by placing a pillow under the shoulders. It is followed in adenoidectomy, tonsillectomy, and tracheostomy. Barking-dog position: Patient lies supine. The Head is elevated by 10–15 cm by placing a pillow under the occiput or raising the operation table’s head flap. The neck is flexed on the thorax and the head is extended on the atlanto-occipital joint. Abscesses of Pharynx
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following marked structures is the space of Gillette?
explanation: Option 1 is Gillette’s space. Retropharyngeal space is divided into two lateral compartments (spaces of Gillette) by a median fibrous raphe. Option 2 - Danger space - between alar fascia anteriorly and prevertebral fascia posteriorly. Option 3 - Prevertebral space. Option 4 - Anterior cervical space.
subject: ENT

question_text: An ENT surgeon is performing an incision and drainage for a retropharyngeal abscess due to suppurative lymphadenitis. Which among the following groups of lymph nodes is most likely to be involved?
explanation: Rouvier Nodes or retropharyngeal lymph nodes suppurate to form retropharyngeal abscess. Each lateral compartment of retropharyngeal space contains lymph nodes that usually disappear at 3-4 years of age. Suppuration of these lymph nodes is the most common cause of retropharyngeal space abscess in children. Option B - Delphian nodes are the pre-laryngeal lymph nodes. Option C - Virchow's node is the left supraclavicular lymph node. Option D - Cloquet’s nodes are the deep inguinal lymph nodes.
subject: ENT

question_text: A concerned mother brought her toddler to the ER with complaints of noisy breathing and the child refusing to feed. On examination, the child has adenoid facies and there is a bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall lateral to the midline. Which of the following is a false statement regarding the disease described above?
options: Suppuration of nodes of Rouvier can cause the above condition
Caries of the cervical spine is the most common cause
In adults similar condition may result from penetrating injury of the cervical esophagus
Torticollis is one of the symptoms.
explanation: The above clinical condition is suggestive of acute retropharyngeal abscess whereas caries of the cervical spine results in a chronic retropharyngeal abscess. Acute retropharyngeal abscess is commonly seen in children below 3 years. It is the result of suppuration of retropharyngeal lymph nodes secondary to infection in the adenoids, nasopharynx, posterior nasal sinuses, or nasal cavity. In adults, it may result from penetrating injury of the posterior pharyngeal wall or cervical esophagus. Clinical features of a retropharyngeal abscess include Dysphagia and difficulty in breathing - as the abscess obstructs the air and food passages. Stridor and croupy cough Torticollis - the neck becomes stiff and the head is kept extended. A bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall, usually seen on one side of the midline. Chronic retropharyngeal abscess is the result of Caries of the cervical spine Tuberculous infection of retropharyngeal lymph nodes secondary to tuberculosis of deep cervica nodes.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 42-year-old HIV positive man presents with an acute onset high-grade fever with chills and shortness of breath. On evaluation, he's diagnosed to have a necrotising mediastinitis secondary to rupture of a retropharyngeal abscess. What is the likely route of spread of infection to the mediastinum?
options: Between buccopharyngeal fascia and alar fascia.
Between alar fascia and prevertebral fascia
Between the capsule of tonsil and superior constrictor muscle
explanation: The likely route of spread of infection is between the alar fascia anteriorly and the prevertebral fascia posteriorly. It is also called the danger space or alar space. It lies just posterior to the retropharyngeal space. It extends from the skull base to the diaphragm. Infections from this space can spread to the mediastinum, and hence it is named the danger space.
subject: ENT

question_text: Given below is an X-ray of a child who presented with stridor. What is your diagnosis?
explanation: The given image is suggestive of a retropharyngeal abscess. It can be diagnosed on a lateral x-ray of the soft tissues of the neck. The features include : Widening of the prevertebral soft tissue shadow Loss of cervical lordosis In an acute abscess, air-fluid levels can be seen.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following options is synonymous with quinsy?
explanation: Quinsy is synonymous with peritonsillar abscess. It is the collection of pus between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx.
subject: ENT

question_text: A middle-aged diabetic man who had undergone a tooth extraction presents with fever and trismus. On examination, his posterior pillar is pushed medially and there is a swelling in the neck at the upper 1/3rd of the sternocleidomastoid muscle. What is the most likely diagnosis?
explanation: The clinical scenario is suggestive of parapharyngeal abscess. Parapharyngeal abscess presents with: Trismus due to spasm of medial pterygoid Tonsils pushed medially Swelling in the upper part of the sternocleidomastoid (space limited to the level of hyoid bone). Option A - Retropharyngeal abscess presents as a bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall on one side of the midline. Option C - In Ludwig’s angina, tonsils are not pushed medially. Option D - Peritonsillar abscess doesn’t produce swelling in the upper 1/3rd of the sternocleidomastoid.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is not synonymous with parapharyngeal abscess?
explanation: Parapharyngeal abscess is not synonymous with medial pharyngeal abscess. Parapharyngeal abscess is synonymous with pharyngomaxillary or lateral pharyngeal or pterygomaxillary abscess.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is correct regarding a parapharyngeal abscess?
options: Always spreads from the retropharyngeal space
It has preponderance for male gender
explanation: Parapharyngeal abscess has a preponderance for male gender. Parapharyngeal abscess is an emergency condition. Infection can spread to the parapharyngeal space from any of the other deep neck spaces - peritonsillar, retropharyngeal and submandibular spaces. It commonly spreads from a dental infection, tonsillitis or peritonsillar abscesses. The patient is usually systemically unwell, with severe trismus and possibly airway compromise. Initial broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics should include cover against streptococci and anaerobic organisms. Carotid sheath vessel thrombosis, necrotizing fasciitis and mediastinitis are some of the complications. Marked neck swelling, airway compromise, and male gender appear to be predictive of higher-risk cases.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following features will not be manifested in an infection of the post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space?
explanation: Trismus is not a feature of infection of the post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space. Trismus is seen in pre-styloid abscess due to the involvement of medial pterygoid muscle. Parapharyngeal space is divided into two compartments by the styloid process and its attachments. Clinical features depend on the compartment involved. In a post-styloid abscess, there is a bulge of the pharynx behind the posterior pillar, accompanied by paralysis of cranial nerves IX, X (resulting in vocal cord paralysis), XI, XII, and the sympathetic chain, which can manifest as Horner's syndrome. Swelling in the parotid region may also be present. Notably, trismus, the inability to fully open the mouth, is usually absent in this type of abscess.
