A pre-styloid abscess exhibits distinct features including the prolapse of the tonsil and tonsillar fossa, along with trismus caused by the spasm of the medial pterygoid muscle. Marked odynophagia is common. Additionally, an external swelling can be observed behind the angle of the jaw. Fever, sore throat, torticollis (caused by spasm of the prevertebral muscles), and signs of systemic toxicity are common features. Diagnosis can be established using a contrast-enhanced CT scan (CECT). If there is suspicion of thrombosis of the internal jugular vein or an aneurysm of the internal carotid artery, magnetic resonance arteriography (MRA) can be useful. Patients require intravenous antibiotic therapy with amoxicillin-clavulanic acid, carbapenem antibiotics plus drugs that target anaerobic organisms, such as clindamycin or metronidazole. A parapharyngeal abscess is drained by an external horizontal incision made on the skin a few centimeters below the angle of the mandible. The image attached below shows the components of both spaces:
subject: ENT

question_text: In which of the following clinical scenarios will you not perform an intraoral incision?
options: A 21-year-old woman with fever, hot potato voice and bulging of soft palate and anterior pillar above the tonsil on the right side.
A 50-year-old diabetic man with fever, neck swelling over upper ■ rd of the left sternocleidomastoid and the tonsils on the same side pushed medially
A 3-year-old child with fever and swelling in the posterior pharyngeal wall lateral to the midline
A 50-year-old man with fever due to penetrating injury of oral mucosa by wood splinters
explanation: An intraoral incision is not sufficient in the case of option B - parapharyngeal abscess. An external neck incision must be made always to ensure complete drainage of the abscess. Option A- This is a case of quinsy as the child has odynophagia and a hot potato voice. Option B - This is a case of parapharyngeal abscess as the swelling is in the upper 1/3rd of the neck and the tonsil of the same side is pushed medially Option C- This is a case of retropharyngeal abscess since there is fever and swelling in the posterior pharyngeal wall lateral to the midline. Option D- This is a case of Sublingual abscess involving the sublingual space which is caused by penetrating injuries of oral mucosa due to fishbone or wood splinters. Indications for Incision and Drainage: Sublingual abscess: Always intraoral incision Parapharyngeal abscess: Always external neck incision. Peritonsillar abscess: Always intraoral. Retropharyngeal abscess: Intraoral - in rose position External - Dean approach Ludwig’s angina: Intraoral—if the infection is still localized to sublingual space. External—if the infection involves submaxillary space.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 9-year-old boy comes with complaints of right ear pain, difficulty in opening the mouth, painful swallowing, and fever. The oral cavity examination reveals the following. The external facial examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is likely?
explanation: The given clinical scenario describes a child with fever, otalgia, trismus, and odynophagia with a normal external facial examination. The oral cavity shows congested and edematous tonsil and tonsillar pillars with edematous uvula pushed to the opposite side. These findings are highly suggestive of quinsy (peritonsillar abscess). It is the collection of pus in the peritonsillar space between the fibrous capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscles of the pharynx. Both aerobic and anaerobic organisms are seen. Patient presents with fever, unilateral throat pain, odynophagia, hot potato voice, torticollis, foul breath, referred otalgia through glossopharyngeal nerve and trismus due to spasm of pterygoid muscles. Oral cavity examination may show congested and edematous tonsils, pillars, and soft palate on the involved side. Edematous uvula pushed to the opposite side. Pus may be seen on the tonsillar region. Jugulodigastric lymph nodes may be enlarged. The management of quinsy is by antibiotics and incision and drainage to drain the abscess followed by interval tonsillectomy 4 to 6 weeks later. Rare complications seen are parapharyngeal abscess, edema of the larynx, septicemia, lung abscess, or jugular vein thrombosis. Other options: Option A: Pharyngitis presents with fever, throat pain, enlarged tonsils, and lymphoid follicles on the posterior pharyngeal wall. Option B: Parotid abscess occurs due to the suppuration of parotid space. It presents with swelling, redness, firmness, and tenderness in the parotid area and at the angle of the mandible. It is usually unilateral, but bilateral abscesses can occur. Due to the thick capsule, fluctuation is often difficult to elicit. Option C: Bezold abscess is a complication of acute otomastoiditis where the infection/pus breaks through the thin medial side of the tip of the mastoid and presents as a swelling in the upper part of the neck.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following statements about quinsy is false?
options: Collection of pus between the capsule of tonsil and superior constrictor
Presents with odynophagia and drooling of saliva
explanation: Peritonsillar abscess or quinsy is usually unilateral. It is a collection of pus in the peritonsillar space which lies between the capsule of the tonsil and the superior constrictor muscle. Usually, it is unilateral though occasionally bilateral abscesses are recorded. It presents with marked odynophagia such that the patient cannot even swallow his saliva which dribbles from the angle of his mouth. The patient is usually dehydrated. Muffled and thick speech, often called hot potato voice.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 16-year-old girl presented with complaints of fever, right-sided throat pain, and difficulty in swallowing. On examination, she had hot potato speech and halitosis. The right tonsil was not visualised due to oedematous pillars and the uvula was pushed to the left. How will you manage this patient?
explanation: The above clinical scenario is suggestive of peritonsillar abscess or quinsy and management involves incision and drainage with antibiotics. Management of quinsy Hospitalization Intravenous fluids to combat dehydration Antibiotics - Suitable antibiotics in large IV doses to cover aerobes and anaerobes Analgesics Drainage by needle aspiration or incision and drainage Tonsillectomy when there is airway obstruction or recurrence. Incision and drainage of the abscess: A peritonsillar abscess is opened at the point of the maximum bulge above the upper pole of the tonsil or just lateral to the point of junction of the anterior pillar with a line drawn through the base of the uvula.
subject: ENT

question_text: In a patient with recurrent peritonsillar abscess, when is the ideal time to perform a tonsillectomy?
explanation: In a patient with recurrent peritonsillar abscess (quinsy), ideally, an interval tonsillectomy is done 4-6 weeks after the infection settles down. Hot tonsillectomy: Earlier tonsillectomy was done during incision and drainage. But this is not followed now as it is dangerous and can lead to aspiration, bleeding & spread of infection.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient presents with complaints of pain while swallowing since 2 days. He also gives a history of toothache since 1 week. On examination, there is a swelling and erythema as in the figure below. What is your diagnosis?
explanation: The above clinical scenario is suggestive of Ludwig’s angina. Ludwig’s angina is an infection of the submandibular space which lies between the mucous membrane of the floor of the mouth and tongue on one side and the superficial layer of deep cervical fascia extending between the hyoid bone and mandible on the other.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is a false statement about Ludwig’s angina?
options: It involves both sublingual and submandibular space
Dental infections are the most common cause
H.influenza is the most common organism implicated.
explanation: Mixed infection with aerobes and anaerobes is seen in Ludwig’s angina. Among these alpha-hemolytic streptococci, staphylococci and Bacteroides groups are common. Ludwig’s angina is an infection of the submandibular space. The space is divided into two compartments by the mylohyoid muscle: Sublingual compartment (above the mylohyoid). Submandibular and submental compartment (below the mylohyoid). The two compartments are continuous around the posterior border of the mylohyoid muscle. Both compartments freely communicate in the midline with the opposite side. Therefore infection rapidly becomes bilateral. The most common cause of Ludwig's angina is dental infections (accounts for 80%) of cases.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 23-year-old man presents to the OPD with odynophagia and swelling. He is diagnosed with Ludwig’s angina. How might you describe the swelling?
options: Tender fluctuant swelling in the floor of mouth
Tender fluctuant swelling in the parotid region
Woody hard swelling in the floor of mouth
Woody hard swelling in the parotid region
explanation: Ludwig's angina presents as a tender woody hard swelling on the floor of the mouth. There can be marked difficulty in swallowing (odynophagia) with varying° of trismus. The tongue is progressively pushed upwards and backward, threatening the airway. Laryngeal edema may also be present. Usually, there is cellulitis of the tissues rather than frank abscess. Incision and drainage show salted pork appearance.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 50-year-old man with multiple comorbidities, post-op day 5 of major abdominal surgery has developed high-grade fever and swelling over the parotid area. On examination, there is tenderness, induration and pus exuding from the Stenson’s duct on applying pressure over the parotids. Which of the following options is not a likely cause for the above condition?
explanation: The above clinical scenario is suggestive of a parotid abscess and excessive gland stimulation is not a cause for its formation. Etiology of Parotid Abscess: Dehydration, particularly in postsurgical cases (5-7 post-op days) and debilitated patients, with stasis of salivary flow is the predisposing cause. Infection from the oral cavity travels via the Stenson’s duct to invade the parotid gland (retrograde spread of infection). The most common organism is Staphylococcus aureus but Streptococci, anaerobic organisms, and rarely the gram negative organisms have also been cultured.
subject: ENT

question_text:
A patient with a parotid abscess is planned for incision and drainage (I & D). Which of the following practices will you avoid in this patient?
Put an incision that is similar to parotidectomy
options: Blunt dissection of the pus pockets
Dissection parallel to the facial nerve branches
Wait for the swelling to become fluctuant before performing I & D
explanation: In a case of a parotid abscess, one must never wait for fluctuation or pus point to occur. This is because the superficial layer of parotidomasseteric fascia is tense and the fluctuation will be apparent only in later stages. A parotid abscess refers to an infection and pus formation in the parotid space. It is caused most commonly by Staphylococcus aureus. Post-surgical cases and debilitated patients with stasis of salivary flow are at risk of developing parotid abscesses. Patients typically present with unilateral swelling, redness, induration, and tenderness over the parotid gland and angle of the mandible. Dehydration and fever are also present. Diagnosis is by ultrasonography or a CT scan. Multiple small loculi of pus are seen in the parenchyma. Aspiration of abscess can be done to determine the culture and sensitivity of the infective agent. Correction of dehydration, improving oral hygiene and promoting salivary flow. Intravenous antibiotics are also used in treatment. Surgical drainage under local or general anesthesia is carried out by a preauricular incision as employed for parotidectomy. A skin flap is raised to expose the surface of the gland, and the abscess or abscesses are bluntly opened working parallel to the branches of the VIIth nerve. The skin incision is loosely approximated over a drain and allowed to heal by secondary intention. Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma
subject: ENT

question_text: What type of lesion is angiofibroma?
explanation: Angiofibroma is a histologically benign tumor but locally aggressive. It is a rare tumor, though it is the commonest of all benign tumors of the nasopharynx. Angiofibroma arises from the sphenopalatine foramen. Recurrent spontaneous epistaxis is the most common presentation of angiofibroma. The investigation of choice is a CT scan. There is anterior bowing of the maxillary sinus's posterior wall, which is referred to as the Holman-Miller sign/ antral sign. Surgery is the treatment of choice. Radiotherapy is used for tumors with intracranial extension. Chemotherapy is used in combination with surgery or as monotherapy when surgery is contraindicated.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient presented with difficulty in breathing and swallowing. On examination, a painless nasopharyngeal mass was noted. Angiofibroma was suspected. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?
explanation: The image shows a nasopharyngeal mass suggestive of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA), which is causing difficulty in breathing and swallowing. It is more common in males. The tumor is predominantly seen in adolescent males in the second decade of life. It is thought to be testosterone dependent. Patients have a hamartomatous nidus of vascular tissue in the nasopharynx which is activated to form angiofibroma when male sex hormones appear. A biopsy is contraindicated due to the risk of severe bleeding. The vessels lack contractile components and hence bleeding cannot be controlled with adrenaline.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 16-year-old boy presents to you with complaints of nasal obstruction and frequent nose bleeds. CT scan shows Holman-Miller sign. You suspect a benign tumour of the nasopharynx. What is its most common site of origin?
options: Anterior wall of the sphenoid bone
explanation: The given clinical scenario along with a CT scan showing the Holman-Miller sign is suggestive of the diagnosis of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA). It most commonly arises from the sphenopalatine foramen. From here the tumour grows into the: Nasal cavity Nasopharynx Pterygopalatine fossa Pterygomaxillary fossa Infratemporal fossa Given below is CT showing the anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus- Holman-Miller sign.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following features will not be seen in a patient with nasopharyngeal angiofibroma?
explanation: Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma presents with rhinolalia clausa (hyponasal speech), not rhinolalia aperta (hypernasal speech). The patients present with progressive nasal obstruction and hyponasal speech due to mass in the postnasal space. Profuse, recurrent, and spontaneous epistaxis is the most common presentation. The patients may be markedly anemic due to repeated blood loss. Conductive hearing loss and otitis media with effusion occur due to obstruction of the eustachian tube. It can spread to the orbit giving rise to proptosis and broadening of the nasal bridge, giving rise to frog face deformity. Other features include swelling of the cheek and cranial nerve palsies (II, III, IV, and VI).
subject: ENT

question_text: A mother brought her 16-year-old boy with a unilateral profuse nosebleed. After successful control of bleeding, a CT scan confirmed the diagnosis of juvenile angiofibroma. What is the reason for it to cause excessive bleeding?
explanation: Angiofibroma is made of vascular and fibrous tissues. Vessels of angiofibroma lack contractile components, they are just endothelium-lined spaces with no elastic or muscle coat. This accounts for severe bleeding as the vessels lose the ability to contract. Hence the bleeding cannot be controlled by the application of adrenaline. Therefore, the biopsy is contraindicated.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following deformity is likely to be seen in a patient with juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma?
explanation: Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma when spreads to the orbit, lead to proptosis and broadening of the nasal bridge, giving rise to frog-face deformity. Option A: Gorilla-like facies are seen in acromegaly. Option C: Bird-like facies are seen in the Pierre-Robin sequence. Option D: Lion-like facies are seen in Paget's disease of bone when craniofacial bones are involved.
subject: ENT

question_text: A teenage boy presents to you with recurrent epistaxis and hearing loss. On examination, he has a frog-face deformity and conductive hearing loss. Which of the following is the investigation of choice to diagnose the condition?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. Investigation of choice to diagnose this condition is contrast enhancement CT scan (CECT). MRI scan can be used complementary to CT to see soft tissue extensions of the tumor. Carotid angiography shows the extent of the tumor, its vascularity, and feeding vessels which mostly come from the external carotid system. Embolization of vessels can be done at this time to decrease bleeding at operation. A biopsy is contraindicated in this condition as it can lead to massive hemorrhage.
subject: ENT

question_text: In a suspected case of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma, CECT is performed. Which of the following signs will help diagnose this condition?
explanation: Anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus in CECT of head and neck is called an antral sign or Holman-Miller sign, which is pathognomonic for angiofibroma. Option A: Tram track sign is used to differentiate optic nerve sheath meningiomas from optic gliomas. Optic nerve sheath meningiomas will show a positive tram-track sign. Option C: Stripe sign/ tigroid pattern represents a specific pattern of demyelination, with sparing of perivascular white matter. It is seen in metachromatic leukodystrophy (MLD). Option D: Eye-of-a-tiger sign represents marked low signal intensity of the globi pallidi on T2W MRI images.
subject: ENT

question_text: Imaging of a patient with recurrent epistaxis shows the following finding. Which of the following statements is false about his condition?
options: Tumor does not have a capsule
Digital palpation should never be done in OPD
explanation: The image shows anterior bowing of the posterior wall of the maxillary sinus, which is called an antral sign or Holman-Miller sign. It is pathognomonic for angiofibroma. Recurrence of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is common. It is a rare tumor but is the commonest benign tumor of the nasopharynx. It commonly arises from the sphenopalatine foramen. It does not have a capsule. Digital palpation should never be done until at the time of operation, as it can lead to severe hemorrhage.
subject: ENT

question_text: A teenager has a mass in his nasopharynx that has minimally spread into the sphenoid sinus with no lateral extension. Which stage of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma could this be?
explanation: The mass has spread into the sphenoid sinus with no lateral extension, so it's Stage 1B according to the Radkowski classification. Multiple classification systems exist for the staging of juvenile nasal angiofibroma, of which the most commonly used ones are the Fisch and Radkowski classification systems: Staging of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (Radkowski, et al): Fisch staging system of juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (JNA) is a highly vascular and locally aggressive tumor seen almost exclusively in adolescent males, associated with significant morbidity and occasional mortality. Note: The Fisch system is considered to be the more robust and practical of the two. Stag e Spread IA Limited to the nose and/or na sopharyngeal vault IB Extension into  1 sinus IIA Minimal extension into the p terygopalatine fossa IIB Full occupation of pterygopal atine fossa with or without er osion of orbital bones IIC Infratemporal fossa with or without cheek or posterior to pterygoid plates Stag e Spread IIIA Erosion of skull base-minima l intracranial IIIB Erosion of skull base-extensi ve intracranial with or witho ut cavernous sinus Type Details 1 Tumourlimited to the nasoph aryngeal cavity; bonedestruct ion negligibleor limited to th e sphenopalatine foramen 2 Tumourinvading the pterygo palatine fossaor the maxillary, ethmoid, or sphenoidsinus w ith bone destruction 3 A:Tumour invading theinfrat emporal fossaororbital region withoutintracranial involvem ent B:Tumour invading theinfrat emporal fossaororbital region withintracranialextradural(pa rasellar) involvement 4 A:Intracranialintraduraltumo rwithoutinfiltration of the ca vernous sinus, pituitary fossa, or optic chiasm B:Intracranialintraduraltumo rwithinfiltration of the caver nous sinus, pituitary fossa, or optic chiasm
subject: ENT

question_text: A young boy with a history of frequent nosebleeds and unilateral nasal blockage. CT scan shows Holman- Miller sign. It also shows the presence of a mass in the nasopharynx that extends into and occupies the pterygopalatine fossa. What is the best treatment for this patient?
explanation: The clinical picture suggests that of stage IIB nasopharyngeal angiofibroma. Surgery is the mainstay of treatment of angiofibroma for stage I and stage II tumors. Radiotherapy is indicated in stage III where there is an intracranial extension or when the tumor is unresectable. Chemotherapy can be used for very aggressive resurrect tumors and residual lesions. Stages of nasopharyngeal angiofibroma: Hormonal therapy was used in the past, but not anymore. Stag e Spread IA Limited to the nose and/or na sopharyngeal vault IB Extension into  1 sinus IIA Minimal extension into the p terygopalatine fossa IIB Full occupation of pterygopal atine fossa with or without er osion of orbital bones IIC Infratemporal fossa with or without cheek or posterior to pterygoid plates IIIA Erosion of skull base-minima l intracranial IIIB Erosion of skull base-extensi ve intracranial with or witho ut cavernous sinus
subject: ENT

question_text:
Radiotherapy is indicated when the spread of angiofibroma extends to which site?
Infratemporal fossa
explanation: Radiotherapy is used for intracranial extension of disease when tumour derives its blood supply from the internal carotid system. Recurrent angiofibromas have also been treated by radiotherapy. Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following viruses is related to etiology of nasopharyngeal carcinoma?
explanation: Epstein–Barr Virus (EBV) is closely associated with nasopharyngeal cancer (NPC). EBV antigens are currently being used to screen high-risk populations. The antigens being used are Viral capsid antigen (VCA) - highly sensitive for NPC Early antigen (EA) - highly specific for NPC.
subject: ENT

question_text: What is nasopharyngeal carcinoma also known as?
explanation: Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is also known as Guangdong tumor. This is because the Southern Chinese province of Guangdong has the highest prevalence of the tumor. Chinese, especially from southeastern China (Canton), have a higher genetic susceptibility to nasopharyngeal cancer (NPC). Chinese emigrants are also genetically more susceptible, however, the susceptibility falls in subsequent generations. Other South-East Asian countries such as Indonesia, Malaysia, and people of Mongoloid origin are also more susceptible.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is not associated with a high incidence of nasopharyngeal carcinoma in high-risk populations of China?
explanation: Human papillomavirus is not associated with a high incidence of nasopharyngeal carcinoma in high-risk populations of China. EBV (Epstein Barr virus) causes nasopharyngeal carcinoma. HPV(Human papillomavirus) causes inverted papilloma of the nose. High-risk populations such as the Chinese have a very high incidence of nasopharyngeal carcinoma. The following factors have been implicated in the pathogenesis: Burning of incense or wood (polycyclic hydrocarbons) Consumption of preserved salted fish (nitrosamines) Vitamin C deficient diet (vitamin C blocks nitrosification of amines and is thus protective)
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient with a family history of nasopharyngeal carcinoma presents with nasal discharge and a painless lump in the upper neck. On posterior rhinoscopy, where will you most commonly expect to find a mass originating from?
explanation: The most common site of origin for nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmüller.
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the most common presenting feature of nasopharyngeal carcinoma?
explanation: Painless cervical lymphadenopathy is the most common (60-90%) presenting feature of nasopharyngeal carcinoma followed by- Hearing loss Nasal obstruction Epistaxis Cranial nerve palsies -Cranial nerves V and VI are the most commonly involved among all the cranial nerves. Headache Earache Neck pain Weight loss
subject: ENT

question_text: A housewife from rural Tripura with a past history of infectious mononucleosis presents with complaints of double vision and a neck swelling that has progressively increased in size. She also gives a history of nasal discharge and is annoyed that her husband is recently complaining of a change in her voice. What is the most likely speech pattern observed here?
explanation: The given case scenario of exposure to EBV, progressive cervical lymphadenopathy, nasal discharge, diplopia (involvement of cranial nerve VI), and change in voice is suggestive of nasopharyngeal carcinoma. The most likely speech pattern, in this case, is rhinolalia clausa or denasal speech, due to obstruction of the nasopharynx by the tumor. Rhinolalia clausa is the lack of nasal resonance for words resonated in the nasal cavity and is usually seen due to blockage of nose or nasopharynx Other nasal symptoms of nasopharyngeal carcinoma are: Nasal obstruction Nasal discharge Epistaxis Option B- Rhinolalia aperta (hypernasal voice) is seen in Velopharyngeal insufficiency. Option C- Puberphonia is the persistence of prepubertal voice into adolescence or adulthood. Option D- Muffled and thick speech, often called “hot potato voice” is seen in peritonsillar abscess or quinsy.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 45-year-old Chinese woman presents with left-sided cervical lymphadenopathy, nasal obstruction, and left-sided hearing loss. What is the most likely cause for hearing loss in this case?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Hearing loss, in this case, is due to serous otitis media. Serous otitis media is caused due to mechanical obstruction of the Eustachian tube by the tumor. The presence of unilateral serous otitis media in an adult should raise suspicion of nasopharyngeal growth.
subject: ENT

question_text: You have sent a patient with nasopharyngeal carcinoma and hearing loss for tympanometry. Which of the following tympanometry curves do you expect to find?
explanation: Type B tympanometry curve is expected in nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Due to mechanical obstruction of the Eustachian tube by the tumor, serous otitis media occurs, causing conductive hearing loss.
subject: ENT

question_text: You are an ENT resident on a clinical elective in Guangzhou. You receive a patient with painless cervical lymphadenopathy, conductive hearing loss, palatal asymmetry, and facial pain. Which of the following do you see here?
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Trotter’s triad/Sinus of Morgagni syndrome/Trotter’s syndrome seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma. Trotter’s triad consists of: Conductive hearing loss due to Eustachian tube obstruction. Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia due to involvement of mandibular branch of the trigemina nerve (CN V) which presents as facial pain. Palatal paralysis due to involvement of vagus nerve(CN X) which presents as palata asymmetry. Option A - Samter’s triad seen in ethmoidal polyps consists of nasal polypi, asthma, and Aspirin intolerance Option C - van der Hoeve syndrome is seen in otosclerosis consists of osteogenesis imperfecta, otosclerosis, and blue sclera Option D - Kartagener syndrome consists of bronchiectasis, sinusitis, situs inversus, and ciliary dyskinesia.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following branches of the trigeminal nerve is involved in Trotter’s triad?
explanation: The mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve is involved in Trotter’s triad. Trotter’s triad seen in nasopharyngeal carcinoma. It consists of: Conductive hearing loss due to Eustachian tube obstruction. Ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia due to involvement of mandibular branch of the trigemina nerve (CN V) which presents as facial pain. Palatal paralysis due to involvement of vagus nerve(CN X) which presents as palatal asymmetry.
subject: ENT

question_text: A known case of right-sided nasopharyngeal carcinoma now presents with drooping of eyelids, reduced sweating on the right side of the face, and constricted pupil. Involvement of which of the following structures leads to these features?
explanation: Involvement of the sympathetic chain causes these features. The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Horner’s syndrome secondary to nasopharyngeal carcinoma involving the cervical sympathetic chain. Horner’s syndrome consists of ptosis, miosis, and ipsilateral anhydrosis. Option B - Cranial nerve V (Trigeminal nerve) involvement presents as ipsilateral temporoparietal neuralgia. Option C - Cranial nerve VI (Abducens nerve) involvement causes ophthalmoplegia Option D - Jugular foramen involvement causes paralysis of cranial nerves IX, X, and XI, causing jugular foramen syndrome, also seen in acoustic neuroma and glomus jugulare.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following WHO categories does differentiated non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma of the nasopharynx belong to?
explanation: Differentiated non-keratinized squamous cell carcinoma is categorized as Type 2. WHO Classification based on Histopathology: Note- The latest WHO classification has combined types 2 and 3 into one category: Non-keratinizing Squamous cell carcinoma which is further subclassified into differentiated and non-differentiated types. Type Histopathological category Type I Keratinizing Squamous cell c arcinoma (SCC) Type Histopathological category Type Histopathological category Type II Non-keratinizing Squamous c ell carcinoma Basaloid squamous cell carcinoma is a rare subtype of epithelial cancer seen in the nasopharyngeal area. It was included alongside the above classification from 2005. It is known for its aggressive clinical progression and poor chances of survival.
subject: ENT

question_text:
A patient with persistent cervical lymphadenopathy now came with spontaneous epistaxis. Nasal endoscopy showed a mass arising from the fossa of Rosenmuller. Biopsy from the mass revealed a keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma. What is the treatment of choice in this case?
Surgery
explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nasopharyngeal carcinoma. The treatment of choice is radiotherapy. Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is extremely radiosensitive, hence treatment of local and regional disease is invariably radiotherapy. Stage I and II are treated by radiotherapy alone. Stage III and IV are treated with radiotherapy and chemotherapy. Chemotherapy can be neoadjuvant, concurrent, or adjuvant to radiotherapy. Anatomy and Physiology of Larynx
subject: ENT

question_text: At what level does the adult larynx end?
explanation: In adults, the larynx ends at lower border of C6. It extends from C3 to C6 vertebra.
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the average final anteroposterior diameter of glottis in women?
explanation: The average anteroposterior diameter of the glottis is 26mm in women and 36 mm in men. Glottis, also known as rima glottidis, is the narrowest part of the laryngeal cavity. It is formed by: Anterior 2/3rd by membranous cords Posterior 1/3rd by vocal processes of arytenoids.
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the primary function of the larynx?
explanation: The primary function of the larynx is to protect the airway from ingested food and aspirated materials. This is done by the sphincteric action of the larynx. Other important functions are: Respiration Phonation Building up of intra-thoracic pressure.
subject: ENT

question_text: The presence of which structure is responsible for infants to be able to breathe simultaneously while suckling milk?
explanation: The high position of the larynx in infants allows simultaneous breathing while feeding. The infant’s larynx is positioned high in the neck, level of the glottis being opposite to C3 or C4 at rest and reaches C1 or C2 during swallowing. The high position allows the epiglottis to meet the soft palate and make a nasopharyngeal channel for nasal breathing during suckling. The milk feed passes separately over the dorsum of the tongue and sides of the epiglottis, thus allowing breathing and feeding to go on simultaneously.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which embryological structure develops into the epiglottis?
explanation: The epiglottis develops from the hypobranchial eminence which is a part of the 4th arch.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following comprises the larynx?
explanation: The larynx has 3 unpaired and 3 paired cartilages. Unpaired: Thyroi Cricoi Epiglottis Paired: Arytenoi Corniculate Cuneiform.
subject: ENT

question_text: The lateral x-ray of an elderly man shows calcification of the laryngeal cartilages. Which of the following is unlikely to be involved?
explanation: Epiglottis is unlikely to be calcified as it is made up of elastic cartilage. Only hyaline cartilages can undergo ossification (calcifications on x-ray). It occurs between the ages of 25-65y. These calcifications may be confused with foreign bodies of esophagus or larynx on x-rays. The hyaline laryngeal cartilages are: Thyroi Cricoi Most of arytenoid. The elastic laryngeal cartilages are: Epiglottis Corniculate Cuneiform Tip of arytenoid.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following cartilage has a signet ring shape?
explanation: Cricoid cartilage resembles a signet ring. It has a wide posterior lamina and a thin anterior arch.
subject: ENT

question_text: The skeletal remains of a person were found in a nearby forest. The thyroid cartilage was identified and the thyroid angle measures ‰0°. The deceased person can be deemed as a
explanation: The thyroid angle measures ‰0° (right-angled) in men. It is the angle between the two thyroid lamina in the midline. It depends on gender: Men: ‰0° (forms the prominent adam’s apple) Women: 120°.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is called cartilage of Santorini?
explanation: Corniculate cartilage is also known as the cartilage of Santorini. Cuneiform cartilage is also known as the cartilage of Wrisberg.
subject: ENT

question_text: An E‹T surgeon is operating on the larynx of a patient and he approaches the arytenoid cartilage. Which of the following is false regarding the attachments of the arytenoid cartilage?
explanation: The apex of the arytenoid supports the corniculate cartilages. The following are the attachments of the arytenoid: Base - cricoi Vocal process - vocal ligament Muscular process - intrinsic muscles of larynx Apex - corniculate cartilages.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is not involved in the closure of glottis?
explanation: The posterior cricoarytenoid opens the glottis as it is the only abductor of the vocal cord. All other muscles close the glottis.
subject: ENT

question_text: An opera singer presents with difficulty raising the pitch of her voice while singing. Which of the following muscles is likely to be affected?
explanation: Cricothyroid is likely to be affected. Cricothyroid and vocalis (internal part of thyroarytenoid) are the tensors of the vocal cord which help in raising the pitch of the voice. The external laryngeal nerve is the smaller, external branch. It descends on the larynx, beneath the sternothyroid muscle, to supply the cricothyroid muscle. The external branch functions to tense the vocal cords by activating the cricothyroid muscle, and increasing pitch.
subject: ENT

question_text: Žou are the E‹T resident examining a patient in the wards. On asking him to swallow you notice the larynx moves upwards. Which of the following muscles is not responsible for this movement?
explanation: The sternohyoid is not responsible for upward movement (elevation). It is a depressor of the larynx. The extrinsic muscles of the larynx can be elevators or depressors. Elevators: Primary elevators act directly as they are attached to the thyroid cartilage and include Stylopharyngeus Salpingopharyngeus Palatopharyngeus Thyrohyoi Secondary elevators act indirectly as they are attached to the hyoid bone and include Mylohyoid (main) Digastric Stylohyoi Geniohyoi Depressors: Sternohyoi Sternothyroi Omohyoi Easy to remember: Check the other attachment(non-laryngeal side). If it's above the level of the hyoid, the muscle is an elevator. If it's below the level of the hyoid, it’s a depressor.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is an intrinsic membrane of the larynx?
explanation: The cricothyroid membrane is an intrinsic membrane of the larynx as it connects laryngeal structures to each other. Extrinsic membranes and ligaments connect laryngeal structures with surrounding structures outside the laryngeal framework like the trachea or hyoid. These are: Cricotracheal membrane Thyrohyoid membrane Hyoepiglottic ligament. Intrinsic membranes and ligaments connect laryngeal structures with each other. These are: Cricovocal membrane Quadrangular membrane Cricothyroid ligament Thyroepiglottic ligament. [Image unavailable] [Image unavailable] [Image unavailable]
subject: ENT

question_text: Following a road traffic accident, a 30-year-old man presents to the emergency department with maxillofacial trauma and inability to open the mouth. To establish an airway, an emergency laryngotomy is performed. Where is the opening made?
explanation: In laryngotomy, an opening is made on the cricothyroid membrane. Laryngotomy is also called cricothyrotomy or mini-tracheostomy. It is done as an emergency life-saving procedure to buy some time to allow a patient to be carried to the operation theatre. Once stable, it is replaced by intubation or tracheostomy. Most of the laryngeal foreign bodies are arrested above the vocal cords, i.e. above the middle of the thyroid cartilage. Thus, an effective airway can be provided by piercing the cricothyroid membrane.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is not seen as part of the larynx?
explanation: Labyrinth is seen in inner ear and not in larynx. The 2 mucosal folds within the larynx divide the larynx into 3 cavities: Vestibule: Above the false/vestibular folds Ventricle: Between the vestibular and vocal/true folds Subglottis: Below the true folds Saccule an extension of ventricle is present in the paraglottic space.
subject: ENT

question_text: A surgeon is worried about the spread of laryngeal carcinoma to the pre-epiglottic space. Which of the following structures do not border this space?
explanation: Suprahyoid epiglottis does not form a boundary of the pre-epiglottic space. The infrahyoid epiglottis forms the posteromedial border. Two potential spaces within the larynx provide an avenue for the spread of tumors: Pre-epiglottic space Paraglottic space. The pre-epiglottic space is bounded: Superiorly by the hyoepiglottic ligament Anteriorly by the thyroid and thyrohyoid membrane Posteromedially by the infrahyoid epiglottis and quadrangular membrane. The paraglottic space is bounded: Laterally by thyroi Medially by ventricle and quadrangular membrane Inferomedially by conus elasticus Posteriorly by pyriform sinus.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 35-year-old smoker presents with hoarseness of voice. On laryngoscopy, there is edema of the Reinke’s space. Where is this space located?
explanation: Reinke’s space is seen in the glottis. It is a potential space underneath the epithelium of vocal cords. It contains scanty subepithelial connective tissue. Edema of this space is commonly seen in smokers and is called Reinke’s edema or smoker’s larynx. The laryngoscopy image below shows diffuse bilateral edema of the vocal folds or Reinke's edema.
subject: ENT

question_text: Žou are performing a direct laryngoscopy procedure to enter the larynx and visualise the structures it contains. Which of the following structures form the inlet of the larynx?
explanation: Aryepiglottic folds form the inlet of the larynx. The laryngeal inlet is an oblique opening with the following boundaries: Anterior: Free margin of the epiglottis Posterior: Interarytenoid fol Sides: Aryepiglottic folds.
subject: ENT

question_text:
Which of the following muscle causes opening of laryngeal inlet?
Vocalis
explanation: Thyroepiglotticus causes the opening of the laryngeal inlet. The intrinsic muscles of the larynx acting on the laryngeal inlet are: Openers of laryngeal inlet Thyroepiglottic Closers of laryngeal inlet Interarytenoid (oblique part). Aryepiglottic (posterior oblique part of interarytenoids). Stridor and Congenital Conditions of Larynx
subject: ENT

question_text: Inspiratory stridor is found in what kind of lesions:
explanation: Inspiratory stridor is seen in supraglottic lesions. It is often produced in obstructive lesions of supraglottis or pharynx, e.g. laryngomalacia or retropharyngeal abscess. Expiratory stridor is produced in lesions of thoracic trachea, primary and secondary bronchi such as bronchial foreign body, and tracheal stenosis. Biphasic stridor is seen in lesions of glottis, subglottis, and cervical trachea like laryngeal papillomas, vocal cord paralysis, and subglottic stenosis. Stridor is an audible respiratory noise that gets produced by turbulent airflow through an obstructed upper airway. It is an inspiratory sound that may have an expiratory component. It is distinct from stertor which is a snoring-like noise produced from an obstructed nasopharynx or oropharynx. The intensity and pitch of sounds originating from the respiratory system vary based on their site of origin within the respiratory tract and may be heard with or without a stethoscope. Usually, the pitch of the sound increases, and the intensity decreases as one goes lower into the respiratory tract.
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the most common cause of congenital stridor?
explanation: Laryngomalacia is the most common congenital cause of stridor. It is characterized by excessive flaccidity of the supraglottic larynx which is sucked in during inspiration producing stridor and sometimes cyanosis. It presents just after birth and subsides by 2 years of age. Stridor improves (decreases) in the prone position, worsens during feeding. The cry is normal. On examination, omega-shaped epiglottis is seen.
subject: ENT

question_text: What is congenital laryngeal stridor also known as?
explanation: Laryngomalacia is also called congenital laryngeal stridor. It is the most common cause of stridor in newborns.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 1-week old infant has been diagnosed to have laryngomalacia. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?
options: Most common cause of stridor in newborn
explanation: Laryngomalacia has an excellent prognosis. Laryngomalacia is the most common cause of stridor in newborns. It presents just after birth and subsides by 2 years of age. Stridor improves (decreases) in the prone position, worsens during feeding. The cry is normal. On examination, omega-shaped epiglottis is seen
subject: ENT

question_text: A worried mother brings her 2-week old infant to you with complaints of noisy breathing that worsens during feeding. On direct laryngoscopy, the following is seen. What is the preferred treatment for this condition?
explanation: The clinical picture and omega-shaped epiglottis are suggestive of laryngomalacia. Conservative treatment is preferred for laryngomalacia as this condition self-corrects by two years of age. Tracheostomy may be required for some cases of severe respiratory obstruction. Supraglottoplasty is required in severe laryngomalacia. Signs of severe laryngomalacia include: Difficulty feeding Increased effort in breathing Poor weight gain Pauses in the breathing Frequent spitting up
subject: ENT

question_text: A 5-year-old child is brought to you with complaints of noisy breathing. On performing direct laryngoscopy, subglottic stenosis is noted. Which grading system will you use to report the extent of the stenosis?
explanation: Myer Cotton’s grading is used for subglottic stenosis. It is the abnormal thickening of cricoid/fibrous tissue proliferation below cords. It causes the airway to narrow and presents with dyspnea, biphasic stridor and a normal cry. Diagnosis: In full-term infants, subglottic diameter <4mm. In premature infants, subglottic diameter <3mm. The Myer Cotton’s grading system allows to stratify the stenosis and plan for treatment: Grade 1: <50% stenosis Grade 2: 51-70% stenosis Grade 3: 71-99% stenosis Grade 4: No lumen detected Other options Option A - Hyams grading is a predictive tool used in olfactory neuroblastoma. Option B - House Brackmann grading is used as a facial nerve grading system. Option D - Modified mallampati classification is used to assess difficult airway
subject: ENT

question_text: A 45-year-old man presents to the ENT OPD with a swelling on the right side of his neck. The swelling moves with deglutition. On examination, the swelling is compressible and there is a gurgling sound heard on compression. What is his diagnosis?
explanation: On compressing the swelling, there is a gurgling/hissing sound known as Bryce’s sign. The given clinical picture with a positive Bryce sign is suggestive of laryngocele. Laryngocele is an air-filled cavity within the larynx developing from the saccule. The patient presents with a neck swelling that is soft and compressible. Options A: Branchial cleft cysts does not move with deglutition. Option C: Cystic hygroma does not move with deglutition and usually presents before 2 years. Option D: Thyroglossal cyst presents as a midline swelling.
subject: ENT

question_text: You are the ENT resident performing a direct laryngoscopy procedure on a patient and report the presence of a laryngocele. The given condition is due to an enlarged diverticulum from which part of the larynx?
explanation: Laryngocele arises from the saccule of the ventricle. It is an abnormal dilation of the laryngeal saccule and extends beyond the thyroid cartilage and the ventricle. It is seen in trumpet players, glass-blowers, or weight lifters due to raised transglottic air pressure. It can be internal, external, or combined. External laryngocele presents as a reducible swelling in the neck which increases in size on coughing or performing Valsalva maneuver. Internal laryngocele is managed by marsupialization. External laryngocele is managed by excision (external/LASER).
subject: ENT

question_text: A mother brings her 4-month-old infant to the ENT department with complaints of difficulty in breathing. On examination, you notice biphasic stridor. Rigid bronchoscopy shows subglottic hemangioma. Which of the following is not included in the treatment of this condition?
explanation: The given clinical picture is of congenital subglottic hemangioma. Embolization is not preferred in congenital laryngeal conditions. All congenital laryngeal conditions tend to regress with growth. The principal management is conservative as many hemangiomas involute spontaneously. Depending on the status of the airway, treatment can involve: To wait and watch Steroid therapy Tracheostomy and observation If the condition does not regress with time, the modalities of treatment include: LASER excision Laryngofissure and excision -pexy and -plasty procedures (epiglottopexy, supraglottoplasty, etc)
subject: ENT

question_text: A 30-year-old singer complains of a change in her voice. Direct laryngoscopy procedure shows the presence of laryngeal cysts. Which part of the larynx does the cyst arise from?
explanation: Laryngeal cysts arise in the aryepiglottic folds. These are benign conditions that need no intervention unless they are large. Large cysts can cause airway obstruction/change in voice. These require immediate aspiration followed by deroofing.
subject: ENT

question_text: Identify the lesion of vocal cord in the image given below :
explanation: The image showing grape-like projections, involving the anterior part of the vocal cords depicts a laryngeal papilloma. Laryngeal papilloma is a benign tumor of the larynx caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV type 6 and 11). They can occur in children, most commonly around 3 -5 years of age (juvenile papillomatosis), as well as in adults. They involve the supraglottic and glottic regions of the larynx. Seeding of the lesions can occur during invasive laryngeal procedures, such as intubation. They have a high recurrence rate and very low potential for malignancy. Adult-onset laryngeal papillomatosis is less common and usually seen in males aged 30-50 years. It is less aggressive and involves the anterior part of the vocal cords. The treatment is the same as juvenile papillomatosis. Patients present with hoarseness, aphonia, dyspnea, or stridor. Laryngoscopy shows pinkish to white grape-like projections that can be sessile or pedunculate with a visible central vascular core. The diagnosis is confirmed by direct laryngoscopy and biopsy. Treatment consists of micro-laryngoscopy and CO2 laser excision. The image below depicts laryngeal papillomatosis on laryngoscopy: Reinke's edema (Option A) is a collection of fluid in the subepithelial space of Reinke. It generally occurs in patients with vocal abuse or smoking. The vocal cords will show diffuse, symmetrical swelling. The laryngoscopic image below shows Reinke's edema:
subject: ENT

question_text:
A 5 year old with gradually progressive hoarseness of voice over three months and respiratory distress for 2 weeks. Diagnosis is
Croup
explanation: The given clinical scenario of a child presenting with chronic hoarseness (3 months) of voice and respiratory distress for 2 weeks suggests the diagnosis of respiratory papillomatosis (juvenile papillomatosis). Croup (Option A) and acute epiglottitis (Option D), which cause acute upper respiratory tract obstruction, are ruled out due to the chronic nature of the symptoms. In croup, the upper airway obstruction becomes apparent after 1 to 3 days of low-grade fever, rhinorrhea, and pharyngitis. On the other hand, in epiglottitis, a child experiences respiratory distress within hours of developing a fever. Vocal nodules (Option C) are not typically associated with respiratory distress. Respiratory papillomatosis is the most common respiratory tract neoplasm in children. They are simple warts (benign tumors) caused by human papillomavirus types 6 and 11 commonly seen in children aged 3 to 5 years. The course involves remissions and exacerbations of recurrent papillomas, mostly affecting the glottic area (vocal cords), and supraglottis. The patient presents with progressively worsening hoarseness, sleep-disordered breathing, dyspnea, stridor, and severe airway obstruction if left untreated. Diagnosis confirmed by direct laryngoscopy, which shows grape-like projections (shown below), and biopsy. Treatment consists of micro laryngoscopy and CO2 laser excision. Antivirals like interferon alpha2a, ribavirin, cidofovir, and acyclovir are used as adjunct therapies. Other options: Option A: Croup (laryngotracheobronchitis) is caused by the parainfluenza virus. The patient initially presents with an upper respiratory tract infection (rhinorrhea, pharyngitis, cough, low-grade fever) followed by a characteristic barking cough, hoarseness, and inspiratory stridor. Option C: Vocal nodule (singer’s or screamer's nodule) occurs as a result of chronic vocal abuse. They appear symmetrically at the junction of the anterior one-third and posterior two third of the v cal cord. The patient presents with chronic hoarseness and voice fatigue. The image below shows symmetric vocal nodules: Option D: Acute epiglottitis is caused by streptococcus pyogenes, pneumococci, Hemophilus influenzae, and staphylococcus aureus. It is characterized by an acute rapidly progressive course of high-grade fever, dyspnea, and stridor. Voice and Speech Disorders
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following voice changes is seen in dysphonia plica ventricularis?
options: High pitched voice in adolescent boys
Hoarseness due to plication of epiglottis
Low pitched voice due to use of vestibular folds
Weak fatiguable voice in TB larynx
explanation: Dysphonia plica ventricularis is a low-pitched voice produced by the vestibular folds. It can either be due to functional voice misuse or due to organic lesions like fixation of the true vocal cord. It is characterized by a low-pitched, rough and strained voice. Treatment includes voice therapy and psychological counseling.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following statements is false about spasmodic dysphonia?
options: May be associated with other dystonias
Abductor type produces breathy voice and adductor type produces strangulated voice
Botulinum toxin is used in treatment
explanation: Spasmodic dysphonia is not only a local laryngeal disorder. It is associated with many neurological conditions too. There are 2 types of spasmodic dysphonia: Adductor dysphonia The adductor muscles of the larynx go into spasm causing vocal cords to go into adduction. The voice becomes strained/strangled. Treatment consists of botulinum toxin injections in the thyroarytenoid muscles on one or both sides to relieve the spasm. Abductor dysphonia It is due to the spasm of the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle and thus the glottis is kept open. The patient gets a breathy voice or breathy breaks in voice. Treatment consists of botulinum toxin injections in posterior cricoarytenoid muscles. Patients who do not respond to toxin injection can be treated by type 1 thyroplasty or fat injection.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 17-year-old girl is brought to the ENT OPD by her father who says his daughter has lost her ability to speak following the death of her mother. Her comprehension is normal but she is mute. Which of the following statements is false about her condition?
options: Vocal cords fail to adduct on phonation but adduct during coughing
Aphonia is sudden and unaccompanied by laryngeal symptoms
Treatment includes reassurance of this patient
explanation: The given clinical picture represents that of functional aphonia. In this condition, vocal cords are normal. Functional aphonia or hysterical aphonia is mostly seen in emotionally labile females in the age group of 15-30 years. Aphonia is usually sudden and unaccompanied by other laryngeal symptoms. Treatment is to reassure the patient of normal laryngeal function and psychotherapy.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 16-year-old boy complains of being bullied in school for his high-pitched voice. A Gutzmann’s pressure test is done which helps you to diagnose his condition. What condition does he have?
explanation: The given clinical scenario with a positive Gutzmann’s pressure test is suggestive of puberphonia. It is a condition seen in emotionally labile adolescent males. They continue to speak in the prepubertal high pitched voice. Gutzmann's pressure test is positive when pressing the thyroid prominence in a backward and downward direction relaxes the overstretched cords and produces a low tone voice. The treatment is speech therapy.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 45-year-old teacher comes to you with complaints of dryness, tightness, and soreness in the throat. He says these symptoms appear after long hours of talking in class. He is also unable to hold long conversations. On direct laryngoscopy, the following is seen. What is his possible diagnosis?
explanation: Phonasthenia is the condition seen in this patient. The clinical scenario of voice overuse and keyhole appearance of glottis point to this diagnosis. Here, both thyroarytenoid and inter arytenoid muscles are involved. Phonasthenia is the weakness of voice due to fatigue of laryngeal muscles. This leads to a phonatory gap. The shape of the gap depends on the muscle involved: Thyroarytenoid alone: elliptical space Interarytenoid alone: triangular space Both thyroarytenoid and interarytenoid: keyhole appearance
subject: ENT

question_text: You perform a direct laryngoscopy procedure on a patient and notice a pseudosulcus in the larynx. What is this condition due to?
explanation: Laryngopharyngeal reflux is the cause of the pseudosulcus of the larynx. Pseudosulcus of vocal cords is a depression in the vocal cord mucosa due to chronic irritation from the reflux. Vocal Sulci: Types True vocal sulci Pseudosulcus Etiology Sulcus vocalis Sulcus vergetur e Laryngopharyngeal refl ux Epidermal cy sts Developmental defect Treatment PhonosurgeryBreak the fibro us bands underneath Treat acid reflu x
subject: ENT

question_text: A 20-year-old woman presents to you with a common cold. Due to this, her voice has changed. Which of the following conditions does not cause a similar voice change?
explanation: Common cold leads to rhinolalia clausa. A large nasopharynx doesn't cause rhinolalia clausa but instead rhinolalia aperta. Rhinolalia clausa or hyponasality is a lack of nasal resonance for words that are resonated in the nasal cavity. Words with M, N, NG sounds like B, D, G. It is due to the blockage of the nose or nasopharynx. Common causes of rhinolalia clausa are: Common cold Nasal allergy Nasal polypi Nasal growth Adenoids Nasopharyngeal mass Familial speech pattern.
subject: ENT

question_text: What type of speech pathology will be seen in this condition?
explanation: Rhinolalia aperta or hypernasality of speech will be seen in this condition of cleft palate. It is seen when certain words which have little nasal resonance are resonated through the nose. The defect is the failure of the nasopharynx to cut off from the oropharynx or abnormal communication between the oral and nasal cavities. Common causes are: Velopharyngeal insufficiency Congenitally short soft palate Submucous palate Large nasopharynx Cleft of soft palate Paralysis of soft palate Post adenoidectomy Oronasal fistula Familial speech pattern Habitual speech pattern. NOTE: Clausa = Close; closed nose and nasopharynx Aperta = Open/aperture; abnormally open nose and nasopharynx
subject: ENT

question_text: Wagner and Grossman theory is related to
explanation: Wagner and Grossman hypothesis Explains the position of the cord in recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) palsy. States that “The complete paralysis of the recurrent laryngeal nerve results in paramedian cord due to the adduction by intact cricothyroid muscle”. Since cricothyroid is supplied by SLN, it is spared and causes mild adduction.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following nerves provide the sensory supply to the larynx below the vocal cords?
explanation: Recurrent laryngeal nerve provides the sensory supply to the larynx below the vocal cords. Above the vocal cords, the larynx is supplied by the internal laryngeal nerve- a branch of the superior laryngeal nerve.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following muscles is not supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve?
explanation: Cricothyroid is not supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve. It is supplied by the superior laryngeal nerve. A the other muscles are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve.
subject: ENT

question_text: While assisting a direct laryngoscopy procedure being done on a patient, you notice that the vocal cords are in a slightly abducted position. Which intrinsic muscle of the larynx is responsible for this?
explanation: Posterior cricoarytenoid is the only intrinsic muscle of the larynx that causes abduction of the vocal cords.
subject: ENT

question_text: You are a junior resident in the ENT department asked to examine a patient’s larynx. The patient has complete paralysis of vocal cords following a total thyroidectomy procedure. What is the expected position of the vocal cords?
explanation: Intermediate (cadaveric) position is seen in complete paralysis of the vocal cord. This is a neutral position of the cricoarytenoid joint. Abduction and adduction take place from this position. It is not always seen in cadavers (misnomer).
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the most common cause for bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis?
explanation: Surgical trauma is the most common cause of bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis. The incidence of permanent RLN paralysis is approximately 1% to 1.5% for total thyroidectomy and less for near-total procedures. Note: Previously, extra laryngeal malignancies had been the most common cause which included lung (50%), esophagus, thyroid, and larynx.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following does not cause bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy?
explanation: Ortner's syndrome is a rare cause of left (unilateral) recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy due to compression by enlarged cardiac structures such as the left atrium or pulmonary artery. Causes of recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy: Thyroid surgery Neck trauma Thyroid malignancy Cervical lymphadenopathy. Though the risk of bilateral nerve involvement is much less than unilateral, it is possible. Depending on whether the palsy is unilateral or bilateral, findings will differ. Terminologies in vocal cord palsy: Pure RLN palsy: abductor palsy (the only abductor, posterior cricoarytenoid is affected) Pure SLN palsy: rare (only cricothyroid, one of the adductors and the main tensor is affected) Complete paralysis: both SLN and RLN are involved.
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the most common inflammatory cause for vocal cord palsy?
explanation: Pulmonary tuberculosis is the most common inflammatory cause of vocal cord palsy. Lesions include: Apica Mediastinal scarring Mediastinal lymph nodes.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following nerves is more prone to injury, causing vocal cord paralysis?
explanation: The left recurrent laryngeal nerve is more prone to injury, causing vocal cord paralysis. The reasons being: It is longer as it loops around the arch of the aorta to climb back to the larynx. It is in association with more structures in the mediastinum. Other options: Right recurrent laryngeal nerve loops around the subclavian artery and therefore it’s shorter and safer. Unilateral paralysis of the superior laryngeal nerve is rare and they are usually a part of a combined paralysis.
subject: ENT

question_text:
A 45-year-old woman has undergone a total thyroidectomy procedure and has been shifted to the post-op ward. 2 hours later she develops stridor and dyspnea, but her voice is normal.
Which of the following vocal cord lesions is the most likely cause for her condition?
explanation: The above clinical picture of stridor and dyspnea with a normal voice is most likely due to bilateral abductor paralysis (B/L RLN injury). It is the most dangerous vocal cord lesion. A the other options will have an abnormality in the voice. Normal voice is seen only in B/L RLN injury. In bilateral abductor paralysis, Both the cords lie in the median or paramedian position, the airway is inadequate causing dyspnea and stridor. This may lead to death if untreated. The voice is good. Dyspnea and stridor become worse on exertion or during an attack of acute laryngitis.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient in the ICU is aphonic but can maintain respiration. He has a history of recurrent chest infections. Which of the following nerve palsies would you suspect?
explanation: The clinical presentation is that of bilateral complete palsy (SLN + RLN). Both cords are in a cadaveric position, the patient has aphonia but respiration is maintained. Aphonia is suggestive of bilateral complete palsy, unilateral palsy presents with hoarseness of voice. Sensations are lost from supraglottis (supplied by the internal branch of SLN), the patient will develop aspiration and multiple chest infections.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 25-year-old singer has undergone a subtotal thyroidectomy for thyroid nodules. She presents to you one week later with complaints of difficulty in raising the pitch of her voice when she tries to reach high notes. There is no difficulty in her breathing and her voice is otherwise normal. Paralysis of which muscle is responsible for her condition?
explanation: Paralysis of cricothyroid is responsible for the difficulty in raising the pitch of her voice. Cricothyroid is the main tensor of the vocal cords. It is supplied by the external laryngeal nerve (branch of the superior laryngeal nerve).
subject: ENT

question_text:
A patient has been posted for type 1 thyroplasty surgery. What does this procedure involve?
Lateralisation of vocal cord
explanation: Medialization of the vocal cord is done in type 1 thyroplasty. Note to remember: MLSL Type Thyroplasty Uses I Medialization In Complete pal sy II Lateralization In RLN palsy III Shortening (relax the vocal c ord) To reduce pitch IV Lengthening (tighten the voc al cord) To increase pitc h Laryngeal Carcinoma
subject: ENT

question_text: What is the false statement regarding carcinoma larynx?
options: Squamous cell is the most common histological type
Glottis is the most common site
Tobacco is an important causative factor
explanation: Laryngeal carcinoma is more common in males. Laryngeal cancer Male:Female ratio is 10:1 Risk factors: Smoking tobacco and alcoho 90-95% are squamous Most common site: Glottis followed by supraglottis and subglottis.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following cancers presents with hoarseness of voice as its earliest symptom?
explanation: Glottic carcinoma presents with hoarseness of voice as its earliest symptom. Lesions of the vocal cords affect its vibratory capacity. Therefore they are diagnosed early and have a better prognosis. Supraglottic and subglottic growths are often silent. Hoarseness is a late symptom.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following is not the reason behind the development of hoarseness of voice in laryngeal carcinoma?
explanation: Phonotrauma is not the reason behind the development of hoarseness of voice in laryngeal carcinoma. It occurs due to overuse of voice and is associated with the development of benign lesions such as vocal nodules and cysts. Hoarseness in supraglottic cancer and subglottic cancer indicates spread of disease to: Vocal cords with infiltration of the thyroarytenoid muscle Involvement of recurrent laryngeal nerve Cricoarytenoid joint involvement. Hoarseness in glottic carcinoma is early because lesions of the cord affect its vibratory capacity.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 60-year-old man is diagnosed with carcinoma limited to the glottis of the larynx. Which of the following lymph nodes would be initially involved?
explanation: Tumours limited to the glottis usually do not spread to any lymph node station as there are no lymphatics in the vocal cords. However, if the tumour invades the supra- or the infra- glottic spaces, lymph node spread can occur. Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common malignant tumour of the larynx. Glottis is the most common site of cancer.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following laryngeal carcinomas has maximum lymph node involvement?
options: All have equal chances of lymph node involvement
explanation: Supraglottic carcinoma has the highest chance of lymphatic spread in the larynx. Lymph node enlargement is often a presenting complaint as it occurs early in the course of the disease.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient has been diagnosed with laryngeal carcinoma limited to the supraglottis. Which of the following subsites will not be affected?
explanation: The Pyriform sinus is not a subsite of the supraglottis. Epiglottis, false cords, aryepiglottic folds (medial wall of the pyriform sinus), and arytenoids are the subsites of supraglottis. Aryepiglottic folds are shared between the supraglottis and hypopharynx.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 55-year-old man is diagnosed with supraglottic carcinoma. Which of the following lymph node levels is the earliest to be involved?
explanation: Level II (upper jugular) and III (middle jugular) lymph nodes are the most common and earliest nodes involved in supraglottic carcinoma.
subject: ENT

question_text: Which of the following statements is false regarding supraglottic carcinoma?
options: Epiglottis, false vocal cords are most commonly involved
Lymphatic spread to upper and middle jugular lymph nodes
Hoarseness of voice is an early symptom
Bilateral nodes seen in epiglottic cancer
explanation: Hoarseness of voice is a late symptom of supraglottic carcinoma. The most common site of supraglottic carcinoma is the epiglottis followed by false cords and then aryepiglottic folds. Nodal metastases occur early to the upper and middle jugular lymph nodes. Bilateral metastases can be seen in cases of epiglottic cancer. Supraglottic growths are often silent as hoarseness is a late symptom.
subject: ENT

question_text: A patient has been posted for a surgical procedure to excise cancerous lesions from the vocal cords. Which laser is most commonly used?
explanation: Endoscopic resection with CO2 laser is most commonly used in laryngeal surgeries. Carcinoma of the mobile membranous vocal cords can be precisely excised with the CO2 laser under the microscope. It gives the same result as being traditionally treated with radiotherapy. Laser excision has the advantage of lower cost, lower duration of treatment, and morbidity.
subject: ENT

question_text: A 50-year-old man presents to you with complaints of weight loss, hoarseness of voice, and difficulty in breathing. On direct laryngoscopy, a mass involving both the vocal cords with extension to the subglottis is seen. Cords are immobile and there is no lymph node involvement. A biopsy confirms the diagnosis of glottic carcinoma. What is the next step in the management of this case?
explanation: The clinical picture of glottic carcinoma involving immobile vocal cords with extension to the subglottis suggests that the tumour belongs to the T3 stage. The treatment of choice is concurrent chemotherapy and radiotherapy. TNM classification of glottic carcinoma (American Joint Committee on Cancer, 2002) Treatment of laryngeal cancers: TLM: Transoral laser microsurgery; RT: Radiotherapy; OPL: Open partial laryngectomy; CT: Chemotherapy; CRT: Chemoradiotherapy, TL: Total laryngectomy. question_text: In which of the following conditions would you not recommend a total laryngectomy as the treatment?
options: Glottic carcinoma with invasion of the thyroid cartilage
Glottic carcinoma involving the posterior commissure
Transglottic tumours with fixation of the vocal cords
Tumour involving both vocal cords with normal mobility
explanation: Tumour limited to both vocal cords with normal mobility can be classified as stage T1b. Treatment will include radiotherapy or transoral laser microsurgery. There is no indication for a total laryngectomy. Total laryngectomy is indicated in: All T4 lesions Invasion of thyroid or cricoid cartilage Bilateral arytenoid cartilage involvement Lesions of the posterior commissure Failure after radiotherapy or conservation surgery Transglottic cancers with cord fixation. It is contraindicated in patients with distant metastasis. Treatment of T3 cancers is controversial, open vertical hemilaryngectomy and more extensive partial laryngectomies are used in carefully selected cases. Total laryngectomy or CRT is recommended for bulky T3 tumors or tumors not suitable for conservation laryngeal surgery.
subject: ENT

question_text: In the oncology ward, four patients have been diagnosed with laryngeal carcinoma. Which of the following patients would you advise for transoral laser microsurgery as the first choice?
options: A patient with vocal cord palsy, with subglottic extension
A patient with tumor limited to one cord, with normal mobility
A patient with tumor invading the thyroid cartilage
A patient with tumor limited to larynx, with fixed cord
explanation: Among the given options, a patient with tumor limited to one cord, with normal mobility will be advised for transoral laser microsurgery as the first choice. TNM staging in this patient is T1a. Option A: TNM staging here is T2b and the patient is advised for chemoradiotherapy as the first choice. Option C: TNM staging here is T4a and the patient is advised for total laryngectomy as the first choice. Option D: TNM staging here is T3 and the patient is advised for chemoradiotherapy as the first choice. TNM classification of glottic carcinoma (American Joint Committee on Cancer, 2002) Treatment of laryngeal cancers: TLM: Transoral laser microsurgery; RT: Radiotherapy; OPL: Open partial laryngectomy; CT: Chemotherapy; CRT: Chemoradiotherapy, TL: Total laryngectomy. Stag e Description T1 Tumour limited to the vocal c ord(s) with normal mobility T1a Tumour limited to one vocal cord T1b Tumour involves both vocal c ords T2a Tumour extends to supraglot tis and/or subglottis, with nor mal vocal cord mobility T2b Tumour extends to supraglot tis and/or subglottis, with im paired vocal cord mobility T3 Tumour limited to the larynx with vocal cord fixation and/ or invades paraglottic space a nd/or minor thyroid cartilag e erosion T4a Tumour invades thyroid carti lage and/or invades tissue be yond the larynx T4b Tumour invades prevertebral space, encases carotid artery or invades mediastinal struct ures T stage Treatment T1a TLM > RT T1b (mid-cord lesion) RT/TLM > OPL T2a RT/TLM > OPL T2b RT ± CT > TLM T3 CRT T4a TL> CRT T4b Palliative manageme nt
subject: ENT

question_text:
Which of the following is an indication of high tracheostomy?
Vocal cord palsy
options: Suspicion of Laryngeal carcinoma planned for surgery later
explanation: Laryngeal carcinoma is an indication of high tracheostomy. It is done at the level of the 1st tracheal ring and an opening is made above the isthmus of the thyroid gland. The disadvantage of a high tracheostomy is subglottic stenosis at the level of the cricoid and perichondritis of the cricoid. However, in laryngeal carcinoma this would be a temporary measure as the definitive management is total laryngectomy. Tracheostomy involves making an opening and placing a stoma in the anterior wall of the trachea. Functions: Provides an alternative pathway for breathing by bypassing the obstruction. Improves alveolar ventilation by reducing dead space by 30-50% and reducing airway resistance Uses a cuff to protect the airways from secretions and blood Allows suction of secretions in the setting of the impaired cough reflex. Allows positive pressure respiration Allows administration of anesthesia Indications: Respiratory obstruction due to Infections (laryngo-tracheo-bronchitis, epiglottitis) Trauma due to external injury, mandibular or maxillofacial fractures Neoplasms Foreign bodies or edema Bilateral abductor paralysis Congenital anomalies Retained secretions Inability to cough due to coma, spasm, or paralysis of respiratory muscles Aspiration of pharyngeal secretions Painful cough Respiratory insufficiency due to emphysema, chronic bronchitis Instruments

question_text: A 25-year-old patient is to undergo mastoid surgery. Which of the following instruments will not be present in the operation theatre?
explanation: Lempert’s trocar does not exist. Option A: Lempert’s curette (scoop) is used for removal of bony septa and granulations in mastoid surgery. Option B: Lempert’s endaural retractor is used for endaural approach to ear surgery. It has two lateral blades which retract the flaps and a third central blade with holes. The central blade retracts the temporalis muscle. The central blade can be fixed to the body of the retractor by its hole. Option C: Lempert’s endaural speculum is used to spread open the meatus when giving the local injection or making an endaural incision. Lempert’s incision is used in endaural approach. It consists of two parts: Lempert I: It is a semicircular incision, made from 12 o’clock to 6 o’clock position in the posterior meatal wall at the bony-cartilaginous junction. Lempert II: Starts from the first incision at 12 o’clock and then passes upwards in a curvilinear fashion between tragus and the crus of helix. It passes through the incisura terminalis and thus does not cut the cartilage. Both mastoid and external canal surgery can be done.

question_text: A 20-year-old woman has complaints of reduced hearing on her right side. You perform a diagnostic test using the following instrument. What is the name of this instrument?
explanation: The image is of a Digital audiometer. An audiometer is an electronic device that produces pure tones, which can be increased or decreased in 5 dB steps. The amount of intensity that has to be raised above the normal level is a measure of the degree of hearing loss at that frequency. This is charted in the form of a graph called an audiogram. The difference in the thresholds of air and bone conduction (A–B gap) is a measure of the degree of conductive deafness. Uses: To measure the threshold of hearing of air and bone conduction Helps to predict speech reception threshold To diagnose the type of hearing loss and measure the degree For the prescription of hearing aids Helps to find the degree of handicap for medicolegal purposes A record can be kept for future reference.
subject: ENT
